star_trek_picard.review: I really liked this season one and it's focus away from Starfleet. I enjoyed exploring the wider galaxy away from the bridge of a Starfleet vessel. The opening episode Remembrance is one of the finest openings to any tv show. I also enjoyed Stardust City Rag and Nephante. What brings the rating down is the pacing with an inexperienced showrunner. When you get to the last two episodes, it feels as they were making it up as they went along.

A fine addition to boldly go. An amazing cast, well thought out story lines and some surprise guests make for a fun show that at the end of each episode you want to know. What happens next?

For me personally this was a good season of Star Trek. It was a refreshing change to all the ship (and space-station) based story telling of the past. Well at least the first 3 episodes and the last two :) Anyhow, some great character moments, some odd choices but not that terrible. I would enjoy Star Trek shows structured like this.

Evocation of some of the original themes of the Next Generation aren't enough to salvage this plodding first season from the tedium that some people might associate with erectile dysfunction. They're lip service at best.

Very Disappointed.  Not really the StarTrek we know and love.
1) No resolution to each episode.  Just one long drawn out convoluted storyline. 
2) Characters are one dimensional. Rafi cannot act beyond her "pissed off" mode.
3) Characters have no respect for Admiral Picard. Rafi contradicts everything he says and even tells him to shut up. Calls him J.L. , like some pet.  Is this how they treat the best captain in the Star Trek franchise? 
4) Storyline has serious holes.  The season depends on the need to make both Soji AND Ashu.  No explanation why the creators had to make Twins of her.  Just glossed over this critical issue to make the plot work.  (weak)

"Star Trek: Picard" - Season One Review

Season One of "Star Trek: Picard" offers a mélange of new and old, but not always in the right balance. At its core, the pacing struggles and plot holes are glaringly apparent. One of the more conspicuous issues is its veering into overt "modern wokeness", which sometimes feels more like a misstep than genuine progressivism. Star Trek, historically, has managed to champion ideals that resonate across generations; this interpretation feels more like it's forcing propaganda under a guise of nostalgia.

Moreover, the reintroduction of key elements - the Borg, Romulans, and the well-trodden synthetic debate - feels less innovative and more like rehashing old arguments. Especially the synthetic topic, which was thought to be resolved in TNG with Data. But the overarching disappointment? The underuse of Jean-Luc Picard himself in a series that bears his name. The blame seems to fall heavily on the shoulders of Alex Kurtzman, who seems to miss the spirit of Trek altogether.

Hits some decent notes, but the writing is terrible from plot to dialogue, and couldn't hardly connect with any of the new characters. In fact, I found them mostly annoying and I didn't even recognize Picard himself. Not to say he should be identical to his 1990's self, but c'mon - people grow and change but are still the same person.

Star Trek Picard is a worthy Star Trek series that (finally) breaks with a few traditions and thus looks a bit more contemporary. Exciting, well mixed. Unfortunately, the whole HD version on BluRay is not free of compression in the picture due to the lack of bitrate. The digital streaming variants are even worse. It's also a pity that everything was shot in an image format that would look good on old Western or Hostoria films, but not in a top modern science fiction series adapted to domestic TV sets. Despite all this, a recommendation for all Trekkies

Star Trek Picard ist eine würdige Star Trek Serie die (endlich mal) mit ein paar Traditionen bricht und somit auch gleich etwas zeitgemäßer wirkt. Spannend, gut abgemischt. Leider ist das ganze als HD-Version auf BluRay nicht frei von Kompression im Bild mangels Bitrate. Die digitalen Streaming Varianten sind sogar noch etwas schlimmer. Schade ist zudem auch, dass alles in einem Bildformat gedreht wurde, welches eher alten Western- oder Hostorienfilme gut stehen würde, aber keiner top modernen Sciencefiction Serie angepasst an heimische TV Geräte. Trotz all dem eine Empfehlung für alle Trekkies

Star Trek Picard does an amazing job of welcoming all the Next Generation fans home!!!  I was stunned when I first started watching this 3-season series!  Every episode feels like its own movie ... the acting is good, the visuals are second-to-none, and the story lines are just as compelling, I felt, as the original Next Gen. shows.

Each episode and season builds on each other so watching them out of order really isn't advised but I would rather you TRY at any point than not try it at all.

I was truly sad when I finished Season 3 and saw online that that was the final season ... although ... they most certainly left an opening for more episodes or a new spin-off to happen!

If you watched the original Next Generation series and gave it at least 3 of 5 then I think you'd be interested in this ... spin-off? ... continuation? ... Whatever!  If you REALLY enjoyed T.N.G. then I don't see how you would NOT like this show!

While some writing decisions left me wondering what the showrunners were thinking (Seven of Nine bringing a Borg Cube under her command was a wasted opportunity), overall this is a good series, and it's very underrated by some fans. For those feeling that it's not classic Trek, you're right, it isn't. Every era of Star Trek has felt different as they reflect the times they're made in. Compare the latter episodes of The Next Generation era with the original Kirk movies and they feel totally different in character and atmosphere. And those movies feel totally different to the original episodes of Star Trek, such as The Cage. On top of that, every series of Star Trek after the original (including TNG) has met with fans dumping on them and saying they don't feel like Star Trek. Fans said TNG wasn't Trek because it was a different crew. DS9 wasn't Trek because it was on a station instead of a ship. And I remember fans who couldn't stand Janeway at first. And don't get me started on how underappreciative fans were of Enterprise. But if you can accept that a new series of Star Trek will have a unique feel, and try new things, especially seeing as Picard is set in a new era, over 20 years after the events of Nemesis, you might hopefully appreciate what this show does right. It's very faithful to the lore of it's universe and covers a lot of ground in showing how the politics of the various galactic factions have evolved or changed, for better or worse. Most importantly, Picard is still Picard, an altruistic but stubborn diplomat who maintains optimism and ethics in the face of more cynical forces.

The comedy falls flat most of the time and the emotional scenes feel hollow. If you like corporate attempts to milk the franchise by providing nothing but shameless fan service then you may enjoy this series but if you want something of substance that upholds the legacy of Gene Roddenberry then forget it.

Picard Season 1 is an outstanding addition to the Star Trek franchise. The show captivates viewers with its compelling storytelling, impressive visual effects, and exceptional performances by the cast.
One of the show's biggest strengths is its writing. The show balances action-packed scenes with emotional moments, exploring complex themes such as morality, loss, and redemption. The pacing is excellent, and each episode keeps you on the edge of your seat, leaving you eager to see what happens next.
Patrick Stewart delivers an incredible performance as Jean-Luc Picard, reprising his iconic role easily. He brings depth and nuance to the character, making him feel more human than ever. The supporting cast is equally impressive, with standout performances from Alison Pill, Isa Briones, and Santiago Cabrera.
The show's visual effects are also top-notch, immersing the audience in a futuristic world filled with advanced technology and stunning landscapes. The production design is exceptional, with attention to detail that brings each scene to life.
Picard Season 1 is a must-watch for any Star Trek fan or sci-fi enthusiast. It successfully continues the franchise's legacy while bringing new and exciting elements. The show leaves you eager for more, and we can't wait to see where the story goes next.

And Dr Agnes: the meta variable of the show that lowers the tone of any interesting scene with her quirky "humour", as if we're meant to laugh because we were thinking the same thing...not to mention she gets away with murder at the end of it all, but I suppose we're meant to forget about that.

This show was a disappointment.  ST:TNG was a show that generally stayed away from action sequences and stuck to dialog and moderately cerebral things, wrapped up in the almost comical "science" of Star Trek.  This is what made it good, because that was entertaining.  Picard, played by a fantastic character actor (Patrick Stewart) takes what should have been a easy win by using what worked before and decides to make an 80 year old man into an action hero.  It is hokey and almost campy, if they weren't trying to be so serious, but not in a good way.  Patrick Stewart becomes the low point of the show, rather than the high point, because this show was not made for him.  It is moderately entertaining, and I did manage to finish watching the first season.

The first episode starts out with some promise, and (already) some concerns.  Unfortunately, as the series progresses, the latter prevail;  the writers channeling mostly dark (mostly recycled) sci-fi themes that do not always add up.   The narrative and direction are too often clunky, detracting from the story and themes (some of which were potentially interesting -- e.g., the ethics of the inherent value of sentient beings, the boundary between AI entities and living beings), and viewer enjoyment, instead leading to viewer disengagement and/or frustration.   Some acting is quite good (Soji, Dr. Agnes, Elnor, Hugh, Seven of Nine), some is inconsistent/melodramatic (e.g., Raffi - overacting too often, Rios - neither fully convincing as an existentialist former Star Fleet Captain or as a comedic force, both the brother and sister Tal Shiar agents), and Picard is over-relied upon so that, sadly, the limits of his acting during quieter nuanced scenes sometimes show themselves. His most interesting theme of the challenges of aging and persisting despite challenges, are often lost to soap opera quality plot lines and dialogue.

Overall, a significant disappointment, partly because we expect better from JL Picard and those in his universe.

I see a split among loyalists who hated it and who loved it.  I really enjoyed season 1. Brought me back to that euphoric feeling of when I watched TNG originals. THE COLORS and SOUND. My goodness is the series visually beautiful. The music is outstanding  as well.  The cinematography and editing has some wonderful highlights as well. Overall, it was a production success.

Even original actors could not fix the shithole that is the plot, the pace, the dialogues, actions and reasonings. I was really pleased to see Riker, because he reintroduced an old TNG feeling with his tone and phrases. Other than that, it is in no way for those who want to sap the luxury wine the original series were. The story features so many cumbersome details that try to push original to "how series are done nowadays", and in doing so, it completely scrapes off the individuality of TNG and blends the Picard series into thousands of mediocre storytellings we can watch on any network. You can not watch it with your kids also - because it's how series should be done today - a loss without any benefit in return. Authors tried to quickly submerge us into characters depths, yet there aren't any - all feel unwarranted or plain. Plot moves fast, and leaves us behind - "wtf is happening?" Nothing seems connected. Characters are used as tools to the plot. All in all, it's just another bad series from an endless list - to spend some time. Definitely should not be taken into canon.

Picard in name only. Sir Patrick Stewart brings his fantastic acting abilities to bear but that only heightens the dissonance with the disastrous writing and one note characters.

Stewart mentioned BREXIT as an inspiration for his return to the character that made him famous but this bloody, indulgent show does nothing insightful or clever with the premise. New Trek already killed off Roddenberry's optimistic vision of a humanity that became better but the misuse of a legacy character dances on that grave. Old Trek writers could have added something to the public discussion, approaching sensitive issues from a new angle possible only through sci-fi, but this bomb relies on nostalgic call-backs, brutal violence, and flashy special effects to really say nothing at all. What's the point? There doesn't seem to be one beyond providing content that's superficially 'Star Trek'. 

The only take-away I had is that Executive Producer Sir Patrick Stewart really never understood Star Trek after all. A disappointment after listening to him speak meaningfully on the topic at conventions.

Acting is uniformly great, some old TNG favorites make an appearance, it's moody, euphoric, utopic and dystopic, and above all very human. I found it exciting and a delight.

The latest Star Trek series from CBS seems to be suffering from modern-day storytelling. They want to delver a darker almost dystopian style show from an existing franchise, the problem is Star-Trek was never and should never have that style.

This show doesn't care about exploring new worlds and civilizations, it only cares about pushing a narrative and agenda. The characters are generally unlikable or completely different from their original counterparts. It feels like they used the Star-Trek name so they could make their own show and trick Star-Trek fans into watching it.

The only good thing about this show is the original characters reprising their roles.

I've seen a few articles criticizing Star Trek: Picard and realize, most of them are from those that don't get it. 
Is the dialogue a little cheezy? Sometimes, though I've heard much, MUCH worse (Mandalorian anyone?).
Is it heavy on sentimentalism and nostalgia? Most definitely. And, that's kind of the point. This is going to be the final chapter on the Sir Patrick Stewart "Jean-Luc Picard". The guys 80+ years old. He may be a health octogenarian, but at this point, each day is a gift. And, as the show is about JLP that's the tone it's going to take. It's an allegory about many things. It is also to tie up some loose-ends in the Picard story arc. And, it is also to illustrate that, no matter how old you are, it is never too late to evolve. 
Now, just like they did in the X-men, they have created ways for a character to be "immortal" by bringing in a younger actor and such. Star Trek is doing the same thing for Captain Pike, Spock and several other OG series characters. But, it will be a long time before anyone forgets Patrick Stewart's presence in the role, just like the ghost of William Shatner's Kirk has not yet faded. 
I for one will enjoy watching the 3rd season which has been stated to be the last one. And, I will also probably experience many feels. Not just of the nostalgia in remembering the series, but also connecting on a whole new level. Age and experience have provided greater appreciation and sensitivity to many of sense of generativity this show has tapped in to. 
It will be a bittersweet season because of the many implications folded in to the story. But I, for one, not only look forward to its story, but the new stories that it could potential spawn. So, ahead 1/4 impulse power and, engage!
Very well done. Good writing. Great Acting. Love the show.
Not good. Why not build upon the massive existing Star Trek universe? This series is an abomination.

What did I watch? I know Patrick Stewart said he was never a fan of his character, so why hand him the keys to the car? The writing on this show is some of the worst writing in the game right now. Clearly there is no regard for Star Trek and nobody actually watched the prior shows. If you love any of the old Trek - DO NOT WATCH THIS SHOW.

The fact that an unapologetically unintelligent and essentially what is an offensive and crude parody to one of the greatest, most thoughtful and most progressive series TV ever aired can get 9/10 reviews by critics just because it is accompanied by a big production network is really a quite depressing sight.

Why hire actual writers to make something deep and lasting when you can hire the transformers guy to make some regurgitated, daft, feverish garbage that'll be forgotten in 6 months? 
Crayons are cheaper than typewriters guys!
This borders on being truly bad enough to ruin a childhood.

No-one was a bigger fan of Star Trek than me. And *even* after Discovery, I was cautiously excited for this. My beloved TNG characters, back, for one last adventure. What could possibly go wrong? The answer is, that I literally couldn't finish watching it.

I don't mind the idea of an altered tone, versus TNG. The tone of the 80s movies was VERY different to TOS, for example. What I object to is that this show appears to be written by teenagers, who are incapable of nuance, with no understanding of story, character or motivation. Picard, as shown here, has literally nothing to do with the character from the original show. Nothing. And, in a way, that's a relief. Because it allows me to disconnect the show I loved so much, from this utter, utter dross. Still, I find it offensive that the writers had a canvas so expansive, and this is the best they could come up with. On the positive side... I guess it looks nice. Effects are fine. A fair amount of effort has gone into the art design. But that's just about the only positive thing I can offer. Whoever wrote this garbage should be genuinely ashamed.

I could rant for hours about how completely this 'effort' disrespects the incredible legacy of Star Trek - but there's no point. I've moved on. I guess I should have known, given the people involved. The reality is that nothing I say, or do, is going to stop this show from being made. I have no idea who it's made for - but I do know it's not made for me, so I'll check out. I won't be watching season 2. I won't be watching season 3. No judgment on anyone else's views - but I have better things to do with my time than watch this drivel.

Season 1 comes as a very good refresh of unforgettable themes and characters. And the launching premise is actually good and clever, leading to an expected, yet well-received finale.

After that, one wonders: why a Season 2? The answer seems to be just an unnecessary elongation of nostalgia, going back again to storyline gimmicks the whole franchise has kept through different incarnations in the last half-century.

In the opening episode of Season 2, Picard reflects the last frontier is not space, but time. Taking that in account: it is time the producers let ST rest in good memory.

Season 3? They say is in the making. I will pass it on.
It is well written and respectful of the history of Star Trek. The new characters are fresh and compelling. It is an excellent addition to the Star Trek Universe.

I tried hard to like it. I actually did like it until the last few episodes of the season. 
The whole Will Ryker part was campy, and no one believed his empty threats. The Romulan fanatics giving up made no sense and the whole fleet going away made no sense at the end, either fleet. They killed off the lovable Picard, but wait, no they didn't. So, let's bring back a lovable character to kill him off instead based on a Pinocchio complex that's supposed to make it seem okay. Picard's high morals were a slap in the face to the Synthetics showing he didn't really value them. Logically, they should have brought in the help to ensure stopping the genocide. There was no logical reason for them not to. There was more hope of convincing the synthetic super-beings to spare some bio life than there was the Roms would just give up their genocidal quest. Ah well.

The problem with Picard is they've made the captain more important than the idea and yet so much of the series the captain is sidelined by lesser characters who over emote and don't fit the mold of Starfleet.  I use to think Neelix from Voyager qualified as the Jar Jar of the Star Trek galaxy but now I think its that obnoxious Raffie. What should have been a bigger moment for Picard between the young dying Romulan cadet and Picard, his mentor, is hijacked by some of the worst acting / writing I have ever seen for a character. Its embarassing. I really want to like Picard but too often these newer lesser characters and their crudeness, pettiness, and cynicism hijacks the show.  Throwing salt into this wound are two episodes of just plain social commentary on present day.  Its bleak, its pointing fingers and there is no sucessful attempt to lighten the mood and laugh at our self as in previous incarnations.  Even the homage to Spock on the bus was lame.  The only thing this Star Trek has over the others is..well the effects look good.  Like Picard says with every new ship they keep getting slicker.  Unfortunately they are less artistic, less graceful and less inspiring.  It really does boil down to who is running the series and unfortunately they've allowed Stewart editorial control over the script as a producer.  Which I get it, they did so to get him on board but in hind sight it was a bad mood considering his previoius attempt at producing Star Trek ended in the epic bomb, Insurrection.  The greater fiends yet are the notorious killer of Transformers, Alex Kurtzman and the infamous Akiva Goldsman who wrote the Batman franchise into an early grave with Batman and Robin. Really this has bad written all over it from the start and no Q (John DeLancey), especially one who has lost his mojo, can save this tire fire.  Its only saving grace is that it might still end up better than the every topsy turvy disapointment that has been Discovery.  At this point I'm checking out.  All new Star Trek and Star Wars entries are just the studio dangling keys in front of a brainwashed mass.  From now on I'll stick with the classics on Blu-Ray and forget about anything J.J. Abrams or his cronies has ever touched regarding Star Trek...and for that matter Star Wars.  And just NO on further revitalising franchises and I mean any franchise even long running ones from the 1960s.
Old Star Trek [TNG, DS9, VOY) had more of a deeper, human connected feel and interwoven stories and plots. Nowadays it seems to be entertainment just for the sake of entertaining

This is a show that appears to have been written by people who have never seen Star Trek. From here there are spoilers. I know this has all been said in other reviews but the show doesn't understand it's characters, the central narrative pillars that drove Star Trek, the shows that followed it or any other aspect of the universe that Gene Roddenberry created. TNG and TOS were an optimistic view of the future when humans had found peace and surpassed base needs for the betterment of everyone. The Federation were a beacon of justice and a force for good, not the petty, rotten and corrupt organisation in Picard.  The characters here are all broken tortured creatures who will never surpass their flaws, Seven of Nine has turned into a bitter murderous mercenary, Agnes is a killer and the titular Picard does not resemble the captain that fans grew to love from TNG and the movies where the name is the only similarity. The rest of the crew are miserable shells of people. This is a dark angry universe with a relentless underlying nastiness. Even if you can get past all this the stories don't make a huge amount of sense and frequently stray out of Science Fiction and into Space Fantasy. At one point the crew fix their ship by "wishing hard enough"with a magic device that warranted a single dialogue line earlier in the episode, a robot does a mind meld, etc... It is as if the writers have seen the names of things and people from TNG and TOS but never bothered to find out what they were prior to popping them in a lazily put together "script". I could go on but by now you get the point.

The biggest disappointment of the year. After Discovery failed to delivery anything resembling Star Trek, I hoped Patrick Stewart might help lead the franchise back to its original positive roots. Instead we got ninja space gore with an inability to turn on the lights in a room and a psychopathic, unlikeable cast. Torture? Check. Murder? Check. Anyone who seemed remotely human and relatable? Nope. An actor's voice is the tool for their craft, and Patrick Stewart's voice is gone. It's no longer enjoyable to watch him on screen, and the cameos and halfhearted revivals of old characters are clearly just a gesture to pacify old Star Trek fans while they get on with murdering the franchise. Critics are too kind. Listen to the fans that know we deserve better than this show by committee.

Great series! It's Star Trek, enjoy it! Some nostalgia seeing former TNG characters. Great story involving the Romulans and synthetic life forms (like Data). If all you want to see is the same old Trek over again, like some of the reviewers giving one star reviews, then I guess don't bother. If you really do enjoy Star Trek, you should appreciate and enjoy this series. Season 2 dropping weekly now!

She's the best eye candy hands down in this series, if only to watch her, it makes this series worth seeing.  If in the multiverse there is a version of me who's married to her...I would crazy glue those pointy ears on her in her sleep.  I am not kidding...

What do you get is the new owners of Star Trek, who have already demonstrated they have no idea what Star Trek is, decide to take one of the most beloved characters from Star Trek canon and simultaneously rip off the plot of the Mass Effect series of games, that itself was a homage to the plot of Revelation Space?  The answer is "Mass Effect : Picard" and it is an insult to the whole of the Star Trek canon.
To sum up the show, a xenophobic federation tells the Romulans to stuff themselves and creates synthetics after one of the most important episodes of TNG establishes them as having sentience and therefore be protected by the Prime Directive.  Meanwhile, Romulan assassins who have played Mass Effect decide that indeed, there has to be a race of Synthetic creatures in the outer reaches of the universe that want to destroy all organic life, and they are right, but they totally missed the ones made by Noonian Soongs grandson. So the Romulans go to a place where there is EXACTLY THE SAME CUT SCENE FROM THE FIRST MASS EFFECT GAME warning them that they have to destroy all synthetics and Naturally, this means the Romulans hack the newly created synthetic slave race that is building the ships to save the Romulans from extinction and make them destroy their only way to save everyone.  Picard makes it all better with the help of a man raised by Romulan warrior nuns, Seven of Nine, a Spanish captain with a ship, an expert on synthetics and a washed up federation drug addled mother who has an estranged relationship with her son.  There's also a captured Borg Cube being worked on by Romulans,  
When Data asks to be killed at the end of the show, it is exactly how anyone who loved Star Trek should feel.  The writers, led by Alex "I write everything in crayon" Kurtzman who, for the 2nd time in his star trek career has ripped off a computer game" writes a nonsense, overly convoluted yarn that rips out everything star trek used to stand for in favour of momentary fan service that ends up killing Picard and replacing him with a synthetic body that still ages, bleeds and...
look, can we please just kill these characters off and be done with trying to reinvent Trek.  The fact is that CBS are going through the same errors as Warner Bros did with their DC universe.... committing rubbish to the screen of this magnitude really does mean star trek is dead.  please just stop.

Being  a long time star trek fan found this dissapointing and what did with captain picard character was atrocious and story was meh at best.  
And what did with offer characters hear and whole universe set in plus smoking and drugs was terrible don't know how else to put it.

Thing did like was special effects looked good so there was that the HD version anyway.

Lots of fan service and some genuinely interesting characters but one gets the impression writers and cast alike are still trying to find their feet.  Picard didn't really feel like the character we all know and love and the S1 ending was just wierd, but it still had some rewatchable moments.  The story arc about the Romulans ripping apart a Borg cube was interesting and explains where Nero got such advanced tech from in Star Trek 2009.
Utterly disrespectful of the source material.
A little underwhelming - nice to see some of the surviving Trek characters in a "where are they now?" sort of way. though. Hopefully a setup season for good things to come.

As a Star Trek fan from the 90s the next generation was the series that got me involved in Star Trek.
Wonderful characters and good stories and the explorer in myself I was drawn into the series early.
The new series brings in former cast members to join in the story while introducing new ones.
So far the series is very well written and very well acted expecting nothing less from Patrick Stewart. I can tell he's struggling onset to keep up with the pace of the scenes. But for some very accomplished performers, the craft dies hard.
The reason why I didn't give it five stars is because there are some things they put into the script that I'm expected to go along with. 
Murder is murder and should not be forgiven without punishment. It seems to be a lesson to send people today that if your murder is Justified then you should be allowed to go unpunished. Gene roddenberry's Vision was to promote Humanity not to make excuses for being inhumane.
Disappointing on too many levels.
It stared off great but got pretty weak in the end. I hear that Season 2 is much better so far. I'm going to check it out tonight.

This season does what Discovery does. It destroys everything you ever loved about Trek. It takes the extra step of destroying everything you loved about Picard. Discovery was the beginning, but this is the final strike in the death of Trek.

I can understand the Firefly comparisons and the different Star Trek approach, with it not having any active Star Fleet characters in its main cast. It's still much much much better then Discovery in every way. I can really appreciate an in universe show and this hits the mark perfectly.... We don't need another show that takes place on a ship, DS9 is one of the best, let's try something different but still Star fleet.
They made me hope that Star Trek Picard would be the return of good trek. Instead, it was some of the worst writing yet. The spirit of Star Trek is now with The Orville.

It had a plot that kept me engaged (see what I did there.) Fun for those that loved TNG, android Sci-Fi, and are familiar with the camp that Star Trek is known for. Patrick Steward is great per usual, and the rest of the cast delivers a good performance. Also, the technology looks great! Definitely recommend.
The return of utopian science fiction!

Picard is insulting and offensive. It completely misses the heart and soul of what Star-trek is: a better future, with a better humanity. Instead, Picard is a Weekend at Bernie's situation with the bloated corpse of Star-trek being turned into the dour, depressing, convoluted, shallow, nihilistic, ultraviolent programming that they think people will pay for. The show having a more than 50% audience score can only be explained by the notion that the positive reviews are paid off, or that rottentomatoes attracts an unusually high amount of the lowest percentile intelligence in the world.

This series suffers from the influences of "new Trek" with the excessive monologues and more focus on Star Wars-like space battles than plots, but the overall story is intriguing and the cast is excellent. Picard does a much better job at developing all of its main characters than Discovery ever has. It would be nice to see Picard back in Star Fleet and in charge of a super ship rather than raiding around on a small mercenary's ship, but we will see what the next season brings.
I didn't even finish the first episode. Bad bad bad writing and directing. Dear god. I was excited too. The Orville is more Star Trek than this is.

I do not understand the audience score for this, outstanding performance by Patrick Stewart. Production value is top notch brings. An interesting group of new characters to join Picard and familiar faces to get your nostalgia dose  very pleasing series

Garbage pandering that should have never been made. Every line is more stupid than the last and each one seemingy contradicts something else and makes the plot even more illogical. Literally no one in this show has any logical reason for any of their actions. It might be one of the dumbest shows I've ever seen. This is truly a disgrace to Star Trek and the legacy of Captain Picard. #NotMyCaptain

The cameos are a bit too nostalgic for my taste even though I love TNG but definitely a good story and great acting. I loved the Borg arc and seeing how that ended up as well as the Romulans. Feels a bit like FireFly. Solidly within the Star Trek universe and a great addition to the world building. Its not as casual as TNG. Picard has well built characters and backstories unlike the poor characters in the Discovery series. In Picard every character has a drive and purpose. Whether you love or hate them you can relate to them because they feel real.

Good story but ruined with constant dumb speeches that were intended to show us "the path we must follow in life".  Whenever one of those moments started (which was on a regular basis), I would either fast forward or check my phone until they passed.
I don't want to listen to constant lessons in what the writers feel is the way we should lead our lives, that was edging too much on woke principles.  If they would have left all of that out (which was completely unnecessary), it would have been far better and far more entertaining. 
Some of the new characters were very good, like Rafaella with her haphazard personality, Dahj who was just one of us with a difference, Elnor with his innocence and Captain Cristobal with his alter ego holograms was really entertaining.  Also something about Narek never made you hate him.  It was also amazing to see Jeri Ryan play Seven of Nine again, however her personality has changed by becoming more emotional in pursuit of justice, which went against the original character who was practically emotionless.
There were also some dumb moments in the plot, like to kill an android, you only have to stab it in the eye, a retired Picard thinking he could just waltz into The Federation and demand a ship and crew, and how bad security checks and vetting at The Federation are.  Unbelievable moments in the plot are expected, but sometimes they went a little too far.

Horrible writing clearly created by people that knew very little about Star Trek. The entire premise of the show makes for a bad story with terrible plot holes that are just ignored or hand waved away.
Badly written, unwatchable.

I'm surprised at the low score from the audience. I relished this show. I loved watching a senior citizen kick ass. Perhaps it's because I'm one as well—one who can kick ass. 
Also, I enjoyed seeing some of the cast from the earlier Picard series. You're not useless until you're dead. Even then you are part of memories. I love his having a purpose and boldly pursuing it where no septuagenerian has gone before.

Was the overall storyline a little heavy, a little too big? Yeah, definitely. But I still liked it! Picard stood for this convictions. In his old age he's come to recognize that the emotional distance he put between himself and others was only serving to hurt him and them, and I'm glad that he's progressed as a character in that front. The characters were all well developed - perhaps the weakest spots were how little time they had to explore Rios' relationship with Starfleet and the kind of handflipping they did with Agnes and how the vision affected her. There were definite flaws with the way the overarching story progressed but it is so hard to fault the show as being bad after we received an entirely fitting and long overdue proper sendoff for Data. I don't agree with all the directions they took Seven's character but having her back and growing as a person is wonderful anyway - and I'm going to admit that I personally loved the fact that they made her a canon queer.

This show is a tragic reminder that Star Trek is, in reality, over.  In the most general sense, it simply is not a universe anyone would want to live in.  Where it was once a gleaming picture of humanity overcoming its vast short coming with the passage of time, now it is a reflection of all that is wrong with mankind and human nature. Despite centuries of time and progress, we have learned nothing.  Ourselves, and even every alien race, are nothing more than war mongering, self interested, naïve beings for which the exploration of the greater universe has provided zero perspective.  Star Trek was about witnessing and striving for the progress and objectivity that could come from a newly enlightened human race, centuries in the future after correcting many of our flawed ideals. Sure there were still imperfections and selfish individuals, but in the case of Star Trek: Picard, humanity remains a mirror image of itself in 2020. Progressing only into space travelers, but not as a society for the better by even an inch.  What a tragic take that undermines everything Gene Roddenberry beautifully and creatively displayed in his vision of a better future for us all.

How dumb is the Script for Picard? A sky beam with a space octopus dumb.
How much of a waste of talent it is? I have seen Patrick Stewart play Bambi's father with more meaningful character development. Because the writers remembered the context of what Bambi's father had to deal with.
You gave Data a second death scene for THE WHOLE FRANCHISE.........and you left out Tasha Yar, Laul, Lore, and Dr Sung from his last moments of his life flashing before his eyes. Forget not being able to get the actors, Brent Spiner could have posed as B4, Lore, and Dr Sung straight away and the others could have been stand ins in the shadows or photoshop images on family photos.

But thinking of that lead me to realize the ROOT problem with Kurtzman's approach to trek: He must ONLY have watched the movies. Why else would the Borg be dismissible? Why else would NONE of Data's FAMILY be important in a DATA'S FAMILY story? Because they were not in those 4 movies? Why did Bruce Madox have to die? Because HE was not in Kurtzman's draft of the script for the ending, so writer's lower in rank than him had to put in REAL Trek Lore in the episodes Kurtzman did not have a strangle hold on. AND THAT IS A HEALTHY SIGN when I can attribute the good writing to stuff that must have been SNUCK in.

You could not call Lavar Burton to play Geordi? You know, DATA'S BEST FRIEND WHO WAS A SUPER SCIENTIST AND AN OFFICER ON THE ENTERPRISE? Could not call in Worf for the Romulan drama? You know, a member of the Enterprise and good friend of Picard that REALLY hates Romulans? Hell, would have made more sense to bring in some new actor as grown up Alexander son of Worf instead of............. Romulan Legolas................which makes about as much sense as Stalinist Merlin or Ronald Reagan's druid or a Mormon Ninja.

For fuck's sake. Star Trek is famous for a reason and not for Kurtzman's insights into it. But sure, he fails upwards. So we are stuck with him until he kills Trek like he killed Amazing Spiderman.

The special effects are good, but that's it. Totally unrecognizable as either Picard or Star Trek. Instead of smart people working together to solve complex problems through science, reason and moral ideals, it's individualistic fools experiencing trauma and sharing zero chemistry, stumbling through a convoluted story with more plot holes than planets. Constant swearing, scant humor, utterly joyless. Maybe three good scenes in 10 episodes. To be avoided by real Trekkies at all costs.

This is the modern Star Trek we deserve. Much better than ST:D. Overall this was a really good story and portrayal of the future of the Star Trek universe. The story is compelling and enjoyable. The characters are decently flushed out and likable (when they want you to like them). I think it is totally believable that the Federation has been infiltrated and not what it used to be.  There are some issues with it though. I felt that the Borg incident was anticlimactic and the final sequence with the Romulans had lots of little issues (overly dramatic half ROMULAN half VULCAN leader, the new Federation ships didn't look quite rite to me, the fact that the Romulans just changed their mind and left without a fight). That being said, ST:P season 1 is better than ST:TNG season 1 (we all know it was the worst season of all the "90s" Treks don't lie to yourself). So with that perspective I hope that this series continues to improve itself and become as good as DS9.

Fantastic. A deeply nostalgic experience as someone who grew up in the fold, particularly for fans of Next Generation. Characterisations etched as deep as the creases in Patrick Stewart's face performed by a cast of often lesser known but hugely talented individuals. Criticisms seem to be that it reflects real world politics and doesn't have big enough special effects. So, if you have a shortage of attention span and even shorter empathy then maybe skip this well realised, thoughtful and possibly grown-up experience. If however you love infinite diversity in infinite combinations then get ready for a 10 hour motion picture that absolutely suits an on-demand experience, get comfy with some snacks at the ready and prepare for a wonderful if sleepless night.

As a life long fan of the Star Trek Universe who has watched all of the series, movies, cartoons, read the books and even collected the comics, I was really looking forward to the Picard series. Patrick Stewart is an incredible actor that made The Next Generation the great series that it was. That's why I was so disappointed after watching Picard's first season.

This could have been such a great show. Many of the original cast members were back, the special effects were gorgeous, and the acting was quite good. But the world that Picard now lives in is so depressing and bleak. The premise is silly with Picard blamed for events that were clearly not his fault (the Romulans had their own massive fleet of ships yet they blamed Picard for not saving more of them). Then every female in the show berates him with such choice lines like accusing him of "sheer ******* hubris" and so forth; really the profanity was not needed. 

In the end Captain Jean-Luc Picard is reduced to a dottering old man who wanders through episodes with a confused look on his face while being berated by his Irish Romulan housekeepers, and every other female character in the show for that matter. At least if the reported paycheck of $750,000 per episode is true then I at least sort of understand why Stewart destroyed his legacy, but that doesn't mean I want to watch him do it. I'll pass on any additional seasons of Picard.

No, he is envolved in this cloak and dagger, spy story that boldly goes where we don't care to accompany it.  I watched two episodes and sent the DVD back.

Is it good? Is it bad? Noone knows, which also goes for the hole future portraied here. Starfleet command, once the pinnacle of what humankind ought to be, suddenly is a fractured, weird nothingness. Maybe this intends to reflect the present state, but Star Trek always was about ideals, what human society "could" be, strifes to be... not the greedy, ignorant version we experience now.
At least Pircard himself - graciously acted by P. Steward himself - holds up those ideals, which is what this series is about. And, in this theme, the series does a good job. Kind of. If it wasnt for the hasty character development, world building and plot development, which had me bloat out "What? Why? Seriously!?" a couple of times. Sure, the guy with a sword who sailed along in a spaceship for a while doing nothing, decides to stay on a hostile space station he knows nothing about, because... Why again? He got a sword. Thats sure gonna solve all issues. "What? Why? Seriously!?"
A couple of moment were so extraordinarily stupid, I struggled to take anything seriously afterwards.
Jumping over those hickups, the series has bright moments. Deep, philosophical questions and moral dilemmas, which we love Star Strek for. If only those were imbedded in more believable writing. So in the end, my rating is a "Meh, ok, What? Why? Seriously!?, alright, alright, 3 stars... maybe?"

TNG is one of my all-time favorite shows. I was excited for this series and profoundly disappointed by it. I can't even stand to watch it anymore. How about cancel this and Discovery, fire all the writers and producers, watch some TOS and TNG, then make a real Star Trek show.

So much better than I thought it would be, and my expectations were high. (NO spoilers follow)

I'll start with the people who won't like it:  it doesn't have a lot of "action", although there are some creative fight sequences, and there are not a lot of space battles either.

However, if your favorite Star Trek episodes are the ones that blend the hard science and action elements with the infinite complexity and intensity of human drama, and if you realize the greatest unknown to explore is the realm of emotion, memory and the experiences that make life most precious, then this will hit you in the gut in a powerful and unforgettable way.

The political intrigue and parallels to current world situations are very well done.  And there are constant references to and reminders of morsels of information from the rest of the Star Trek universe that dedicated and observant fans will notice with delight.

Last but not least, if you are already a fan of Patrick Stewart, and Jean-Luc Picard, the best Captain in Starfleet, it is criminal that you have not seen this already.  Clear a weekend for watching the first season as though it were a trilogy of feature-length movies.  Do it ASAP.

This series alone is worth the cost of a Paramount Plus subscription.

If you've ever wondered what a pathetic old Jean-Luc Picard would be like in the background, this series has you covered. The plot is painfully slow and revolves around blaming Picard for everything, even if it's not his fault. The rest of the plot is hard to describe: it's just there and happens? Like Star Trek: Discovery, this series presents a dark, non-optimistic version of Star Trek. Most of the characters are broken and hard to like, with the exception of Rios. The dialogues and character development are mediocre. This series negates any personal development that Picard and Seven of Nine have made in previous series. And there are other guest appearances (massacres?) from previous Star Trek series, some of them quite neat. Production-wise, the show is well done.

Just like how Star Trek Discovery awkwardly inserted its dull, preachy, soulless, and unlikable characters into the backstory of our beloved classic Star Trek legends of old - thus retroactively taking credit for everything that happened afterwards. Star Trek Picard sees fit to alter the fundamental nature of the Federation, Starfleet, and basically everything else in this world. It's turned Starfleet itself into a diverse hire paradise where every single senior officer is female. It takes established and beloved characters that we grew to know over the years or even decades and deconstructs them into obscene parodies of themselves. This show undermines the basic message of hope and optimism. Instead, it presents a bleak, hostile, greedy dystopian version of the Star Trek universe. It revels in gore, torture, violence and destruction, in a show that once had taken a higher path using rationality, understanding and diplomacy to solve problems. It does all of this, and for what, to tell a story that nobody wanted in the first place. To explore ideas that have already been handled by past better writers. To seamlessly forcing the creator's political views that none of us asked for or care about. Or was it just to squeeze the last remnants of fun enthusiasm from a franchise that pretty much has been run to the ground by people who don't know what the hell they're doing.
Star Trek Picard is just another sad example of what happens when arrogant, talentless, shameless hacks try to elevate their own mediocre work by standing on the shoulders of giants.

Pretty uneven series. *spoilers* The Good: Patrick Stewart, the Borg reclamation project story, all the TNG cast appearances.  The Bad: There are a lot of overused Sci-fi plots here. Flesh and blood androids, fear that AI will take over the universe, Android bans, Patrick Stewart's brain being transferred to another body (they really took an idea from X-Men 3?) Plus, the new crew just isn't that interesting.  The holograms provide great comic relief though.

Why wouldn't Picard have grown old and been marginalised by Starfleet?? The show is criticised for being too Marvel but at the same time some viewers want enduring super hero JLP. The show is a slow burner and it is season 1, it is also addictive and a great watch , so it has a seasonal arc, so what? Some audiences in particular are known for not handling long arcs and slower paced sci fi, look at the Stargate Universe dismissal or the end of Bablyon 5 for example. I am sorry but this IS Star Trek, the Picard character is totally believable, unless he was meant to be Captain America.... and the supporting cast generally work, although the jury is still out on the sword..... p.s. just this morning i was watching an interview with Leonard Nimoy in which he discussed the quality of scripts in Star Trek..hmmmm

Superb! Haven't seen a disruptor in action in ages. Nasty weapon. Loved the legacy of Data story line. Loved seeing old friends in their new lives.

It has some major continuity errors with TNG, notably Picard being BFF with Data.
The story is ... OK if you do not think about it too much. The amout of characters from previous series is quite high. Character interactions are on level of amateur theatre, they feel fake.

For both "Picard" seasons, I loved Patrick Stewart's ability to bring the aging Picard to the screen again. I loved the scenes at his chateau in Future France. The archeology scenes in the ancient Borg Cube were amazing. I loved the young actors selected to tell the stories of the artificial life forms--and I really like those story lines.  I really liked all of the characters in this story--7 of 9 was expertly played and and even bigger badass than ever.  I loved Riker & Troi in their rural homestead. All of these things makes the series a must see for me.


Possible Spoiler Alert...


I do feel like the Picard creators chose to weaken the Future Star Trek mythology as a means to draw in a new fan base and it didn't feel like an organic progression after "Nemesis" or the JJ Abrams's "Into Darkness". 

The "Picard" storyline which drives the first two seasons is clever and interesting, but short sells the ideals and beliefs that Star Fleet and the Federation were imagined to defend. 

It'll be interesting to see how consistent the new Star Trek Picard and Discovery universes can remain or if the writers/creators will use some kind of time warp cataclysm to cause the social breakdown along selected timelines. 

Lastly, I wish the Borg had not been reduced to tragic figures. I hope the Picard writers choose to develop the Borg story line more fully--Beyond Hugh's independence, how did the entire hive collapse? Every system has "anti-bodies" which would continue to embrace Borg beliefs (at least for a time) we know human will and "desire for freedom" isn't consistent across all beings. Where are the other Borg cubes?  How did the Borg begin?
An insult to Star Trek.

Star Trek The Next Generation holds a dear place in my heart as far as TV show's go.  I was so excited when I heard Picard was coming out and looking forward to how they could portray an older Picard.  After several attempts I just can't get through the entire series.  I find the new characters mostly uninteresting with a story that just doesn't grip me at all.  Too many characters are reluctant hero model which feels beaten to death in this day and age.  It feels like the writers don't understand what made TNG so special to a lot of people and are relying on the nostalgia of the characters to drive the show.
Awful.. really rotten story, was great to see some of my beloved characters. shame they made such a mess of what could have been a really good show..what a missed opportunity!

Who is this Picard? A shell of the Picard from ST:TNG. If you're ok with taking names & faces from TNG and dropping them in modern day so called sensibilities.. you might like this.  
Seeing familiar faces was the only reason I watched the entire season.
I don't get how this is a good vision of the Trek future...
A slap in the face of Star Trek fans.  Random pandering moments by beloved characters cannot change the fact that this show unapologetically craps on everything fans love about the franchise.

This is not Star Trek and that is NOT Picard's character. Every piece of Trek post the 2009 Star Trek movie is completely out of sync with the spirit of Star Trek, and this show personifies the worst pieces of this. So many characters and motivations are prone to aggressiveness and violence. The influence of Marvel movies has had a negative impact on so many franchises, Star Wars and Star Trek in particular. Everyone knows some martial art and all guns blazing, with characters that really have no real depth. Also, this series has a SKY BEAM, a giant sky beam! How original.  Poorly written, not Star Trek. Alas. True Trek is gone. I'm glad we have so many of the older series to enjoy though.

It's Picard. You must at least give it a go and see how it goes. 
I was very much looking forward to this early in 2020 and the final result was.. mixed. 
Started off pretty strong. Certainly felt different in vibe compared with what I remember of the TNG universe we left in 2002's Nemesis.. but inuniverse (as in real time) 2 decades have passed and the world (galaxy) has changed as it constantly will. It does seem far darker than the more happy universe of 2360s that's for sure! Kind of feels similar in how the 1990s now seem so lovey-dovey compared with the relative depressive times we now inhabit in 2020 so the show seems at least relevant in that context, in how its really relating to our current climate. 

The show itself is rocky in quality. I honestly can't pick out any highlight, though I felt overall the strongest episode was the one we catch up with the Rikers on their planet that they now live. 
The new characters in the show are OK, but perhaps being this is the first season the acting is hit and miss. Stewart for the most part is excellent in his role but expect him to be a bit slower and bit more 'elderly'. This is not the Hot Picard action hero of Nemesis and the TNG films in general. He's more on the sidelines in terms of the action overall.

Season 2 is coming and I'm thinking this show will hopefully build on a relatively solid but sometimes weak S1 and develop really strong. This is certainly better than the X Files Reboot a few years ago. This show doesn't try to redo TNG the series at all and that's why this show has a chance of pushing on and getting better!

It started good I didn't think much for the first few episodes, then it got progressively worse and traumatically bad. The series try's to milk the feels by playing legacy tracks from TNG, but then hits you with absurd new trek random ass pulls.  Patrick Stewart didnt need this, even though he surly thinks this is a masterpiece of art and entertainment. It only trainwrecks his legacy as one of the more admirable star trek captains.  Anyway hes just there to put the spotlight on the new gen of characters that are very unlikable, other than the crazy ship captain. 
The last ep is a cringefest and like it or not you must see it to believe whats called Star Trek these days.

So I just finished binging all three seasons of Star Trek Discovery and the one season of Picard. Discovery feels like it was made for teenagers and millenials, a soap opera with no depth and way too much crying. Picard series feels like it was made for adults, and more a long the line of the Next Generation series obviously. The plot was very predictable without any twists, but seeing Picard, Riker, and Troy all on the screen at the same time again was a joy to see, they have great chemistry as always. The Picard series had excellent CGI and everything from the planets to the old Borg cube looked good. I found myself rarely rolling my eyes watching Picard, unlike Discovery where my eyeballs hurt from my eyes rolling all the way back into my brain. I hope there is a season 2.
It keeps you on the edge of your seat.

This was far better than I expected.  It is different than a traditional Star Trek series.  But, there is excellent storytelling and the guest stars from Picard's past do not seem unnecessarily contrived- like an episode of the Love Boat as many walk-ons to SNG seemed to be.  I cant understand why viewer ratings are as low as they are - this was excellent television.

Not sure why this has a low audience score, the story is very good, and flows through the series very well. There's a good balance between new characters and returning ones, as well as good balance between character developmental action. A great series in my opinion.

An very interesting storyline is not helped by uncertain direction. The need to build a new star trek universe and tie a diverse group together hinder the narrative but having assembled the crew I'm hoping for better next time round!

This is so painful.  I LOVE TNG and I love Captain Picard.  But this universe is so different, so depressed and hopeless, that it's like they picked up the character and put him in a completely different universe.  If I wanted to see my favorite, hopeful and endearing characters either killed off or disillusioned and dark, I'd watch The Last Jedi again!  This show needs to be cancelled so they can start over by looking back.
From some of finest in Starfleet a real cool new show with a few new characters brought to their best. Amazing so far. Lots of cool from Data in the show too.
Absolutely terrible. This was a travesty, not Star Trek at all. Best not to watch it as it completely ruins the character of Picard. Extreme violence, brutality, and swearing every other word.

There is one scene where Picard and company are at a simple dinner table on a set that isn't full of holograms, flashing lights and lens glare. In the scene, a problem is clearly stated and each person at the table gives their input into how to solve it and Picard uses this input to come to a final decision. Needless to say, it was the best scene in the entire season (the last couple episodes are very good too). 

I miss characters discussing their issues and coming up with practical solutions. I want a group of unique people working together solving problems, not secretly working against each other for the sake of plot. I don't like snuff, and the last place I expected to see it was in this show, but it is there. 

All said and done, Jeri Ryan's return managed to keep me on board for the lousy first half of the series. The prospect of Seven and Picard working together in a series is very appealing to me. While the show did have a satisfying last couple of episodes, it's held back by its desire to be like other modern shows - characters making stupid decisions or keeping secrets for the sake of plot, pointless action with nameless grunts dying en mass, a couple snuff scenes, and an elongated plot that didn't need to be more than a couple episodes stretched out into 10 because nobody knows how to write a tv series anymore and they all want to make extra long movies.

Terrific. There are so many beautiful threads picked up from the previous series and movies relevant to Jean Luc Picard.  I am deeply impressed with the story and writing.  This is so much better than the nightmare that is Star Trek Discovery AKA STD. 

What I've recognized from the canon that has been woven beautifully here:

Picard's brain lesions that Beverly Crusher diagnosed long ago.
Hugh, the young Borg in TNG, is back as a recovered Borg. 
A Borg cube "artifact" as research site. Was this artifact a result of Janeways Borg Computer virus destruction in the finale of Voyager?
Romulan synthetic life xenophobia goes right along with Romulan canon
Various Romulan secret societies  - yes, that jives and I love it. And I love learning more about Romulans.
Picard having difficult relationships, such as with the new character Raffi.  Consider his bracing engagements with Commander Cisco in beginning of Deep Space Nine.  Jean Luc is not always a warm and fuzzy guy.  This relationship jives with his character.  Patrick Stewart is brilliant. 
Picard struggling with the loss of Data and the ban on synthetic beings.  Yes!  Data sacrificed himself in Star Trek Nemesis to save Picard and everyone.  Of course Picard would be burdened by this. 
Bruce Mattox as contributing creator of new synths.  This totally jives.  Bruce was the person in TNG that wanted to study Data, and Picard had to prove that Data was sentient and had a right to determine his own fate. Picard stuck his neck out for Data.  Mattox was disappointed.  Of course, Mattox would have found ways to continue his research. (Too bad, they did get the same actor to play Mattox in Picard.)
Seven of Nine as a sort of Marshall in the lawless regions.  Why not?  Potentially bisexual?  Why not?  Devastated that Echeb, one of the young Borg that she helped to rehabilitate in Voyager, is murdered?  Of course!  He was basically her son.  Of course she would be crazy mad. Bringing Seven into Picard's sphere?  Terrific.  Wonderful way to tie together the lives of our favorite Star Trek characters.
Picard turning to old friends for help?  Of course. 

I think this show is great.  It shows that the Federation is not infallible.  It presents the destructive force of xenophobia, but also shows why xenophobia can develop, which is relevant to our time in 2020.  STP, like the other series, explores that there are likely malevolent and hostile forces in the universe. It also has great character developments.  

There are many new elements to enjoy, and numerous nods to the Star Trek universe throughout the series. STP is spot on.  I love it.  WATCH IT multiple times.  You will love it too.

The theme and intro are also beautiful.
Boring and formalic dreck. Patrick can't save writing this bad.

Not Star Trek. Gene Roddenberry must be rolling over in his grave. The producers should all be fired for what they've done to the greatest franchise to ever exist. Star Trek and the Federation is supposed to represent humanity at its finest. I couldn't even make it wall the way through the pilot before I had to turn it off. I've watched every episode from TOS, TNG, DS9, & VOY at least half a dozen times (probably have watched entirety of VOY more than a dozen times over). This is simply not Star Trek. 

It would have made for a descent sci-fi show had it not been labeled Star Trek. I probably even would have enjoyed it although the writing would still leave something to be desired.
I thought this was a great story with convincing acting.  It engaged me throughout.
That third episode really hit All the Feels. And it continued until the end. It is what Trek should be.

I've never seen such an incoherent mess that takes a huge, steaming dump on it's heritage while still having plot point that directly contradict each other at opposite ends of the season, while having other plot points that go nowhere, while having characters that are about as deep as puddle after a summer storm.....Oh wait, yes I have.  Its called Star Trek: Discovery.  
Anything with Alex Kurtzman's fingerprints on it consistently follow this behavior.  Both in and outside Trek.  (See The Mummy as an example.)  I expected this from the minute Picard was announced as I knew The Kurtzman Effect would be in play.  And dang if I wasn't 100% right.  Do not bother with this turd.  Fan made shows are better than this.

Really REALLY wanted to like it because I love Star Trek, but like Discovery this is yet another series polluted with over-the-top forced down your throat social justice.

This is nothing like TNG, and you'll be very disappointed if you go into it hoping that.

I know I was disappointed!
Garbage. Starfleet, Picard, and Trek are unrecognizable. Pure dumb, mindless action schlock. Gene Roddenberry's vision of Trek is dead.
We expected more for this show it is good to see beloved characters one again but style of this show and story is just awful
I so wanted it to be good, but it's just more Kurtzman and Co. rubbish.
Its not the usual star trek set up and that makes it so compelling.  Patrick Stewart is so great, you can't help but want to see where he goes next. Im grateful to be along for the ride!

Awesome great to see some of the old characters return, with some great new characters. Also thought it was a great plot, staying true to subjects of past star trek episodes and movies. Definetly recommend to any Star Trek fan and and sci-fi fan in general would enjoy this show.

Jean Luc Picard, the philosopher one of the  greatest fictional leaders to ever grace sci-fi TV. Captain Kirk advised him to not let them promote him to admiral and here you get to see the story unfold of a retired captain and his continuing journey to bodily go where no man has before. There's a great essence of time and life and the closure between commander data and captain Picard, is what I mostly tried to focus on albeit this series has some loopholes it does hit your heartstrings especially in the final episode. 

"Someone once told me that time was a predator that stalked us all our lives. I rather believe that time is a companion who goes with us on the journey and reminds us to cherish every moment, because it will never come again. What we leave behind is not as important as how we've lived. After all Number One, we're only mortal.
Jean-Luc Picard
Amazing series. If you loved TNG, you will love this show. Visit old friends and make many new ones. Smart and exciting. Must see!

The story is so bad :-(
I'm sad because I used to love Picard in TNG.
I save just the episode "Nepenthe" because was pure fan service.

As a generic Sci-Fi flick it would have been alright, but this is neither "ST The Next Generation" nor "ST Voyager". This is not even properly Star Trek: the episodic format has been thrown out of the window for a contrived and internally inconsistent season long overarching story, in my opinion to it's detriment. 

This gets further compounded with several in-universe retcons of factions/characters that are in stark contrast to previous portrayals of these characters: Picard, Seven of Nine, Deanna Troi, Data, Icheb, Riker and the MO of the Federation and the Romulans. 

Verdict: Bloody awful Star Trek with mistreatment of established characters and lore. An overall mess of a series.

there is never going to be something like tng again, the concept isn't "profitable" enough for hollywood. 
don't even bother
This show is so bad that I not only hate star trek now but it made me question what was the point of getting attached to fictional properties... there is no point.
Great ending! I look forward to season 2!
I was expecting more than a bit more action
I was so looking forward to watching "Picard", alas it was a disappointment. Given the caliber of the main character the story just drifts along. I couldn't finished the series.
Started well and ended well, the middle was a bit meh though, very slow in places. It's set up some really interesting things to continue next season.

Certainly a show with plenty of writing issues, but I mean hey some great acting (Stewart, Pill, Hurd, Cabrera), the return of Seven of Nine, solid directing, and FINALLY a nice death for Data.  And I mean hell, the only Star Trek show that ever had a really good first season was TOS.

The first season was the most useless collection of clichés I've ever seen.  the plot does not feel fan.  Was Picard brought back from his beautiful winery, only to be forced to kneel and apologize for existing?  This does not make any sense.  To make matters worse, the collection of characters without charisma and ridiculous situations seems to have no end (a terrorist attack at Starfleet headquarters is not even investigated!) The series is a slap in the face for fans and an offense to The Next Generation's legacy.  I can only conclude that it is just a gigantic money laundering operation.  "Sheer f * Hubris!"
Star trek with Picard again! Even better although it needs some improvements. Great to see more and more old characters. Looking forward to see more.
A lot of inconsistencies with Picard's character in previous Trek. Excited to watch this series, was pretty disappointed with end product.
It took everything we loved about Star Trek's greatest captain and flushed it away. The end of the season was an insult to the character of Picard and the fans.

I accept that this was not intended to be a Star Trek film, but in building on the past series, as this does, it is reasonable to expect some conformity.  This is a pure vanity series by and for Stewart.  I tried to forget his peurile rants at the recent election in the UK, but you can see the same elements in this that he has created for himself.  Impulsive, angry, ego-centred, arrogant and old - not qualities that were present in the Enterprise captain at all.  The violence, terrible script and plot writing and poor acting just made for painful viewing.  I really wanted to like it but after the first couple the plots it became slow and predictable.  Stewart should just retire to an actual vineyard and fade into obscurity for the sake of entertainment.

Where Next Gen was born from Roddenberry's optimism and hope, Picard is nothing more than expression of Patrick Stewart's personal fear and disillusionment. Where Roddenberry engaged in unbiased examination of social issues, Stewart came to the table with a specific agenda.
If you loved the next generation please don't watch this.

Great production value, horrible writing though. Visually great with excellent effects. The writing is pure awful. Ham-fisted morality pounded into the viewer with a sledgehammer. No subtlety or finesse at all. Picard spends most of his time carelessly endangering all around him in pursuit of enforcing his concepts of right and wrong on anyone who comes within earshot. He never has the complete picture of what's going on, but that doesn't stop him from being hyper-sanctimonious at every opportunity. It's really pure luck that anyone who he suckers into his sphere of influence manages to survive at all because he does nothing but use them and then leave them to their own devices as he blindly pursues his vision of right and wrong. Everyone becomes blindly loyal and trusting of him for no apparent reason. Characters are left to their own devices and usually in dire peril as soon as he feels he needs to be elsewhere. Plot holes abound and incomprehensible character decisions are lightly filled in with just a few seconds of backfill or contrived justification. Just an unfulfilling shell of a show.

Had such high hopes that this show would recapture the feel and spirit of Star Trek, but I didn't sign up to see Picard being screamed at repeatedly by some of the worst new characters to grace the small screen. And I certainly don't like that returning characters feel like strangers. Did the writers even watch old Star Trek episodes?!?
Star trek at last! Needs some fine tuning but I had great fun.

When I try a new food, I decide whether or not I like it.

If I order a pepperoni pizza, and the when the pizza man arrives it's an olives and cheese pizza, I'm not happy with that pizza. If the pizza man then tries to explain to me that he loves olives and cheese on pizza, and I should try it, I likely will feel very miffed about it. If I then call the pizza place and tell them they got my order wrong, and they tell me that I just don't understand pizza, and I should love the pizza they sent me, I'm going to be very pissed off at that pizza place, demand my money back, and never order from them again.

Star Trek was a brand. When I sat down to watch a Star Trek show, I was expecting a specific type of show. I wasn't looking for a gritty SciFi show, or whatever Picard was. I was looking for the comfort food of shows, and I got something different than I was told by the Star Trek logo I would get.

Some people may love olives and cheese pizzas. Some people might love anchovies on their pizza. That's why pizza places keep those toppings on hand, but you're not going to convince people who don't like olives to eat an olive and cheese pizza just because you call it a pepperoni pizza. You also can't leave cheese off, or the sauce off, or send it without a crust to sit on top of, and call it a pizza. You can't send me spaghettis and call it a pizza, they're similar but not the same.

Stop trying to "gain more audience" by changing the ingredients of Franchises. You can't add olives to a pepperoni pizza and expect someone who hates olives to be happy with that either, and you can't throw pepperoni onto an olive pizza and expect people who don't like pepperoni to enjoy eating that. All you're going to do is make the people who dislike olives and the people who dislike pepperoni, dislike your pizza. You're not going to win them both over by mixing the two.

There's an old saying, "You can't please everyone all the time..." STOP TRYING TO PLEASE NON-STAR TREK FANS BY MESSING UP STAR TREK!
So much better than I anticipated.  I love the rag tag broken crew.  I was worried it would be cheesy with some of the old characters but it was great. I look forward to season 2.

I wanted to like this.  And if this were a show starting from scratch, it could have worked.  

But it really had no business being called Star Trek.  The Orville is far more trek than this.  Picard is simply a different character.  

The new creators are attempting to broaden star trek and bring it to game of thrones audience.  I get that, it's lucrative.  

But when you get rid of golden age sci fi outlook, you remove the heart of star trek.  When characters are archetypes and the galaxy itself is tiny, it's not sci fi.

The return of Jean-Luc Picard was long awaited and although we find him in a new phase of his life, he is still the same man that we know and love. This show is a slow burner, but as the series progresses it lives up to most of our expectations. Like Discovery season one, Picard's first season has lots of potential and some missed opportunities that I am sure will be rectified as the show progresses. It is not TNG by any means, but TNG is not forgotten. Well worth a watch (best to binge it in a couple of sessions for full effect).
Tragic to see a beloved character reduced to a tag-along character in his own series. If you enjoyed TNG, give this one a miss.

A muddled mess of terrible revisioning of what used to be, in a previous generation, a great tv series. Poorly written, as if it's set in present day, not in the distant future. Picard went from being a positive, respected leader as captain in the original series, to a bumbling, unsure, castigated old man in this drivel that bears his name. To think that I subscribed to all access to watch this garbage. Fool me once...

There are a lot of big ideas that could have been really really cool if they had been explored with any depth. There are elements that definitely work. But there's also a lot that doesn't work. I think I'm more inclined to be negative because of the potential that existed here, but if you've watched the first season of any Star Trek show, you'll know that they can take time to find their footing. There's enough here that I'll be watching season 2, but its hard to speak of it favourably given how much it failed to fulfill the considerable potential.

I actually agree with the critics. Beautifully done show right done to the opening music. Everything you always got out of the next generation. Never really exciting to the new movies level but it holds the audience. From the first show to the last I was not disappointed.

The series offers an Initially interesting and big plot, but the development of it is really bland mostly because the new characters are terrible ad also because the show doesnt feel like the future of StarTrek TNG, characters smoking, Starfleet is corrupted, people dress like us, conversations are simple and too much of contemporanean, 7 of 9 goes down from being a uber intelligent ex-borg to become a "cowboy/girl". Too, talkings about peace and acceptance but many episodes are full of unnecessary violent solutions and action scenes. The production throw us to the face the most uninspired ship designs of the whole saga, that in the season finale offer a CG confrontation without any sense more than show the biggest number of these uninspired  (and by the way small as cars) ship designs. 

For more than I LOVE to see again face to face Picard, DATA, Riker, Troy, Hugh, etc. with the exception of what they had done with 7 of 9. I cannot stand the most part of the new characters/actors with special focus in Rios or Raffi, non mention about their smoking and drinking habits that may Gene Rodenberry ideas about the future have a facepalm in the afterlife. 

Is a mess, tastes much less StarTrek than Discovery, something I wasn't expecting at all, and I just hope this season suffers of bad scripts and confused new actors as the 1st season of TNG. 

Is a mediocre season, with some teally charming moments in the hands of the classics, with some new cool bad guys, but with a big bunch of new good guys that have zero chemistry with the classic actors or even between them.

The beginning is interesting, the end is bland and tries to drink on nostalgia and Brent Spinner to solve the big problems of this new series that doesn't seem to know what it really wants to show us.

I was happy to see new Trek coming available, but this show was made for Game of Thrones fans. There are multiple suggestive incest scenes and of course, the F word. They killed off one of the most popular Trek characters, the highly intelligent and perceptive Seven of Nine, and replaced her with a video game first person super hero shooter version.
