The original Seven of Nine character was a positive female role model. She was willing to reach, trying to overcome and gain inner control after a traumatic past. This character is just nasty and an insult to women--a misguided response to trauma. Then they kill off three more popular characters.  I like seeing Picard again, but the rest is dark and dreary, and imitates all the other dark movies and shows.  The wrong people are leading this show.

So much violence and melodrama. It's so depressing and is the complete opposite to what Star Trek is which is a hopeful adventure sci-fi series showing what we as humans could become and overcome. There was also a massive disregard for the story. So many things contradicted the story from TNG,DS9,VOY. There were also a pile of things that didn't make sense that feels like it was pulled out of a generic action scifi film where you weren't supposed to thing... "Galactic Treaty" hah.

One and a half stars for what could have been. "Picard" is just there trying to monetise on hard-core fans. Lots of fan-service bits (that rarely have any relevance to the main plot), also lots of disappointment; almost every previously known character seems out of place and out of character. Picard is an irrelevant man that gets spoken down to every chance the writers get. The plot is full of gaping holes that anyone who's ever watched a couple of Star Trek movies or a dozen episodes (of any past series) would detect in an instant.
The creators of this show just didn't give a damn; it's like they created "Picard" after watching a few episodes of TNG without paying too much attention.
In conclusion, a huge let-down. Even the final episode is the monumental disrespect to the character whose name it bears. Spoiler alert: Picard is now a robot!
Don't bother. Just… don't.

I don't get all the audience reviewer hate. I absolutely loved this. It started a little slowly, but once it got going, I became highly invested. The characters were well sketched. Excellent dialog, thought provoking science and philosophy. She'd Patrick Stewart evokes even more feels and pathos in his frailness. Elnor was very touching, Dr Jurati so well acted, Raffi, the rest. And it was awesome to see Ryker, Troi, and Data again. Not to mention Brent Spiner playing a human! Loved it, can't wait to watch season 2!

It's hurtful to watch this series while the showrunners slowly destroy the hopeful optimism of Gene Roddenberry's vision for the future, while desecrating beloved characters of my youth. CBS has much to answer for from die hard fans.

What a wonderful job of completely ignoring everything that has happened in all of Star Trek. I went into this hoping it would be good. I wasn't expecting amazing or extraordinary, just some fun.  I was expecting him to be retired. I wasn't expecting to see people write a story that completely ignores all of Next Generation, with the exception of the hour where Picard was a borg, and then turn Picard into space Jesus. Why and who enjoys this? I love Patrick Stewart. I love Picard in TNG. I love Star Trek. I hated this more than anything. This entire series was just Mass Effect mixed with Matrix and just completely void of anything that could even arguably make this a Star Trek series.

Do not expect to see the traditional Star Trek TNG as so many expected.
It's dark, it's pretty slow moving, but at the same time has a sense of mystery and a side of the Federation that we have not seen before.
It feels like a mature series that has clearly evolved from its origins, yet keeping the grand sense of Star Trek.
Patrick Stewart delivers a robust performance and has in my opinion not faded into the distance.

Absolutely terrible.

It completely retcons everything that happened before in The Next Generation. Picard is so old and doddery with no respect, getting shouted at by everyone. Theres nothing redeemable about any of the other characters either. They just kill off or give original characters complete personality changes.

Nobody wants to live in that universe anymore. Its all bleak and depressing. Makes absolutely no sense. Gene Roddenberry would be so disappointed.

Patrick Stewart and all the writers and producers should be ashamed of this complete and utter dumpster fire.
Star Trek died with Enterprise. Bless Sir Patrick Stewart but the writing is utter garbage.

I adored TNG growing up, but if I had any criticisms of the series it was that some of the effects did not age well, and the sheer number of episodic storylines over 7 seasons made regular viewing a slog at some points. How happy I was then to see Jean-Luc Picard back in action for this show, with Patrick Stewart's brilliant acting combined with up-to-date visual effects and a proper story arc. Cameos from other TNG-era characters was also great to see, and I look forward to seeing more in future seasons. After an 18-year break from the character, Stewart does play Picard slightly differently, with more of himself visible, and although not necessarily a good or bad thing it is noticeable. It's a strong start for the show, and I can't wait to see where it takes us next.

If you ever watched Star Trek and thought "okay but what if the federation was racist?" this is the show for you.  There are a million forgettable dark dystopian sci fi action thrillers but star trek stood out bc it's not any of that.  It was people sitting around a board room trying to figure out how to solve something scientifically complex without violence while staying true to their morals.  

It would be more forgivable if it were a good action thriller but it isn't that either.  It's mostly just a pile of bad writing and weird unsatisfying violence.  Even the first scene doesn't make sense.  If you were trying to kidnap a very dangerous person, why would you beam a few people into their apartment to lose a fight when you could just beam the person you want to kidnap out of their house?   The answer is that the producers wanted to start the show with a jason borne style fight and didn't want to get bogged down in the details of why that doesn't work in the context of this world building. 

The original sin of this series is that it tried to make show that was tightly linked to Star Trek Nemesis, which is by far the worst and least popular movie.  

The thing about Star Trek is that the utopia isn't a gag. There's no "gotcha! They're eating people!" or some other Aldous Huxley reveal about how utopia comes at great cost.  Star Trek argues that a better world IS possible.  Ppl need to understand that before getting involved with the franchise.

Prior to watching this series, I haven't watched anything Star Trek since Voyager, and that I didn't even finish, though I did watch the finale for closure. This show, however, truly captured my imagination again, and I feel as excited as I did so long ago watching a Star Trek series. True, it veers from the familiar ground I'm used to, but you just feel like you're looking in on old friends and what actually happened to them. And I will be sticking with this series to it's end. (And yes, watching officers drop f-bombs doesn't work for me either, as for others who have already commented...but that doesn't make it a bad series, or "not Star Trek"...Star Trek has simply grown up.)
I don´t know what it is, but it is NOT Star Trek and definitely not good either. Go and rewatch DS9 if you want to see something good.
Just horrible. So disgraceful to Picard, horrible story, horrible acting. The sheer f'in hubris to call this Star Trek.

Picard lacks what all the Star Trek series of late lack, that is humor. This vision of dystopic space leaves one wanting. Spock and Bones bickering, Data trying to become human, Katherine Janeway as the Queen of the Spider-People, Ben Sisko baseball feud with Vulcans, all of these examples showed a very human side of Star Trek, none of these people were one-dimensional heroes self-absorbed by the disaster of the moment. Unfortunately, today's writers seem to find nothing humorous in like and we are with little or no hope as opposed as the original series that thrived on the notion of hope for the future.

If you're a fan of TNG, then Picard is FOR YOU! If you've never seen Star Trek, you might get a little lost at first until you catch up. Won't lie; the season starts off a little dark. Starfleet has failed to live up to the ideal and Picard is older now, and has made mistakes. But in true Star Trek fashion, the good guys win, and Roddenberry's vision of a future lives on.

I wanted to like it, I really did. But the murder, the sex, the murder, the drug use, the cursing, did I mention murder? Really turned me off.

I want Star Trek to go back to the stories that were inspiring, hopeful, dramatic. This new Trek leaves much to be desired.

There's enough nostalgia to entertain old TNG fans, while still adding elements to make the show its own.  The brilliant performances of Patrick Stewart and Brent Spiner can only cover up so much, though.  There is some awful writing at times.

That... hurt me. More than I expected. It's vulgar. That's the word that comes to mind after some detailed thought. That's the issue with new Trek. It's vulgar. There's none of the heart that the original Trek had, and even bringing in Sir Patrick isn't changing the trend of empty action sequences and CGI light shows instead of interesting science fiction and moral conundrums that were the beating pulse of Star Trek. The tarnishing of Gene's bright vision of humanity's future didn't help either. We really could use the old Star Trek's guiding light forward towards something more these days. 

I suppose you could say the show subverted my expectations. I expected it to be good.

It is hard to watch this show after watching an episode of TNG. If you are a fan of any of the shows from the 20th century, you may not like this show. Picard has changed, which time does, but changed to be such a basic character that makes the show frustrating to watch. It is also unfortunate that the show changes a lot of the lore present in TNG, Deep Space 9 and Voyager and instead goes more with the lore from JJ Abrams Trek.

This is not star trek.  Sorry you cannot use a few well know actors and totally change the characters to the point you don't recognize them in a boring, dark, depressing, story and call this trek.  I only hung on for the whole season because I kept hoping it would get better.  The thing is all I could say was wow what a waste of time.  I'm done with cbs version of trek.  I cancelled my subscription.

Dreadful. C'mon, what have you done with the real Captain Picard? This just isn't Star Trek.  Dark violent dystopian world with elves from Lord of the Rings. I think it's Legolas's older brother. Who needs a ray gun when you have a sword. All the characters are drowning their sorrows in this one. Quite literally. Dreadful just dreadful.

Poor Gene Roddenberry's name & legacy being associated with this rubbish. 
Patrick Stewart had a lot of say about the writing of this show, wouldn't agree to make it unless he did. Well, actors don't make good writers and it shows. I actually thought Patrick Stewart was intelligent, not anymore. It just goes to show, how wonderful the writing was on ST TNG, it made him look good. My heart goes out to Gene, I can only image what he'd think if he were around to see this rubbish. I have missed him greatly since his passing, but not at this moment, I'm glad he's not around to see this abomination. Anything of ST made after Voyager/Enterprise, is not worth your time watching, sadly. RIP Gene, loved your work! I'd give this a zero if I could.
A lot of wasted potential.  The show has too many logic gaps, poorly and under written characters with a story-line that made little sense.

My moral compass and traditional liberal outlook was effectively molded by TNG, DS9 and VOY era Trek.... It was a universe of optimism and hope, even in the darker moments. Picard has none of this... It's clumsy, nialistic, bleak, bitter, immature and worst of all... BORING AF
Grim and deeply depressing, this show destroys the legacy of The Next Generation along with any credibility Patrick Stewart had left. What a waste.

This is not a "reboot" - it's the continuing powerful story of one of the greatest ever TV characters written with such depth, gravitas, reverence and dramatic tension no less than Captain Picard deserves.

Really disappointing lots of  plot points that made no sense, like bringing back bruce Maddox over 3-4 episodes only to find out he's not being played by the same guy, 
and then kill him in the same episode where you found him - then his killer doesn't even stand trial - then there's Picard who doesn't actually do anything, except dodder around until the final Episode then he dies only to be resurrected exactly the same as he was.  Just horrible....
It's a wonderful slow burn, with old characters that we love and new ones that we come to love.
An insult to the legacy of Next Generation and the character of Jean-Luc Picard. Unforgivable trash.
People used to watch Star Trek because it was smart, thoughtful and engaging. These new Trek shows aren't Trek.

Lol! Some Star Trek fans can be pretty intense. Read the reviews for a good laugh. It's fine if you don't enjoy something, but some Star Trek fans act like anything that isn't exactly the same as TNG is very offensive to them. Anyhoo, I love TNG myself, and this series grabbed my interest from the beginning to the end. Very enjoyable watch.

The Good.

Excellent computer graphics, special and practical effects.  Good set design.  Decent acting.

The Bad.

The end is entirely predictable.  The plot, getting to the end, is a mess.

The Ugly.

They completely changed the personalities of Picard, 7 of 9, and others.
Pretty good! It follows the spirit of the TNG and continues the story after the last movie in a very enganging way.

This isn't Star Trek, but a space opera they put the drama on extra thick.  While Picard not being the same is explained, 7of 9 getting a whole new personality is not.  Let's bring back all the favorite TNG characters, change their personalities so it's not the same (same show), and people will love it.....right t

SPOILERS

Picard is, unfortunately, an incomprehensible mess of themes and story. It's message about artificial life is so confusing and mismanaged that the audience will wonder what the point was at the end. And it's handling of the world and characters it inherits is intent on breaking audiences expectations of Trek without earning any of it's choices. Episodes are long and full of wasted time and energy. Scenes feel like they serve no real purpose other than to fill that time. And character's motivations are weakly formed at best. Picard himself mostly feels like he's along for the ride, rather than an active participant in his story. Data is for some reason the chosen cornerstone for this story even though Spiner seems well over the character and the plot uses the well-despised Star Trek Nemesis as it's prime inspiration.

Instead of showing the best of humanity under adversity, Picard chooses to show us only broken people. But whereas it's predecessors allowed the choices and moral questions of the show to define and hone those shattered people into better people with purpose, Picard instead just throws them into a whiz-bang action sequence and calls it growth. Well trodden characters like Seven of Nine have their entire arc tossed aside for the benefit of creating a "bad-ass" character. Picard himself is shattered by a choice that honestly doesn't seem really in his control. And all the new characters all given slow push-ins with dramatic music in place of development. 

While DS9 and TNG skillfully managed episodes dealing with corruptions within the trusted institutions of Star Trek, Picard uses it as a device without  any real satisfactory examination of the moral and ethical failings of those institutions. The Federation bans artificial life and we are told that's bad. But the catalyst for that choice is artificial life more-or-less causing the genocide of the Romulans. So as a viewer we kind of get why that ban would be in place. And to make it more confusing the artificial life that the show is protecting is...organic...It's a confusing mess. And the backstory of how she's kind of Data's daughter doesn't help matters.

Perhaps, the most disappointing thing is we explore nothing new. The show manages to go an entire season not managing to achieve what a single episode of any trek show before it does. Even Discovery, manages to have some episodes that explore new ideas, cultural or ethical questions, or scientific theories. Picard does none of that. It barely explores it's own characters with anything more than lip service.

To top it all off, viewers get shown Data is still alive (kinda), only to then watch him ask Picard to kill him. What's the point? Just want to milk a little drama? Sure as hell seems like it.

One of the worst pieces of TV I have ever seen. Everything in this show is a complete mess. The writing is absolutely atrocious, the dialogue and the amount of melodrama in every single scene makes this feel like a TV show made for teenagers exclusively.

The acting is shockingly bad, the characters have zero motivations for their actions and everything is extremely silly. If you spend more than 1 second thinking about any given plot point in this series it all falls apart like wet toilet paper, absolutely nothing makes sense, and in typical Alex Kurtzman fashion the show moves along extremely quickly in an attempt to not make you not notice how everything that is blasted to your face adds to anything coherent. Picard himself is merely a footnote in the show and serves no meaningful purpose. You could basically cut him out and wouldn't make much difference.

This TV show is an absolute travesty and I have no idea how Patrick Steward got conned into doing this.
boring and does not follow the original picard personality.

This is an exceptional re-visit to the character of Picard that any fan of Star Trek Next Generation will enjoy. Star Trek Picard is a marvel, Sometimes it can be a slow burn, but hang on to the finale and you will not be disappointed.

Bad! Real bad. I really wanted to like it and was looking forward to it. I forced myself to watch 2 episodes hoping it would get better but it didn't. That was 2 hours of my life wasted and will never get back. How on earth did the "Tomatometer" get 87%? Bad acting and bad story line. Didn't the director notice? Didn't anyone notice?
Never been the biggest Star Trek fan, but even I knew, even before this, that Picard is the greatest captain. Watched all 10 episodes in a single day. It was beautiful.
If you don't understand the essence of Star Trek please stop making it.
This one star is for Patrick Stewart alone. This whole show seems intent on spitting in the faces of Jean Luc and audience's alike.

So many reviews all say the same thing - it's not star trek. I've watched both the new and old star trek shows and what makes them star trek? Science, space and meeting alien life. Just because a show doesn't do what you want it to doesn't make it a bad show. And not gonna lie but, some of the so called classic star trek is boring.

The show is great and makes you invested in the characters. There is action but not excessive which makes Picard instantly better than Discovery. The only main issue I have with the show is the F bombs dropped by certain characters, it just doesn't suit their personality.

I know the show is being picked up for another season which to me seems very unnecessary given the way the first season ended. Personally I can't see where they would take a second season and I don't hold high hopes for it.
Very good first season with freshness and classic stuff combined in a brilliant way. Recommended!

Very disappointed! I just could not watch any longer after episode 3. Just sad, that is all what I feel. I do not continue to watch it any longer because I do not want to remember THIS Jean-Luc. Apologetic, lame, weak, baffling old man. It is not his age, they turned him into sg. he is not...
The return of the iconic Jean Luc Picard. Well done.  An adventurous story with the addition of a handful of other iconic Star trek heroes of the past.

Interesting characters that suffered from poor writing, bad acting here and there and no time to show their full potential. JL often comes across like an old man chasing ghosts that has the support of the crew out of pity instead of trustworthyness. So much potential and they made this. Pity.

I think Picard is amazing.
Some people say it's not Star Trek or too dark or too something but they forgot that in older trek we got many many dark things and as in Picard, they were always used to once again reaffirm the principles of the federation and self-reflection.
It is an incredible show. Def a must watch

The season starts off with nice nostalgia but the plot is a mess. Every inconsistency with the established Star Trek universe destroys the suspension of disbelief. Even trying to ignore this is suppose to be Star Trek and treating it as a separate entity the plot makes no sense. The boring melodrama on the Borg Cube is a waste of time, characters are hollow and poorly written. By the end you're left with the feeling you've seen this story before and it was told infinity better by other Star Trek and Sci Fi shows. That said I'll probably start watching season 2 in the hope it's better written.

I waited to binge the entire series so I could make an honest call on the show.  It is just not what I expected.  Felt more like BSG than Star Trek.  At times I was wondering why they even decided to put it under the Star Trek brand when it just doesn't work.  It is mean spirited, poorly written, and just confusing to watch.  Did not care for it.

I really wanted to like this, like I wanted to like the new Twilight Zone, both beat you over the face with modern day issues inorganically used. The old Twilight Zone was subtle it made you think the old Star Trek gave you hope for the future. Now they both just slap you in the face with issues, I get it, the world sucks, does the escape I use to decompress have to suck too? Does everything we do have to push how crappy the world is? EVERYTHING?

As expected, great performances by Patrick Stewart and all the friends from the Next Generation. Slower paced than most Star Trek series' but the dialogue and story line was interesting and I didn't miss the action. Looking forward to Season 2,

"Picard" 1st season ranks about 70%...maybe a bit less. I think there are some significant flaws, though. First of all, I didn't really like X-Men, and I could see some "convenient" parallels with the story in Picard and the X-Men movies. Then, I also think Picard as a character was often very sanctimonious in the TV series and movies. Athough the writers seemed to focus on making him a bit more "human" in this series, perhaps they could have done just a bit more in that direction, in much the way, Kirk and Spock wound up being more open about their own BS, at least to each other, I would like to have seen Picard open up a bit more then what he did. The acting is difficult to gauge, as these people are only as good as the writing, so, let's just say there's a fine line between flashbacks and lengthy speeches....when out of balance...it effects the FLOW of the story and character development. It did. There's ALOT of moving parts here..and so this was probably a herculean project. I'm glad they did it...I just wish the tenor of this would have been less melodramatic and more real. It was in parts, but it kept swerving in and out like a car almost out of control.

The writing is bleak and bad, even insulting to the franchise, even more then J.J.-Trek, which says a lot. 
When I was younger, I always felt I was not smart enough for old Star Trek. Now I'm glad to know I'm not dumb enough for new Star Trek.

 Made me rewatch DS9.

I've just caught up with Picard, now on Episode 6.  Brilliant!  Yes slower paced, but great characters, acting and direction.  Patrick Stewart sublime and nuanced, as always. Lots of lovely nods to earlier series. Fingers crossed there's another season to be had.
I'm so happy they brought Picard and Seven of Nine back and I hope we get lots more.
I give it 3 stars. Episode one is really good, but then it starts to drag on and on and on. The pace is too slow and it feels like the series comes to an end without ever getting in top gear.

The cast, special effects, etc. are great. What sucks is the writing, characterization, tone and deliberate destruction of beloved characters, as well as all the endless continuity mistakes. It's just a terribly uninspired mash-up of every fantasy or SF thing ever, combined with gratuitous sex and violence, while ruining the entire Star Trek universe (e.g. turning the Federation into a dystopia) just to tell such a lackluster tale that doesn't even make any sense. Terribly disappointing, and clearly written by people who've never watched TNG seasons 3-7 and don't know why fans loved it. If you don't know Star Trek and just want to watch a violent, non-nonsensical SF show with some pew-pew action and some androids, go ahead. But if you were a fan of TNG or VOY, it's better to stay away and remember the characters and world the way they were.
Absolutely terrible.  Vandalism of a beloved character and television show.
Too stuffy. Tries too hard to be better than the other Treks. Lousy experience.

The ending was terrible. Have any of the writers or show runners watched a Star Trek episode before working on this show?  With CBS All Access the overall theme of their Star Trek series is dystopian.  Star Trek should show a better future for mankind.
I know CBS Access is a paywall app, but historically network TV has difficulty producing science fiction.  It shows on this series.
I was really looking forward to this show, but the writing was just boring. I saw the twists a mile away and it just doesn't feel like Star Trek at all. Discovery is so much better than this.

Why is the internet in general always so grumpy and judgmental about things? Having just finished Discovery and Picard, I have to say that I loved them both and can't wait for more. You see, I love Star Trek, any Star Trek, and since I can't go out there and write my own shows, I watch the ones that are presented to me, and I enjoy them. Because it's Star Trek. I've watched every show of every series and every movie. While some I've liked more than others, I still like them all. Not once has the creators of this series disappointed me to the point of making me hate a series or movie. I'm just thankful for them all, and want more, more, more. I truly believe that most of us fans feel that way despite what some of these reviews claim. I respect their opinion, but that's just what they are writing: an opinion. Who these people are and what they want out of Star Trek is unique to them and should not be masquerading as an informed critique of a show's worth to others. Don't be ashamed if you liked Picard or Discovery. Many of us out here who choose not to vomit criticism all over the internet agree with you.

A little late criticism of this magnificent series, which is more than a sequel to The New Generation, Star Trek: Picard, it is a resolutely modern series, whether in terms of image or narration, from natural settings to special effects, through the choreography of the fights, everything is sublime, the impeccable performance of "Patrick Stewart" (Picard), is all in finesse and spark of empathy. The series starts smoothly, to intensify as it unfolds its full capacity for seduction. It is moreover very rare to see a series which positively affects the human and positions the human spirit in a more obliging manner and encourages the spectator to think positively of a future which currently is still not looking good, so a little freshness, will know what to do good. There is an interesting and captivating story of superb special effects, beautiful colors of beautiful science fiction that will delight all fans and positivize others. An incredibly well done series that I loved and that I obviously recommend.
Simply magnificent.

Not top notch, but definitely more than a pass.
The series was a bit slow to start off with, but seemed to heat up a bit toward the end of Season 1.  I'll be watching season 2 for sure to see where it leads.

I've been watching Star Trek for as long as I can remember.  I even watched some episodes of TNG over airwave TV when I was little, and remember how popular it was at the time.  I continued watching and became more serious about Star Trek during DS9 and Voyager, and finally got DVDs and Blu-Rays of all of the series and movies as an adult, and have enjoyed watching them all.

Picard was heartbreakingly bad and killed my love for his character and others from TNG and Voyager like the way that it pointlessly murdered Hugh and others.  This show made me dislike the company and actors that would make such insulting garbage and then try to sell it to fans as a step-up from the old.  It completely dumps on the message and spirit of all of the older Star Trek series.  You've ruined one of the greatest pieces of sci-fi in history, and then told us that we should like it or there's something wrong with us.  I won't be continuing to spend any money on Star Trek unless there are drastic changes to the way these shows are made.

Very disappointing. The visual effects are good, that's the only upside. Bad story telling. If I wnat to see a space fight spectacle, I would rather watch Star Wars. Nothing in common with Next Generation, which established a noble, empathetic society of the future. There is not much left of things, which made Star Trek popular.
More Mandalorian than Star Trek Discovery. Boring with poor writing

it is extrimely slow, nothing compared to Voyager or Star Trek next generation. Very little imagination. If you compress all episodes in just one, may be it wold have been an ok episode. Good to watch to get to sleep.

What a let down. Action spectacle from a dark place. Sprinkled in some character moments, with characters you loved but that now are twisted and broken and most of the time out of character. The story is a basic action scifi story, spread out like a piece of butter over way too much bread. It only makes you think how these characters could ever act like that. Plot follows function - the function to setup the next visually pleasing scene or the next action spectacle. No deep thoughts, barely any believable character development, totally not the star trek spirit that is an example of how to act. It's an okay nonsense action flick, but it dismantles the Star Trek brand further into an exchangeable futuristic battle field with not depth.
I love Star Trek in general however this show is horrible. Made myself watch into episode 6 but I can't take it anymore. So many good shows out there today so don't waste your time on Picard.

Tragically bad. If you want to see good darker scifi watch DS9, Babylon 5, Farscape, The Expanse and probably 100 more. If you want to see Star Trek look to any other product with the words Star Trek.
One of the biggest disappointments in TV history. An incoherent boring mess from start to finish. Shocked by the critics ratings.

The story is overly convoluted to try and fool you into thinking it's complex. Just like Discovery, they try and make up for the bad writing with likeable actors. Honestly though, its worst crime is how GRIM it is. Every character is a suicidal, borderline alcoholic completely consumed by past trauma. Even in our modern dystopia, humans are capable of experiencing way worse trauma than these characters without becoming brooding and hateful. It's even worse that it's set in the trek universe where humanity has supposedly evolved. Star Trek will never be BSG or the Expanse - it's best when it's message is optimistic

Throws all of the noble, positive, and optimistic things about humanities future in space (as shown in every series in the franchise up to 2009) and replaces every character you've loved with a dystopion, black-mirror version of themselves. 

This is a shamefull show written by people who are being intentionally divisive and are smug about it. It panders to the kind viewer who enjoys being beaten over the head with todays awful, reactionary internet politics. So to summarise, this is a show so bad to watch, and bad for your ability to control your temper that it should come with a health warning rather than an age rating. 

Avoid.

Loved it!  Picard was my hero in TNG so I was afraid and excited about this series.  It achieves a great balance between maintaining the spirit of the original TNG characters while introducing edgier story lines and updated feel.  I feared this was going to be another supposedly updated show that beat us in the head with overwhelming liberal ideas while completely destroying all that we loved about the original story line and the characters.  But it does not.  I watched TNG in my 20's.  I have since grown older, matured and changed, but who I am did not.  I feel like the TNG characters did the same.
Not Star Trek in my opinion
Patrick Stewart plays Jean-Luc Picard exactly the way it needs to be played. Impressive debut for a show runner's first show. Main flaw is that the plot tries to do too much in only 10 episodes.
It's good to see Jean Luc back in action!
Sadly this is only star trek by name. Very disappointing. I'd rather see the franchise die in a good state (after voyager) than see any more of this.

The show starts out really well and I got hooked thinking this is going to be good.  Then you start watching the next couple episodes and you get lost in trying to figure out where things are going but still pretty good and pays tribute to TNG of the past.  The best episode I thought was the one when they visit Riker and Troy's house even if it didn't really help further the story it at least filled in what happened with them all these years later.  7 of 9 makes this freaking awesome entrance into the show but gets muddled later on into a story line that leaves you going what was that all about.  Then you get to the last episode and it left me with a bad taste in my mouth is the only way to explain it.  It brought back memories of Generations where everything was rushed and it completely showed. Overall it's good and I'd recommend it and while it starts out as OMG this is freaking awesome in the end it leaves a bad taste in your mouth and wondering do I bother with Season 2.

This new series is a slow-paced sci-fi adventure with a complex and sophisticated plot, nearly each episode in itself suspenseful and ending with a cliffhanger, but the final conclusion is derivative and waters down all the accrued expectations.
Love my Picard! Only Spock and Kirk are more Star Trek than Picard. More please . . .

terrible dystopian version of franchise I used to love so much..violence, terrible writing, people drinking in every episodes and all of them went through some big trauma..boring, dragging, absolutely without any idea how to create a star trek story..shame on producers..

I wasn't expecting much with all of the terrible Trek movies out there.  Admittedly, I am a TNG fan, not as much of the others.  I was presently surprised at the quality of the script, acting, production, and story.  It's probably a bit better than 7/9, maybe 8.5/10.  It's certainly worth a watch if you are a Trekkie or TNG fan.  

That said, it's got some plot holes.  It's got a very unlikely curtain call from Riker, reminiscent of the 1980s style.  I'm not buying the Riker/Troi offspring casting and character.  I hate to say it, but I hate seeing an aged Deanna Troi as she goes from interstellar hot in TNG to mortal.  It was a nice surprise to see Hugh.  I didn't care for the casting of the Romulans.  Selfishly, I missed Geordi and Worf, but that would have been too much like a TNG reunion.

I'm unsure that a season 2 will be as successful.  I'd love to see Picard get some swagger back.  You cannot go wrong with seven of nine!  Isa Briones was really great!  She can dominate season 2 with character development as long as they don't make it so lame as Data's endeavor to be human. You can dump Alison Pill's character.  Give Captain Rios some of his swagger back too.  Get some of the old crew and let's go sprloin'.

On a final note, I have to say that the sending off of Data was just perfect to me.  I think it was a difficult thing to write in a manner that was emotional yet organic.  I feel that it was a fitting end to a life well-lived.

Star Trek: Picard is a betrayal of the hopeful spirit that once made the franchise great. Dark and edgy, Picard destroys Gene Roddenberry's optimistic dream for the future: a utopia where all humans (and non-humans) work together in the name of exploration.

A series that once presented philosophical questions about the nature of humanity, has been reduced to a generic sci-fi show, packed with unnecessary action and violence. Never are the characters allowed to bond with each other or the audience, resulting in a story that lacks soul. Never is there a lighthearted moment, making all the "intense" scene (i.e. all of them) feel like more of the same. With no frame of reference, the stakes never truly feel high.

Seven of Nine has become a cynical terminator. The Federation has become corrupt. Even the new characters can't save the show, feeling like shallow tropes played out in every other mediocre action franchise. Picard makes so many attempts at creating depth, that it never really takes the time to develop any of them, causing everything to fall flat. When a hundred and one things are happening at once, how could you possibly expand upon any of them?

The plot is contrived and implausible. There are numerous scenes so unnecessary that they could have been cut out of the show entirely, with no effect to the story. Not only are these scenes unnecessary for the plot, but they don't endear the audience to the characters or provide any relevant information. In other words, they're completely useless.

Perhaps the worst moment in Picard is when you are forced to witness Icheb, a former Borg drone from Voyager, be tortured by an antagonist. The scene is extremely gory and difficult-to-watch, and for no good reason, considering there is nothing in it that couldn't have been conveyed to the audience in a different way. It leaves a bad taste in my mouth that Picard brought back an old fan-favorite only to torture and kill him.

The cinematography is overdone and distracting, adding to the confusion created by the already-too-complicated plot. There are so many lens flares and closeups and "poetic" camera angles that it becomes hard to keep up. The producers clearly think that more = better, when in reality, sometimes more = a visually-appealing train wreck.

Star Trek is dead, and everyone involved in this killed it.

Visually good looking with decent special effects. Too many plotlines that go nowhere, terrible two dimensional characters, nonsensical story and terrible ending. Probably one of the dumbest shows I've seen in a long time.

Disappointing. On the one hand, glad to see the Star Trek franchise alive and kicking. On the other hand, this series was so mediocre. The main storyline is utterly boring, and Picard seems to have lost his mind -- he just lets his swaying emotions make all decisions for him rather than think them through. He would never have become a starship captain at all had he acted like this in ST:NG. Supporting characters come and go with little rhyme nor reason. Some show up just for fan service. Others who seem important simply vanish, I guess because all the writers got hit by amnesia. So little effort was put into this series, it's like it was designed as a cheap throwaway.
Preachy and disappointing. Don't make a Star Trek series unless you want to make an actual Star Trek series. Wanting to tear down a beloved property isn't exactly constructive or profitable.
I really enjoyed the story. And I can't wait for the next season
Horrible representation of Star Trek universe. This "renewed style" of Star Trek shows are painful to watch. They really need to let it go and end the Star Trek.
An 87% rating from Critics makes as much sense as the plot for this first season: IT DOESN'T. The only good thing about this show is the great Sir Patrick Stewart. Thats it.

Picard is Trek's message at its finest. Picard has a bittersweetness that may be too much for some fans to handle. Seeing one's heroes age and soften around the edges with time can be painful, even if it's a television show. Picard has aged, the federation has changed, for that matter the galaxy has changed. Picard's Star Fleet is not the same armada that welcomed home Voyager in 2001 and The Captain is not as spry as he was ,last we saw him, on the bridge of the Enterprise E  in 2002. And the way the story is told has changed. I think the team at CBS did a great job bringing Trek into the 2020s. It's sometimes dark, definitely conveys more emotions and humanity, the characters we love have aged, been wounded, Some have more to lose than ever and some are simply looking for a reason to carry on. The new characters are played by incredible talent. But for me the series best performance was Marina Sirtis' Troi. She  is the very epitome of empathy in Picard . You can see the pain that other's are trying to hide come through in here eyes, she doesn't even need lines... but she has some great ones.  Not as good as Picard's speeches or Riker's "debriefing" of his former captain. and Rafi is one of THE most humanized characters in franchise history. Her struggle is real, the pain, the frustration, the regret,  the anger, the self pity, the longing for acceptance... so relatable. So many great characters, all multidimensional. Loved it!!

This is honestly one of the worst things I've ever watched. As for a Star Trek show, it's shameful. So nihilistic and depressing. The writers of this show should be embarrassed. Star Trek is done for me.

A solid start had me hopeful for a great season of Star Trek, but the show seemed to fall apart as it neared the finish line. Emotional beats seemed predictable and uninteresting, the minor details where other contemporary trek shows have shined seemed lackluster. While Star Trek: Discovery had interesting and varied ship designs for every group they encountered, Picard only showed two classes of federation ship, two Romulan ships, two types of shuttles, etc. The Holograms in discovery are glitchy and build up a small background arc of the the technology getting shelved until the Picard era, while in Picard the background elements tell no story. This lack of world building could be forgiven if the story wrapped up in a satisfying conclusion, but I found myself somewhat uninterested in the final episode and hoping for new stories and character arcs in season 2 rather than wanting to see more of what's been established in the first season. Overall, the intriguing and well done setup to Picard earns it a few points, as does it's decision to leave the season in a place that anything could happen in season two rather than tying itself down to specific arcs, but its not what I had wanted from a return to 24th century trek, nor was it an especially pleasant surprise.

Delusion. Plot is naive. Illogical. Senseless. Cheap.
[Spoiler]  
In example, one of the team betrays them, murders another team member, and after 15 minutes of chat, they simply accept the murderer back in the team, assigning her vital key roles, as if nothing happened!
Another example is another villain, that manages to manipulate the Startrek team, and convince them to ally with him and work for his goals, after little chat.
Capitan Rio, wow so creative, also very fitting for a Startrek.
Ninja in the team. Wow so mature. Top notch writing. *claps*
Every episode has 1 "happened previously" 2 "happens in the next episode" and a long intro clip, eating away good 10 minutes from every show. Every episode is full of flashbacks.
The last episode is super rushed and shoke full of often useless stuff. 
In the middle of the key fight, while multiple things happen. The director decided to fit in also the story of Picard dying from a brain condition. All the tears hugs and sentiments etc, only to find out 5 minutes later in the show that they copy his conscience into an identical human like android, to continue life as if nothing happend. So wtf you need to spend 15 minutes in melodrama just to reverse it 5 min later??
There is 7 of 9 joining them for the final battle only to do literally nothing. So one wonders why tf she joined?
I really liked to like this, it was painful to watch.

After enjoying the first three episodes the plot falls apart as it approaches its climax. The addition of layers and layers of plot threads that go nowhere, remember how Raffie has a son that hates her and is having a child with a Romulan, not important, remember how Agnes kills Bruce without any real consequences and remember  Elnor and his fascination with the Three Musketeers, nope, remember Picards Tal shiar house keepers, despite being given almost main character states, ahhhh all nothing. 
The weird leaps in logical you need to have to get into the plot, in the background we have the evacuation of the Romulan people...why, the Romulan Star Empire doesn't have ships to evacuate two planets from a Supernova, which takes thousands of years.
But deep down this Show justifies intolerance, in hindsight the Romulans' have the moral high ground, hear me out. The Romulans find evidence that of a Galactic wide apocalypse caused by artificial life and Souji, despite being an all round pleasant person (android) who has friends on the Borg reclamation station, gains a father figure in Picard, has a sister she communicates with who is in love with a person, she is has a pleasant experience with Riker and family where she learns about the death of Riker's son and the emotional grief the daughter went through, arrives at the Android planet sees Noonian Soong Jr and Bruce Mattics living side by side with androids in peace and sees the absolute lack of hostility between the crew and settlers. After one small moment she decides that she will summon a robot tentacle monster to destroy all organic life in the Universe. The show goes to length to show that thinking androids (not Data) are similar to us, except for their processing speed and superior strength. Does this not justify the Romulan response.
Absolutely awesome series, im a die hard star trek fan, the whole plot was brilliantly written! So great seeing old familiar faces.  Bring on season 2 ASAP! BRAVO AND THANK YOU!

Perhaps I'm not a "true" Star Trek fan, as the show appears to be getting hammered by audiences. But, I thought it was awesome. A really modern take on the show, a bit more gritty (in a realistic way), and the characters have a lot of depth compared to when we last saw them. I highly recommend it!
Hot garbage, just like Star Trek Discovery.

When going into this show I was pretty excited to see Stuart back in the Picard role, and I really liked what it was pitched as: A character study and Star Trek story that takes place outside of Starfleet. That sound new and different for this franchise, and a "character study"?! Sound like it won't be mindless action like Star Trek Discovery or the JJ movies! I'm In! 
But as the show went on I grew more and more frustrated with it, so many plot threads that either go nowhere or are just underwhelming. The production values bounce between "Wow, this looks like a movie" to "Wow, this looks like a high school student film." Also I feel like a lot that made Star Trek unique and different from other Sci-fi out there and replaced with an inferior copy of other Science fiction properties like Mass Effect, The Expanse, or even West World. It would be one thing if it was interesting and fun to watch but man watching this show began to feel like a chore.
The plot is flimsy, the reasoning is non-existant, the acting is surprisingly weak, and the entire purpose of Star Trek as a vehicle for telling stories is ignored. It's Star Trek: Justice League.

Not only was the Federation unrecognizable, but the character of Picard was a shadow of this once beloved Enterprise Captain. It was obvious the writers weren't fans of Star Trek, or worse stunningly ignorant of TNG's narrative and tone. This abomination has sullied what was once a beloved franchise. It's a shame really. I had really hoped to enjoy the show.

TNG was a future where for the most part humanity had become something better. A future you may have actually wanted to be in.

Well throw out hope, exploration, curiosity, and many of better sides of human nature from Roddenberry's ideals and get ready for another grim ride. Why try to inspire people when you can just have shakey cam fight scenes! Philosophy is hard to write and people don't want their perspectives challenged so throw in fight scenes with swords. TNG wasn't the pinnacle of writing but at least it had fun, at least it usually made you feel good by the end of the episode.

It would be nice for once considering the amount of terrible things blasted at us in the news if people could make something a bit more hopeful/inspirational like the old TNG series. I suppose we have the Orville which is the closes thing that has come out recently.
Reaaaaaaaally bad trek. Mediocre scifi.

Honestly hard to watch. The story is boring and even long term trek fans struggle to hold interest. I watched the entire first season during lockdown and had I had anything else to do I wouldn't have made it past episode 2. Complete trash
I hated it. See RLM's Plinkett review to understand why.

A slow, narrow-minded, uninspired, and bastardized regurgitation of what was once considered some of the finest examples of the franchise. No elements moving forward would convince a viewing of another season, especially with any current writers at staff.
I wanted to like this season but was profoundly underwhelmed by the mediocre science fiction that's become today's standard fare, completely unworthy of the Star Trek label it proudly flaunts.
Trash, what waste of time.

This show is not Star Trek.  Dystopian future with drug addiction and constant murders (murder without consequence!).  Plots that make no sense with lazy writing to get out of complex situations.  I think the best way to understand how crappy this series is by the last episode being rated so poorly because everyone finalized realized that the show never got better.  Steer clear if you don't want Star Trek ruined like no one has done before.  I mean it's soo bad I was inclined to leave my first ever RT review.

Fantastic! Great story arc and fantastic characters. I'm a longtime Star Trek fan and I like to see them show how the future isn't always perfect. Flaws make us who we are and make these characters much more believable.
Beautiful and full of nostalgia, this show reminds me of what is good about Star Trek: the story of people.

Great show. Brilliant writing. Yes, it's a very new and different Star Trek. Thankfully. Why do the same thing over and over again. It's fresh, sharp, edgy. Acting is exquisite and the writing is phenomenal. Can't wait for season 2.

Front-loaded with the better (but still absolutely not good) content, the writing, plots, character "progression" has gone right down the same awful and incredibly WTF-inducing pathways as Discovery Season 2.  The writing is utterly abysmal, and "Jay El" is NOT Jean Luc Picard.  It's Patrick Stewart playing Patrick Stewart amidst CW-level plots, with YA-esque romance, then more violent murders and mustache-twirling villainy than a Marvel plot.

We knew it wasn't going to be TNG, but I still expect it to be *Star Trek*, not Space Trak Jay El with real Star Trek memberberries.

Oh and did I mention it entirely rips off the plot of Mass Effect 3?  They ripped off the plot of one of the most hated video game plots of *all time.*

Get these hacks away from the Star Trek franchise!

Wow, just wow!
Patrick Steward still shines as Picard!
Entertaining and better written than many much better received shows. I really do not understand the hate.

This... new attempt by CBS adds in elements of sadism.  If we want to participate... we must watch a man's eye slowly and purposefully torn from it's socket to cause pain.  I think, that could be a metaphor for what CBS conceives Star Trek to be.  It was always, a bold new adventure with an optimistic, and humanist belief of sentient beings to overcome challenges beyond our greatest fears.  And to leave the world a better place.  I will not support any series made by the current production and directorship at CBS.  They need someone new, who understands that despite all the challenges, the future is one in which humanity has moved past it's current short-comings and brought hope to a challenging galaxy.

One of the most horrid productions in the history of the universe.  Although it breaks with so much of Star Trek's past, that is the least of its problems.  Poor cinematography, terrible writing & acting, bad chemistry, confusing visuals, use of stock photography (yes, look it up on Youtube) make this production truly one of the worst of all time.  I didn't agree with DEVS philosophical foundations or conclusions, but at least the show is well acted, paced, and the cinematography is off the charts.  CBS should rethink their involvement with this entertainment franchise.

I had high hopes for this. Perhaps too high. It started so well, and ended in a way that I am still trying to decide as to whether I am happy with. Though I am leaning on the negative. 
Most of the characters are good. Seeing some of the old crew is great. And those scenes add to the story. Hopefully season 2 builds on what they have and we get something a bit more hopeful .......like the Star Trek future is suppose to be.
Remember, these critic reviews are usually only based on the first few episodes.  The show started off strong, but really devolved into the season finale which was an absolute mess.
Not worth watching.   Just bad.
I like this, if you were a fan of Star Trek Next Gen then you will feel like an old friend has returned with a new tale to tell.

I find this particular series of Star Trek a bit gruesome and vulgar with the language being thrown around. Those are Just a few top points I would point out besides the social engineering script... deviating just a bit, it took me several weeks just to get through the first episode and I consider myself a Trek Fan. Took me another month to get through (with several start and stop viewings) episodes 2 and 3. Yeah, stopped there ... not a Fan of the new series. Some like it, more power to you folks. I think rottentomatoe was extremely generous in there ratings for this series mine would have been in the teens and only because Patrick S. Was in it....
Retconning at it's worst.  Only the names of people and places are recognizable in this TNG spinoff show and it's only the familiar names that will bring in it's audience.
Star Trek Picard is amazing. Even though it is slower and darker, it works, and the show is beautiful
It seemed a little exhausting getting through each of the new main characters' stories, but "Picard" really came together during the last three episodes.

Star Trek: Picard is yet another spin-off from the original series TNG with Patrick Stewart being the center of attention.  Star Trek has always been about space exploration and discovering new worlds, but this one takes Picard to the far reaches of space to help syndicate beings to be treated as equal to everyone else.  Picard and his love with Data puts their lives at stake against the Romulans till they learn the truth behind their agenda.  Overall it was an okay series, bored at times with familiar faces from the past. I didn't like how the first season ended but hopeful of the future, just felt Star Trek is starting to turn into a Star Wars series where no one ever dies.  Watch at your own risk not an enjoyable series.

This is not a Star Trek show. Star Trek was designed to be 'wagon train to the stars.' It was designed to be an exploration of space, and in relation a show that, as all good stories should do, address the human condition. There's not even much space travel involved in the stories. And Star Trek has a certain style, a certain high concept, that permeated from TNG all the way through ST: Enterprise, that modern producers have abandoned. This is just another typical modern drama that uses some Star Trek names and characters. Same issue with Discovery.  CBS needs to get people like Rick Berman and Brannon Braga as show runners, and develop a series that follows the ideals and style of Star Trek, or they need to stop using the name. Even The Orville does a better job following 'Star Trek style' than these recent 'Star Trek' shows do. I quickly gave up on Discovery, and I have quickly given up on ST: Picard. Time to cancel CBS All Access.

I can understand that things need to change and evolve with time, to incorporate new ideas and concepts and to appeal to a new generation.

This being said, Star Trek Picard is a brain dead mess of a show. It is filled with pointless plot devices, constant over the top eschalation of the stakes, butchering of loved Star Trek characters and sadly introduces only new ones in a massively flawed way.

Like I have done with Star Wars, I am writing Star Trek off as dead. There will sadly not be good shows or movies made in this universe again. If that is due to how brain dead the viewership is now or the lack of skill and commitment on the part of those making them, I can't say. But I am done.

How did Star Trek become dystopian fiction? For a show that continues the story of a beloved character, it shows a poor understanding of its source material. That aside, the show is rife with bad writing, weak characters, and busy, distracting cinematography. There are very few redeeming qualities to this show.

Am impressed that Star Trek has grown up. The stories of this show have the qualities of good Star Trek like curious scientific concepts or the evolution of governments, but has finally combined it with moving histories of characters that are quickly real - and without going through 2 seasons to get to know them..

star trek picard is not only the best star trek series in the franchise since the next generation era but also one of the best tv of the year, this is a great example of how great this show is, patrick stewart deserves to have an emmy nomination for this work for this.

This might be the worst "Star Trek" series to date.  Multiple variations of series world building raised to the ground alongside Luke Skywalker levels of character assassination. Star Trek in name only.
As someone who couldn't stand Discovery, it was a welcome relief to have some good Star Trek television to watch again.

I grew up watching The Next Generation.  I thinI Patrick Steward is the reason; hindsight being 20/20 and all.
  I don't like science -fiction.  I loved ST: TNG, however.
  This was that *most welcome* throw -back....only better.  It kept me I suspe need and the serial nature made me binge.
   Beautiful...also the background scores are superb.
I liked it but some of it seemed silly, and I've always had a problem with the whole "robots can feel stuff too" thing, because it doesn't really make sense.
Absolutely epic! :) Everything that I loved about Star Trek just got turned up to the max! Looking forward to season 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8... :)

This is a mediocre, poorly-written dystopian sci-fi action flick. However, as a Star Trek show, it's even worse. It is depressing and occasionally insults your intelligence. The writers and actors don't seem to care about the source material. I want to cry. The Star Trek of old is dead. They're going to ram this flashy, action schlock down our throats until the end of civilization.

Great series!  ST: Picard does a nice job wrapping up loose ends from the old days while being a compelling 10-episode story that stands on its own.  Nods to yesteryear come in about the right balance with new story.  And the cast does a great job.
Avoid like the plague, even if your not a star trek fan, its terrible as Scfi show, even worse as a star trek show,  Not even sure how this got approved and made?

The first season seems like the content of 1-2 episodes of TNG stretched out on 10 episodes.There were a lot of inconsistencies and illogical events like: the Romulan Empire consisists of thousands of planets spread across the galaxy, yet they can't deal with refugees from their home planet.The Starfleet is a union of hundreds of races and civilizations, with exploration, knowledge and diplomacy as their motto.How come they are now isolationist and prudent, after centuries of 'boldly gone where no one has gone before', with these close minded and dumb leaders?Every season, every episode of Star Trek was a valid argument for why exploration, knowledge and boldness are better than stagnation. The explanation that the current bad writters have for the change makes no sense at all. The dialogue was terrible, the themes discussed were overly simplistically analyzed. It's hard to believe the dialogues were carried out between highscool graduates, let alone high officers and scientists. Picard as a character was inconsistent with TNG, except for the episode 'Tapestry' (that was an excellent written episode with great dialogue). The current Picard seems like the logical evolution of the alternate, cowardly and dreary man from 'Tapestry'. He appears as senile and overwhelmed and with no authority whatsoever. Everyone yells at him and he apologizes to everyone for everything, while not knowing how to handle simple events. I watched every episode with the hope that maybe in the next episode there will be something better, at least small things, small dialogue, but the overall story and the the way it evolves turned everything bad. In every episode there is so much bad writing, with so many small and big inconsistencies, that makes Picard one of the worst showes in a bad year for TV/streaming. As a separate and personal note, not related with my rating: I'm an AI specialist, and AI doesn't work the way is portrayed in TV shows. It doesn't work like that since Asimov's days. I understand that AI is there just to create conflict and ask questions about what is truly human, but if Hollywood just makes a little research about AI than there could be better and more relevant stories to be told about this subject.

The writing is terrible, and the direction for acting is off as well.  I'm very disappointed and will stop watching until the 2nd season - to see if anything is changed.  The characters have no integrity, the frequent cursing seems out of place and ruins the special "Star Trek" feeling; as well as the increased violence and more gore than any of the past series.  Sad.

For fans of Star trek, its very very good
If your not a trekkie, don't rate it, you don't understand the whole thing
Can't wait the season 2
ok for nostalgia, very little to do with the star trek franchise R.I.P Star Trek
The finest production from this franchise in decades.

I just finished watching Picard. They did a great job of filling in the gaps of what characters have been doing since the show ended, and where they were going. Very impressed.

It was basically the opposite of what Star Wars did with their last three movies.

This show is on par with that other GARBAGE series on CBS called Discovery, but what makes this so shameful is not the crappy scripts, the horrible casting, the painful acting or the idiotic efforts to remake and reboot an iconic fictional franchise, no, no, no, what makes this series suck beyond belief is how it pissed away the capital of earned respect from The Next Generation that was still at least frailly holding on after a few bad movies, and doubled down on the basics of bad storytelling and bad TV; characters consistently behaving out-of-character, horrible camera work, and a recycled plot shoved into a meat grinder that belched out something so incoherent it is plainly NOT Star Trek. When Picard dies at the end, we the viewers are desperately made to see how sad the cast is, but this show was dead on arrival.
Unwatchable.  The writers have possibly never seen the original Star Trek shows.

I don't care for this version of Star Trek.  I think the writing is lazy and I was shocked at the elements they have borrowed from other scfi/fantasy shows.  The writers resorted to poor language and gruesome violence as a substitute for thought provoking writing.  I may be a relic, but I would much rather watch something in the vein of the "Inner Light" or "Far Beyond the Stars" rather than watch an eye getting plucked out of its socket or bashing ones head in with a stone.  Star Trek was a positive influence on me.  I literally studied engineering because I aspired to be better than what I was.  If I grew up with this new version of Star Trek, I wouldn't be taking the time to write this review because I wouldn't care.  I sincerely hope CBS hires some writers worthy of Star Trek for Season 2 of Picard.

This is not star trek. It's so bizarre. It looks terrible. All the camera lighting effects.. 
All the values of star trek are not present.. It seems wrong. And it just not interesting. Even if it were a random sci-fi show, it didn't bring anything interesting to the plate...

The season is not too bad, considering it has to live up to a lot. There is no need for even saying anything good about PT as JLP - He stands on his own. The very reason the series exists. I do have some beef thought. The 23rd century had given up on money etc. Incidentally there is a constant talk of monetary elements and all the vaping and swearing. It somehow didn't sit well with me. It just feels out of whack and misplaced.

It was firing on all cylinders until the end. One giant plot hole to set up the cathartic sacrifice that changed nothing yet altered everything and a needless redux to say goodbye (again) to another fan favorite character. 
It's always poor storytelling to use a giant reset button. And speaking of Doctor Who; the magical thinking tool is a totally a sonic screwdriver. 



Spoilers:

What plot hole you ask?






Why wouldn't Soong after having stopped Sutra by deactivating her proceed to deactivate Soji? Picard's "sacrifice" felt unnecessary and a ultimately was a cheat you could see coming a mile away. 
"Yeah, but we would've missed the parenting moment where grandpa gets to empower the young offspring make the right choice (with a little help from Synthulu)"
SMH
Slow, plodding, disappointing, and full of inconsistencies, plot holes, and continuity errors.

From a lifelong ST fan, this show is virtually unrecognizable as part of the Star Trek universe. Words that some to mind are: Disappointing. Boring. Confusing. Humourless. Pessimistic. Joyless. Patrick Stewart is great as always, but that's not enough to save the show.

This is not a good tv show it is a long action movie, and we know the star trek historic on movies, the odd ones are never good. It does not do justice to the trek i knew. while romulans still look like romulans the rest of the world is very foreign to trek. much more the tone and similar story line of the battle star galactica remake. i still watched the whole thing, now time to dump cbs access.
I loved ST: TNG and this was very different so I was skeptical but the show won me over. A worthy addition to the Star Trek universe.

Gene Roddenberry is turning over in his grave right now. Any semblance of the hopeful future that Gene envisioned for humanity has been irreversibly tainted by this so called edgy spectacle. This show is Star Trek in name only. I think the most egregious part of this show is how they have taken one of the finest examples of a fictional character ever created (JLP) and destroyed his legacy. I read several articles where Patrick Stewart was excited to do the show because he thought "there was something special there". Well with all due respect to Mr Stewart (whom I admire greatly and will watch anything he performs in) who by his own admission isn't a Star Trek or a science fiction fan. Why is it so difficult for CBS or Paramount to find an actual fan of the franchise to write these shows? Where are the Okudas? Where are the folks who took pride in creating and continuing Gene's legacy? Whatever at this point I can literally vote with my wallet and choose not to give CBS any of my money. Congratulations CBS, you have successfully hammered the final nail into the Star Treks coffin.

I enjoyed Jean-Luc Picard's return to television.

I really liked the new characters in this. I thought the show did a good job of setting up their personalities and backstories. Patrick Stewart continues to do a great job as Picard. Since this is supposed to take place twenty years after the last Next Generation movie, we do get a naturally progressed take on the character. Picard is older now and retired and has gotten to that old man point in his life where he stopped caring what anyone else thinks and has loosened up a bit.

This show varies from TNG by being serialized rather than episodic, giving this an almost theatrical quality. The story and the different places our heroes travel to are interesting. There is also a small sense of humor that helps balance some of the darker parts.

However, I admit this isn't a perfectly written show. (There were moments where I considered rating this a little lower but then there'd be a moment that would remind me why I liked the show.) The emphasis on character development does eat into the overarching plot and I felt that parts, especially the revelation of the big mystery, weren't explained as well as they could. The show is also pretty confusing about what parts of the universe need money and what don't.

There are moments that feel like they were ideas from the writers and weren't natural. There will be a couple of times where you'll go "Wait! What?!". In particular, this applies to some of the kills in this. I'm not one of those people complaining about the show just because it's darker. (Even TNG had its darker episodes.) However, some of the kills in this feels like the writers were going for a "Games of Thrones" shock value rather than really being needed.

Picard looks pretty impressive for television, keeping the look and feel of the nineties shows but able to do this on a larger scale. I especially liked that they kept the bright lighting scheme from TNG. Be sure to check out the opening credits.

Overall, I can see how some people could like this less than me because there are some legitimate parts of contention, but I at least recommend you give this a shot before you make up your mind.

From the start let me make clear that I have been a Star Trek fan for around a decade (I'm currently 21, so in my metric it's half of my lifetime), so what I'm about to write here, comes from someone who grew up on Voyager and The Enterprise. I love TNG, but it's not MY Trek, if you know what I mean.
After this disclaimer let's get on with my review. This show is confused, and mentally impaired. It not only cannot keep the established continuity of the Star Trek franchise, having to retcon a huge amount of established lore. It also can't seem to follow it's own logic needing a rather large amount of "suspension of disbelief" to keep watching. It's suffers from beign generic and unimaginative, needing to use tropes and plots from other successful stories like Mass Effect, to push forward a mess of a plot that is so confused as to what it is trying to say, it says very little.
Because I'm foreign to USA/UK politics, I can't say if it's pushing any social propaganda like some people might say. I can say however, that its lessons are so out of touch and contradictory, I don't believe it to be neither progressive, nor conservative. It's just uninspired.
For those who love bullet points:
- 90% of Star Trek lore has been retconed, making the Discovery more Star Trek. Clearly an achivement in itself
- It's own internal logic is flawed, making contradictions with itself
- The ship drama is a below average sitcom
- There are no real moral lessons, no exploration of humanitys past or present problems
- Its story is not interesting or compeling, using cheap tactics to spark and emotional response.
- It's exploiting past Trek entries to create an illusion of a developed universe as an excuse to keep the drama going.
For a trekkie it is rotten. As a standalone Sci-Fi show it is below average.

Shallow, brainless action with needless gore, sex and profanity to appeal to the masses. Having one big, tired conspiracy story arch makes it worse. Star Trek should be lighter, deeper and make you ponder philosophically. 

TNG episode "Inner Light" and many others, are far better than this entire season. 

This is not Star Trek, this is a 10 part action movie.

Picard had a poorly paced first season where EVERY character had an overwrought backstory dribble out with the implied importance of high drama, but landed with a thud due the plot device's overuse. In addition, many characters simply weren't interesting and/or relevant. Admittedly the nostalgic cameos work for that purpose, but are so hamfistedly thrown in that they hurt the overall plot. The whole thing feels like pieces of different jigsaw puzzles jammed together to try to make a single whole.

What a waste of a healthy production budget.

The only likeable characters are from previous Star Trek series, everyone else just makes you hate them; both from the character portrayals and casting points of view. 

The confused storyline is akin to the worst Trek films; coupled with the stupefyingly dull pacing makes for a tedious and frustrating watch.

The ending is just horrible in multiple ways.

The only positive is the production values which are good, unfortunately it's completely wasted on this: the worst addition to the Star Trek franchise.

I was never a fan of Star Trek, I watch a few next generation, I tried hard to get into the space station one, but I could just never connect...... with Picard things are different, it's so much more relatable in terms of themes, and it's exciting to watch.  Great series
A betrayal of every single ideal Star Trek stood for, made only worse by inane dialogue and nonsensical plotting. Avoid at all costs and forget it exists.

I binged the season.  So worth it!  The story and cast were awesome. It was visually beautiful, exciting, elegant, thoughtful, and inspirational.  A new vibe rooted in the deep tradition of Star Trek.  I just loved it and can't wait for the next season.
I was disappointed with the script, the acting, and the direction. It's one long, incoherent and rambling movie.
Absolutely the best small screen version of Star Trek imaginable.  Picard, Riker, Troi, and Seven of Nine do not disappoint.  A 10 hour movie that rivals any of the feature films.

An epic series that has everything that made TNG great and more!  The focus on character and dialogue is amazing and the special effects are first rate.

The scale of the universe is huge (multiple settings) and it feels like a blend of everything that works in Star Trek along with the realistic vibe of some of the great Star Wars movies. 

Tons of nostalgia while forging new ground as well.

Keep making more and thank you!

A veces menos es mas, esta primera temporada podría haber sido espectacular e incluso podría haber permitido el ingreso a un montón de nuevos fanáticos si la historia hubiera tenido menos elementos (específicamente todo lo relacionado con el cubo Borg me parece que estuvo de sobra y eso ya espanto a muchos potenciales nuevos televidentes, Los Borg podrian haberse incluido en otra temporada).

La historia central de los Androides y los Romulanos era suficientemente interesante como para profundizar mas al respecto de las cuestiones morales e incluso dejar espacio a persecuciones y escenas entretenidas de acción y conocer mas a los nuevos personajes de la tripulaciòn

Finalmente el arco de Data con Picard me pareció inmensamente significativo y hermoso que sin duda hubiera sido mucho mejor con una temporada mas satisfactoria. 

Esperemos que para la Temporada 2 los escritores puedan potenciar las fortalezas que tuvo la Temporada 1 y corregir las cosas que no resultaron tan bien.
Horrible.  Captain Picard went from role model to doormat.

I honestly thought this would be background TV, another rehash of a good series - OMG how wrong was I!! First episode down & I can't take my eyes off the screen - just as good as watching Picard in Next Gen first time round. Filled with nostalgia and plenty of up to date gems. LOVE IT - CAN'T WAIT FOR SEASON 2

Galactically stupid.  Spoilers:

"The Romulans are sending a fleet to save all organic lifeforms in the galaxy from exterminating robots from another dimension."
"Send another fleet to stop them.  {The Romulans, not the E.R.F.A.D.}"
"Who shall command?"
"There's an aging hippie who used to be a Commander."
"Promote him to Acting Captain and put him in command."

Panicky Roboticist:  "I have a magic device."
"Use it to make a single repair."
"OK."  {Puts magic device away.}
{Later}
"Can I use my magic device to make reflections of our small ship?"
{Puts magic device away.}

"Our robot relatives are sending a distress signal indicating that organic life is trying to exterminate them."
"Exterminate! Exterminate!"
"The distress signal has strangely ceased."
"Don't Exterminate! Don't Exterminate!  Don't Investigate! Don't Investigate!"

Even More Famous Roboticist:  "I can save this organic non-robot with incurable neurological damage.  But let's make sure that the new body self-destructs in a few years"
"What about this very important robot for whom you have obtained an excellent backup?"
"What do you think I am, a famous roboticist?"

Very Important Robot:  "Please turn me off for vague philosophical reasons, right away, even though we have just been reunited decades after I saved your life."
"OK"

First, the positives: it looks good and obviously had a bit of money spent on it; I did enjoy some elements of the story. However, as I commented about ST Discovery, we're still not seeing the optimism of what made Star Trek unique. Most worryingly, for someone who remembers TNG the first time around, it didn't feel like it was Jean-Luc Picard at the helm of the show. The main problem with modern Trek? The storylines are just not that imaginative. Yes, the vocabulary involved often sounds complex and inventive but the actual concepts are poor science fiction. The trap was sprung - too much reliance on highlighting current social justice issues. Furthermore, recent Trek incarnations always seem to involve grand scale outcomes such as saving Earth, the galaxy or existence itself. This is not what the Original or Next Generation series were all about. A wide variety of science fiction writers and contributors worked on those earlier series and I may be wrong but I'm not sure that has happened since the 2009 reboot.
