Maybe the producers need to realise that it is okay to take risks by creating stories that are small scale with new characters (possibly based on one spacecraft and a charismatic team of seemlessly diverse people?!), and involve intelligent exploration of challenging science fiction, morals and the development of the human race in a future that makes us want to live there. Good luck to those who are entertained but I suppose I have to accept that the franchise I grew up with and loved is a ghost of the past; I so want to like Picard and Discovery but they're just not pioneering in the way that they think they are.
Betrayal of everything Star Trek used to be. Where are the ALIENS? Where's the lessons about other cultures that teach us about ourselves along the way? It's terrible. The writing is awful.

I recently binged season one, and while not super fast-moving it was really enjoyable. The story arc carrying through all the episodes of the season, allowing for past characters to have a light shone on them, as well as allowing for new character development. Looking forward to season 2! 

(Though, come on CBS allow an option for ad based viewing - the pay-wall seems a little rediculous)

Elder abuse. A scene where a young person physically assaults Picard, a man close to 90. As a medical doctor I am required by law to report elder abuse, even if it's only suspected. This is what "Star Trek" has become? No thank you. I stopped watching at episode 7 and will never watch again. Good luck.

As a huge fan of TNG I understand many critics, that not much is carried over from that glorious era of Star Trek except overabundant display of fan service with all the characters getting to appear without real tie-in to the storyline. Why I like it nevertheless? Sir Patrick Stewart is a blessing and he delivers as always. And the bad-ass captain is cool. What I would wish for season 2? More utopian Star Trek feeling that the future might be a better place, more ethical depths and more Picard. As a captain, on a great ship, for a cause.

1 star and I'm only giving it that because RT doesn't count votes with half a star. Terrible series and definitely not star trek. Gene roddenberry would be ashamed of this show as it betrays everything he created. It's pretty clear the people who run this show are not star trek fans. Terribly written drivel.
Amazing and well worth the time

I am giving up on New Trek ever going back to what actually Star Trek was. I am tired of Star Wars wanna-be, gritty, "realistic" versions of the future. I am tired of single characters being responsible for the fate of the galaxy. When Old Trek had that it was a team endevour except Wesley Crusher(f that character).
Great story. Love the special effects the culture of the romulans. Very well made great actors

Please Chabon and Kurtzman read this and put your sheer f*cking hubris aside...  I only made an account to place my first rating every due to the horrific storytelling in this mess.  One of the reasons Star Trek is so poor is because everyone has lost hope in 2020.  I won't be back for season 2 if there is one.

It wasn't Star Trek.  It wasn't Picard.  It was the year 2020 dressed in Star Trek COSPlay and filmed. The writers had two primary problems: they don't understand the Star Trek Universe (money, wealth, cursing are antithetical) ,  and they can't write scripts. Please someone send them to the "Expanse" school of script writing. In the meantime, take this pile of crap, put it in the transporter, set it for deep space, wide field, maximum dispersion: and energize.

This is not Star Trek. It's generic, poorly written action shlock with a few okay moments featuring the characters we remember from earlier Star Trek shows. But this isn't ACTUALLY Star Trek. It's generic trash. Poorly structured. Poorly written. Just poor, in general.

If you thought Star Trek cannot get any worse than Discovery oh boy you were wrong. Basically everything about this show is wrong. Not only it's awful, boring and obnoxious across the running time but it's also not Star Trek. It's just a weird postmodern, post-heroic, post-romantic unarticulated howl.

I'm a very big fan of the Star Trek franchise.  Have been for some time with watching from Star Trek: The Next Generation to Star Trek Discovery.  Star Trek Picard has big blockbuster movie visual fx and is entertaining to pass the time, however, I would not call this Star Trek.

After watching the first season of Picard, I was left in a bit of bewilderment as to what I had seen.  Personally, what made Star Trek great was every episode was its own story following a group of individuals who were put into various situations.  Star Trek showed the best that humanity had to offer show them as a strong, but compassionate species that was able to bring together a wide variety of alien cultures for the sole purpose of protection, cooperation and trade.

Picard to me has sank so low, that it felt more like a Star Wars saga. Every major character from the previous shows including Riker, Seven of Nine, Data made appearances but in a blink of an eye where gone making me ask myself, "What just happened?"  *SPOILER* When Riker swoops in to save Picard with his fleet of ships, felt like an epic scene but then within minutes the battle was over and Riker was gone left be befuddled by the fact that Riker was completely oblivious to the fact that his best man was in distress and dying.*END SPOILER*

Even Seven of Nine's character has been changed to a point she isn't even Seven anymore.  She went from being a Spock-like representation of a Star Fleet officer rediscovering her humanity with her star crossed lover Chakotay to an emotionally driven mercenary who has an affinity for women.

Season one of Picard as a whole felt very disconnected and pieced together nonsensically with the over arching plot of, "Save the cheerleader, save the world." Rather than it being one of those shows that you look forward to watching every episode, it really feels like one you should just wait till after the season finale to catch up on and say meh, it's something.
If you want to watch Star Trek, go watch The Original Series, The Next Generation, Deep Space Nine, Voyager and Enterprise. This is not Star Trek.
Laughably bad, an abomination.
Insightful, kept me guessing, a lot of old characters -- a bunch of new ones. Very interesting to see where they will take Season 2.

This dystopian nonsense has no place in the Star Trek universe.  The intent of Star Trek has always been to leave us with hope for the future, and this travesty does precisely the opposite.  That being said, the acting was spectacular, the visual effects weren't bad and it was good to see to many beloved characters back in action, even if they "fell into the bottle."

This is an absolute DISGRACE to the the heritage of Star Trek and the character of Picard. The character is portrayed as an absolute shell of his former self which for the last 30 years or more was portrayed as a confident and commanding Starfleet Captain. The character development of new characters is horrendous and the "tech" that they portray in the series is pulled from fantasy films that focus on magic than actually based on science. As a long time Star Trek fan I am truly, absolutely utterly stunned that the original Trek actors participated in such a travesty.
This show was boring and awful..
Love Star Trek, hate this
Really bad sci fi show. Even worse Star Trek show.

This show does not even get its own stuff right:
So, even the most basic Robots with AI are banned, but much more refined holografic AIs are allowed? Uhm, what?

In regards to beeing Star Trek it fails completely:
The Federation and Starfleet like roddenberry envisioned them, as an utopia, whould never be this dark, it is obvious that the creators don't care about the optimism of real Trek. 
The romulan star empire was not able to deal with a single supernova? You can calculate when a sun is going to blow up billions of years before it happens, the romulans could easily evacuate their homeworld long before that themselves using the ressources of their empire that equals the federation in power! This is not the same universe.
Where are all the old crews? Why does nobody from Voyager care about Seven or Icheb anymore, after risking the ship and their lives multiple times to save her? Like, for example, her husband? Well, they whould never fit into this dark universe where people hate those who escaped from the borg, so they just got ignored.

There is one good thing for Star Trek fans, and that is the really well done goodbye between Picard and Data in the final episode, much better end for Data then in the 10th movie, so one star for that.

Real Star Trek was never mainstream, but this show is nothing but mainstream.
This show views the universe as a dark cold place and you should better stay home, like Picard gets told in the first few episodes, but real Star Trek is about boldly going where no one has gone before, not out of need, but because you want to.

Contrived, boring, uninteresting characters and lots of plot holes. Picard was a strong regimented and moralistic leader, so sad to see his character reduced to being told off by every character every single episode.

I'm being generous with 1.5 stars because this is the nail in the coffin of the legacy of Star Trek (The Original Series).

I'll come back and elaborate and may correct mistakes because this is off the top of my head.

It's an unsatisfying mash up of these and the 2 Trek films in this list were Awful:

•TNG episode The Measure of a Man
•First Contact

You've been warned.

Peace and Long Life.
It was awefull it sure wasnt star trek either.
Recaptures the classic ideals and spirit of Star Trek TNG
Great show for star trek fans! Moreover the new characters are complex and captivating.

awful just awful writing.  Flagrant disregard for developing believable sci-fi plot devices, and more interested in mysticism, superstition, religion and projecting all the worst parts of the worlds today into the future.
Not very interesting story with see-through plot, characters acting weird and not like Star Trek characters

This is not about nostalgia. And this is not because my favourite series is TNG and my favourite captain is captain Picard. This is because of the efforts of the writers to connect the series to the Star Trek cannon  but also to make something new. The effort to tell the story reflecting the world as it is today. Keeping the ray of hope, a crumb of optimism, the idea that the things can be improved alive. Amazing visuals, good to excellent acting, heartfelt moments, smiles and tears...everything packed in so-so little- just 10 episodes of about forty minutes each.  Not enough to develop every detail and leaving a lot of the plot connections to the viewer, not being able to satisfy every Trekkie desire to see more of this or that character or justify every plot turn. But able to develop the characters so that we warmed to them and ad them at least to our head cannon. And of course, this was watching 400 minutes of the amazing acting of Patrick Stewart and enjoying the acting of his new crew. I don't want to go through every up and down of the series. Sufficient to say is that I wish the next episode were next week and not who knows how far in the future. So this is...a thank you letter: to the actors and the makers of Star Trek Picard. Live long and prosper!

I simply agree with the negative comments. I am an eternal fan of TNG and the Picard character and I do not understand why they have 1. changed it to this 2.why is everyone saying it's "so good" "poignant" ?  The actors are GREAT, the fiming GREAT, but the WRITING..?? Dear God, it's so awful.
Star trek Picard has failed to live up to Gene Roddenberry's vision of the future. This show is a shame. It does not feel like star trek at all! Terrible.

None of the integrity of the best of Star Trek. 90% Star Wars magical woo woo, 10% Star Trek.

 Super duper crap writing. Nothing has any consequences in the show, including the death of the titular character. This is not a spoiler because they tell you he's going to die in the beginning and then 4 episodes before the end they show you how his death will be instantly undone so nothing matters. Guess what he dies. They try to cheat emotions out of you with a montage of the entire cast crying about his death and then one of the cast who had just been crying magically fixes him, you know instead of telling everyone that she figured out how to save him already before he died and had the plan all ready and everything. No. Everyone cries, then he's fixed. Magic. No problem. Death doesn't matter anymore. Cool.

CBS, next time, instead please hire writers who don't hate Star Trek.

Slow. Too pessimistic and dark in tone. Too many f-bombs. Other Star Treks and Orville are episodic, with each episode being its own story. Picard Season 1 is one very, very, very long story, and it's just not a good one. So many other scifi films and TV shows have done the same story, but far better. People treat Picard like garbage and he just takes it, has no self-respect. The ninja character seemed compelling, but is insultingly underused. The show was clearly written by people who don't know the old Star Trek shows and have disdain for those of us who did, e.g., ignores the wealth of old shows that portrayed a very gradual improvement and evolution of Human-Romulan relations. The brass who make this show should do what the makers of the Mandalorian did: put fans in charge. Dave Filoni and Jon Favreau adore Star Wars, and it shows in how they lovingly crafted the Mandalorian. The people who wrote and directed Picard have gone on record insulting Star Trek fans, and it shows.
Well made and enjoyable to watch.
I expected waaaaay more :(

Roddenberry is dead and Picard killed him. Nice job. No spirit of the 23rd century that he pioneered exists here and even references to ST:TNG times or characters are tainted with revisionism that recolours it in a grittier view or a disingenuous recalling. If the offensive abuse of the setting (xenophobic Federation? Humans filled with hate, classism, obscenities, etc) isn't bad enough, the complete avoidance of scientific reality (the atmosphere of mars IGNITES in the precipitating incident) and the embrace of MYTHOLOGY/MYSTICISM (beware the Destroyer who comes as a pair, that the ancient Romulans predicted accurately using... ?) will turn you away. Last but not least are the plot holes and generally poor writing. How or why is the Android ban lifted? Ah who cares, let's mention it in passing as already done and over. This whole season was a Discovery style chase towards.... setting up an ensemble cast of wacky characters to apparently Firefly around the cosmos?
What the actual F.

Takes a couple of episodes but then it is absolutely cracking! Look out.. Spoiler Alert: To see Hugh again... remember, from The Next Generation had me in happy, happy years. New characters, old characters, great storytelling, AMAZING!!

This show had so much potential to get Star Trek back on track as a franchise, but they squandered it all.
There was so much terrible writing. It was incoherent, cringe inducing, entirely inconsistent with previous Star Trek series. It was clearly written by people who have no knowledge or understanding of Star Trek, or they simply didn't care.
The show-runners are on record saying that they wanted to cash in on the success of Game of Thrones, which explains so much about how the show failed.
A Star Trek show that lacked any intelligence or depth. Any initial excitement turned to disappointment, to then seeing this show as a joke as the show went on. They need to give control of this show to people that actually love and respect Star Trek as a franchise.
Tone deaf characters, child-like writing. Unintentionally hilarious character arcs.

This season had great promise... The first several episodes built a great story arc with solid acting, story, special effects, etc. Well produced. Well directed. Well written. It looked like the full package.

Then it fell apart. It was one shockingly bad cliche after another... One decision after another in the last few episodes that make no sense in the context of the characters making them. A stupidly illogical (and poorly animated) end of the universe scenario that is illogically averted. 

(I mean, these destroyers of everything are super powerful and just waiting for a phone call. But when the call comes and they set out to visit, they are thwarted because the rinky-dink tower on our end of the call gets turned off. Apparently they can destroy the universe, but they can't fold their own tin-foil.)

And the worst sin of movie or TV making... To kill off a good character at an appropriate time, with everyone sad (even though they all just talked about the obvious solution). Then poof, he's back alive... In a robot body, but whoa, hey, we intentionally made the robot as weak as you were. And it looks like you, and will age and die the same way as you would have... Give me a break.  

Literally 5 stars for the first several episodes... Then a 3... then a 2... then a zero. I think that averages about 3 1/2 stars.

La serie nos traslada lenta pero consistentemente desde ningún sitio hacia ningún lugar, haciendo gala durante el viaje de los peores desarrollos que he visto en un buen tiempo. 
Empezando por el guión, que llamarlo mediocre resulta en una suerte de elogio e impropia benevolencia. 
¿Cómo puede una trama ser tan floja? No resiste el ligero soplo de un análisis antes de derrumbarse. 
¿Cómo pueden los personajes ser tan insulsos e intrascendentes al final de día? Literalmente gastan un capítulo entero introduciendo un personaje cuyo aporte luego se diluye en minutos forzados y sin ninguna relevancia (No exagero). Y eso es un simple ejemplo de lo mal desarrollados que están. 
¿Donde está la humanidad utópica, el ideal de superación y descubrimiento que hizo memorable la franquicia? ¿En que momento la humanidad retrocedió tres siglos? Aquí todo es malas palabras, corrupción, violencia y políticas que nada tienen que ver con el mundo de Star Trek. 
¿Donde está el capitán, el almirante, el hombre con temple, honor y valor? Aquí Picard es un viejo inútil, crédulo, ignorante, cobarde, presto a recibir insultos y ser menospreciado por cada personaje nuevo que aparezca. Ese hombre... ¿Quién es ese hombre? ¿Qué es lo que le han hecho? 
Y podría seguir y seguir. La serie en sí misma es sosa, tediosa, lenta, incoherente y mediocre cuando menos. Ahora bien, como parte del canon oficial, es un insulto, un trozo de saliva escupido directamente al rostro de cualquier fan que entienda lo más mínimo del espíritu de la saga. Una aberración que jamás debe ser considera parte de la misma.
Están advertidos.
PD: Nadie con el mínimo espíritu crítico puede darle 5 estrellas. Hay mucha cuenta paga con comentarios vagos e incoherentes. Cuidado.
Stretching one episode out into ten = serialized storytelling.

As a long time ST:TNG fanatic I absolutely LOVE Picard. My only wish would be even more appearances by Picard's old D & E crew! La Forge, Worf, Troi, Crusher - even Barclay! I never get tired of TNG so Picard is a much adored continuation!

The writing was so bad that not even Patrick was able to rescue it at points. Quite what they were thinking with the Commodore Oh, Raffi and Narissa characters is beyond me. And that ending... So convenient.

I was a bit apprehensive to watch this series. I've always been a huge fan of TNG and didn't want it to be ruined.  I'm so happy I gave it a chance. If you are a fan and love the characters from TNG as much as I, you will appreciate Picard. The story arc corresponds with not only the original series but also the movies. In my opinion, it is respectful to the original characters. Their stories and journeys are crafted with taste. This isn't a fast-paced, shoot 'em up show. However, it's a fantastic sunset story for the characters.
Long time Star Trek fan. Loved season 1 of Picard. Must See for any Trek fan.
Awesome loved the show! Patrick Stewart and Brent Spiner were amazing as well as the whole cast.

I am a Star Trek fan. Star Trek Picard season 1 was good for the most part. For me, it started out slow but became more interesting as it neared the end of the season. However, what spoiled it for me was when the writers decided to resurrect his brain abnormality and kill him off, only to bring him back as an android. I thought that was pretty lame. Part of what made the character Picard interesting was his human frailties, both psychological and physical. Now, the writers can pretty much do whatever they want with the character, even make him super human. I think the writers really screwed up this character but there's no turning back now. I'm not sure I see myself watching a season 2.

If you loved the humanistic approach of the older series where an issue was examined from both sides in an attempt to understand, bail now. If you like characters that make decisions based on their goals and desires, bail now. If you like stories that make sense, bail now. If you like to think about your Star Trek, bail now.
If you like gratuitous fight scenes, if think one of the actors look hot, or if you just want to shut off your brain and want to see a time waster that evokes some nostalgia, give it a watch. 

Me, I'm going to go re-watch some TOS, TNG and DS9. Maybe I'll even watch some of the good Voyager & Enterprise episodes. Then I'm gonna go read a book and wait for more Orville.
Lost it's soul. One time watch.
THE WORST STAR TREK SERIES EVER MADE.

This did have the characters but not the soul or intelligence of the old star trek. With that said, if there was no giant to stand on and this was a new show, even then the plot holes would make it unwatchable. The story is not very interesting and is jumping all over the place (also completely stolen from mass effect!). 

Please get better writers next time and at least watch the old show before attempting such a thing.
Patrick Stewart is amazing as always. Almost everything else is flat and just a stale rip off of better shows and stories. I'm not interested in Season 2 but it was great to see Riker and Troi again.

I was really, really hoping to like this show. 

But I really, really didn't.

I hated it so much, in fact, that the only reason I created an account on Rotten Tomatoes was so that I could give this show the unflattering rating above.

This show just does not feel like Star Trek. It feels like they took an idea for a science fiction series, couldn't sell it to anybody on its own merits, and slapped a familiar and beloved Star Trek character onto it in order to get somebody to greenlight the thing.

A lot of shows these days are able to make the ten-episode format work without completely botching the pacing. Not this one, though! Everything feels rushed, character motivations aren't readily apparent – ever – and stuff just sort of happens and then maybe someone will use dialogue to explain it after the fact.

Just by way of example: in the last episode, the characters literally use a magic wand – I wish I were making this up – to get around two very significant problems they're having: they crashed their ship at the end of episode 9 and now it won't work, but poof! Magic wand! Now the ship is fixed! Then, later, they take the ship and fly out to confront the Romulan fleet that is attacking the planet, and poof! They use the magic wand to make a million holographic copies of the ship!

If you liked the Rise of Skywalker, you'll absolutely love the finale of Picard. Because it does a lot of the same things and uses a lot of the same lazy writing. It also actively seeks to sabotage the ending of a previous film in the franchise, as it effectively resurrects Data and asks us to witness him dying a second time. 

We also witness Picard's death from a vaguely-described "brain anomaly" – which, I guess, they had to do something like that because Star Trek medicine can cure cancer as if it were nothing, and there just isn't any space to actually make up and then explain a whole new disease with all the stuff that has to happen in these ten episodes of streaming entertainment. 

But then, moments later, Picard's death is instantly reversed when they transfer his brain into a robotic body! So Picard is now an android. But don't worry, he doesn't have any special powers or anything, and he will DEFINITELY not be immortal, because the other characters made sure that they programmed his robot body so that it would expire on its own after some number of years, giving him "the exact amount of time he would have had if not for the brain anomaly."

This is stupid no matter which angle you look at this from. 

But oh well! I guess this is the fate of science fiction in the 21st century. Bad writing, eye-pummelling visual effects, and so many edgey gritty dark edges on everything that you risk giving yourself a nasty cut on account of all the edges.

Avid Star Trek Fan here. I've seen every show/movie and this production has ruined it for me. The writing is atrocious, characters empty, and the progression of the storyline is horribly paced.

If you're a casual Stark Trek fan, the type of person that doesn't care for consistency, and someone who just wants "anything" to watch, Star Trek Picard just might satisfy you for 10 hours. To me, this show is a sword thrust deep into my TNG (The Next Generation) heart. It's as if someone took the carcass of TNG and buried it in Stephen King's Pet Sematary, only to have it show up as a ghoul of its former self.

I can say with almost 100 percent certainty that if I were to play any scene from any episode of Picard, I could point out why it doesn't make any logical sense, or it is inconsistent with everything that has happened in Star Trek's past.

I have taken no joy in writing this review. I don't know Patrick Stewart personally, but I almost view him and the other TNG actors as a long lost family because of my love for their work. Star Trek Picard saddens me to say, it's downright awful.
Otima série, explora bem o universo de Star Trek com um tom sério e atual. Patrick Stewart está impecável.

Horrible actors, stupid plot, bad writing and scenes that don't make sense such as those for Picard to act like a child or idiot at times, the "Ninja dude", etc. The show feels like it was made with too little budget, rushed and the people behind it clearly dont understand Star Trek. So while Discovery Season 2 really fixed so many things from its horrible Season 1 opening, this show just took it to a new low.
Excellent.  The story arc was good, enjoyed the next gen visits.  Story stands on its own.

Better than Discovery, but with a lot of holes in the story and with a lot of use of 'deus ex machina'. It is unbelievable the main plot, of Romulans's hate against cyborg. There are many useless characters in the story. The Borg Cube makes no sense at all. The resolution of the story is completely unreasonable and ridiculous. Even Picard himself could be better.  I hope that it makes better in second season.

Different. Pointless killing, swearing, crying... stories... just not very well done. Perhaps teenager boys will like it. But to an older fan it felt like inconsistent mess of ideas that were rushed through disregarding their own continuity.
Lazy, unimaginative generic sci fi that eviscerates Gene Rodenberry's vision of the future.

Excellent season! The story, the characters, script and ending were just crisp and familiar at the same time. Brilliant twist and turns and done with great imagination and great journey. A season I would want to watch again and again.

Really good. A real treat for all of us Trekkers and Trekkies, with great cameos and lots of little Easter egg references. Heavy on exposition, which is actually kind of refreshing for a sci-fi series, but the action sequences don't disappoint. Looking forward to season 2.

Patrick Stewart is good as always. But he can't save this boring show. The only thing the show has, and what it leans on heavily, is star trek nostalgia. If you were a big fan of older star trek, you might like it. But if you look at it as a stand alone, its a tired and predictable show with lazy writing. It feels like you could take literally any line out of the show and match it up to at least 30 other sci-fi programs. To me, not one idea the show had was original or had any depth, and I was left struggling to get through each episode and the show as a whole. It pains me to say it, as I usually love sci-fi, but DON'T WASTE YOUR TIME WITH THIS CHEAP GARBAGE.

It all has a new sense, but old connections are still there. The ending is additionally so meta that it will easily become one of the best finals of mine for decades. You would expect far less from the introductory season.
It does not suffer much if you are a little bit patient here and there, as they wanted to tell quite a complex story and align everything properly. They went very much into all details and gathered all pieces right to create it.
I just loved it and will watch again. I would love to watch this big screen actually to be honest. It must be expensive to do all these props so precisely and they would shine in the cinema.

If you grew up watching The Next Generation (or are a fan of Star Trek in general) you'll grow to find this incarnation of Captain (erm, Admiral, ret) Picard more rewarding and vulnerable than you remember JL (as a main character calls him). The world we find our protagonist is, strangely, a lot like ours now. Less optimistic (but no less hopeful), more gritty, and more 'you're-on-your-own' than TNG ever was. This takes some adjusting to but after you get accustomed to it the show is that much more rewarding and enthralling. In other words, episodes 1-3 build the premise, plot and setting (perhaps a little too much so) and then it gets good until you find yourself at episodes 8 and 9 where you're really involved. The season finale is fun and a bit quirky but, if you're a fan, very rewarding. The nice thing about this version of the Star Trek universe is that it references TNG and other series but you get a glimpse of what life might be like for more ordinary folks and there's a bit of self referential humor thrown in for good measure. 

The fx and computer UI look great and we can only hope that these science fiction bits will become realities like the how the original Star Trek foresaw cell phones, iPads (tablets) and more.

The nonsensical plot and shoehorning in of nostalgia seems gross. Picard doesn't act like the captain we knew from the 7 seasons of the next generation, and the emphasis on action for action sake seems completely out of place for a Star trek show.

The borg, data, riker, troi, and seven of nine have been placed into this series under the loosest of plot treads and the each episode makes me question why I am still watching it.
Just Kurtzman Bullshit with Terminator Picard in the End. F... this. ST is dead.
Between 3.5 and 4 stars. For me, it has found a new perspective on how to watch Star Trek.

Acting 6/10
Effects 3/10
Plot 2/10
Script / character development 2/10

40 out of a 100 that's a D in my book. Nothing that happens in the show truly mattered as by the end of it your back in the same situation as prior to watching Picard. Picard. I have been a fan of Star Trek UN since 1998. TOS was amazing TNG was excellent DS9 struck a chord with me and Voyager really blew me away. The movies of TOs and TNG were really well-thought-out. Then I watched Star Trek discovery and Star Trek Picard and I am speechless. In Star Trek; Humanity has elevated itself to a higher standard. In Star Trek nemesis; Picard said to Shinzon that I still believe today " if there is one ideal that the Federation hold most dear is that all men all Races can be United". The idea of this show throwing that belief and ideal away as well as betraying the characters of All Star Trek shows that came before is so appalling as it looks like this show was written by a 5 year old child who just looked at an episode of Star Trek and thought to himself " that looks amazing, that looks cool, and what a good idea to put this into a show and have it geared towards a new demographic.". To me that seems very disrespectful and totally betraying what Gene Roddenberry believed in as well as trampling on the Legacy of not only Gene Roddenberry but also every actor and actress who has ever been on Star Trek even if it was only for a brief appearance. If I have to say only one word to describe these shows: Traitors.

I am a big DS9 and TNG fan. I also like TOS, especially the movies, and some of Voyager. I even enjoyed much of Discovery. And maybe I'm the only one who thought the final TNG movie, Nemesis, which this series kind of plays off of, was an underrated Trek movie.

I really wanted to like this show, but it just isn't... good. Most of the concepts are actually really interesting, but they needed to be refined and improved. They also wasted the first half of the season by putting too little in, which hurt the second half by trying to put too much in. They also made the cardinal sin of wrapping most plot points up in one season finale. Boo-urns.

I appreciate the efforts with nostalgia and resolution, and it might've worked with better storytelling and pacing. As always, Sir Patrick is superb, and most of the supporting cast did a good job. Am I the only one who thinks the Soji actress is not a particularly compelling actor? Could've done much better there, as they did with Discovery.

Minor knit-picking aside, This was a great show....I LOVED IT!!! (more please!!)

It's not Star Trek, easy as that. The acting is solid, the special FX fairly impressive. But the writing... my god. Whoever wrote this hasn't watched a single episode of Star Trek. It's as though a teen trying extra hard to be edgy got the cliff notes of TNG, and was let loose. It's a very simplistic, bordering on child-like vision of what a "dark" Star Trek might entail.

It's entirely possible to execute a darker version of a universe, "Logan" being a very good recent example, while still retaining the essence of what makes it work. Picard absolutely fails to do so.

The entire raison d'etre of Star Fleet, of Picard himself, no longer exist here. 
The show never actually shows us why Picard acts the way he does.  A good example, and spoilers: he leaves Hugh to die without a thought. Or even a look, or thank you. Whenever he interacts with almost anyone the entire conversation is very one-sided. People in this series bend over backward for him, and he barely recognizes them as human at times. The accomplished diplomat, and deeply caring, if somewhat stoic, Picard of old, has been replaced with a manipulative asshole that throws people's lives away on a whim.

The entire thing is frantic, moving from set-piece to set-piece, never allowing itself to breathe. There is no internal logic, there are no tension arcs, no interesting character developments. It's literally a save the damsel in distress, and get/stop the McGuffin, with some heavyhanded deus ex machina thrown in for good measure.

Watch if for the lovely interactions between Picard and recurring characters from former shows, treat it as non-canon, and you might enjoy it.
awful lazy writing... was good seeing old characters, rest pretty meh.

In Season 1 of Star Trek: Picard, Sir Patrick Stewart dazzles us with a master-class performance by returning to one of his most iconic and beloved roles. Even when some of his fans may not see it, Stewart gives us a perfectly-aged, wizened Picard who is always just a little more aware than everyone else in the room about his own mortality which, as he discusses with Data in the Season 1 finale, makes it all worthwhile. Some fans, perhaps expecting to pick up with the Next-Generation-era, force-of-nature Picard, may not have fully appreciated that episode 1 of ST:P picks up some 20 years after Picard's last known, active status - at least not at first.

Stewart's nuanced - and progressively energetic - performance anchors the story throughout Season 1 of ST:P, which is an exquisite, and often very specific, sequel to Star Trek: The Next Generation, the flagship of the marvellous 90s-era Trek TV offerings. It is also a sequel to the decidedly less marvellous, though certainly fan-worthy, Star Trek film 'Nemesis', which is consistent with one of the main memes of ST:P's first season: twins. As fans know, Picard himself was 'twinned' in 'Nemesis' after the Romulans cloned him for dark and murderous purposes, but later abandoned their nefarious plot as too risky (and in another twin-related development in the plot, there was of course Data's twin, B4). 

As a sequel to both, ST:P soars in both story and cast. Those who have been distracted by what they perceive to be an overly dark and unnecessarily dystopian future have not appreciated the full message of ST:P in its first season, namely: there is always room for humanity to grow and progress. The growth and progress of humanity was always one of Gene Roddenberry's central themes for the future and has, despite what some critics of the 21st-century-era Trek offerings claim, carried on in ST:P. 

As much as I like it, though, I would not necessarily recommend ST:P to newbies as an entry point to the Star Trek universe. It is, after all, a sequel to both a major motion picture and a television series that lasted seven glorious seasons. As the vicious half-Romulan, half-Vulcan General Oh might say, it is only logical that those be watched first. It is not an imperfection, it is an invitation. Luckily, in this age of on-demand, stream-it-when-you-want-it digital viewing, that is a task most easily done - and a very worthwhile one at that!

For seasoned Trek fans, though, ST:P gave us a wine most worth waiting for, as if carefully cultivated at Picard Estates themselves. Not only was this a series where the writers clearly knew their stuff in terms of the background facts (known as 'canon' to fans), it was also one that was beautifully produced and skilfully directed by many talented people, including Jonathan Frakes, aka Riker, on a weekly basis. 

To turn a phrase from the series, Star Trek: Picard is "perfectly imperfect."
I absolutely loved this series!!! I've been a Trekkie since the 60s way before it was ‘in'. And it just keeps getting better and better!! Wow!! I can't wait for season II.

At first I was a little put off watching this show, but it grew on me. However, if you stick with it the show becomes quite enjoyable and the characters are downright endearing at times. If you allow yourself to become immersed in the story and characters rather than nitpicking at every opportunity you may just find value here. I am looking forward to more!

This series conclusion made me sad… and not in the way the writers intended.
It suffered all the same issues as Star Trek: Discovery Season 2. Great actors were given the most vacuous things to do.  By most accounts, the actors loved playing in this show, but the result wasn't coherent for the viewer.

Typical Bad Robot flashy physics were in play. Characters could get from A to B in an instant, whether the distances were in light years or long hikes. The Drama was hollow. A dramatic moment, undone instantly…. Constantly.

The last 10 minutes, after all the build-up of the series, had nothing to do with the season narrative. Some great acting in there trying to tug at heart strings that left me honestly feeling nothing.  

The last minute had character interactions that had no build-up and in at least one case, zero-repercussions from previous crimes.

Characters were interchangeable with their skills, and simply disappeared when the writers either forgot they existed, or they needed another character to do something. Having a Cyberneticist, who hadn't been to space before, suddenly comfortable at a navigation station and quoting the Picard Manoeuvre wasn't fun to watch.  RIP Emergency Holographic crew… you were needed, wouldn't have impacted on the drama… but forgotten.

The Episode 9 MacGuffin one of at least 2 that paid off in Ep10 was so blatantly obvious that I was desperately hoping this "X-Men 3" scenario was some sort of bluff…. It was not.

This series could have been 20 episodes of Picard: "Logan".  A beautiful, "sweary" journey where Picard made a difference one last time over two, 10 episode arcs.  But CBS and Bad Robot couldn't get their act together and changed their writing roster to boot.

I don't know if Season 2 of Discovery and Season 1 of Picard equates to being twice bitten. 

Help me Obi-wan Orville… you're my only Star Trek hope.

I'm trying to be sympathetic to all of the die-hard Star Trek fans out there... considering myself one (not on the Sheldon Cooper level but I'm a lover of the series and watch reruns frequently).  At first , I have to admit, seeing Captain Jean - Luc  in the first episode took a little getting used to. 

 Striped away was the character I knew and loved.  What I saw was a man that was much older, weathered by circumstances, filled with pain and regret.  Did we all think that Jean-Luc  And his beloved crew lived happily ever after and rode off into the sunset of perfection?  I did!  I liked that ending I created in my head... they all get together for Sunday dinners and reminisce about the old days on the Enterprise.

But when I put that aside, I began to realize that this was a Star Trek that we all should see....like it or not!!!  So I went in ... somewhat kicking and screaming... and came out the other side. Now...I understand it, except it and I am in awe of it. 

The concept... brilliant.  Execution... getting there.  Hopeful and excited about Season 2.  For my Star Trek fans... support it, embrace it... and if you can't, just give it a chance.

Been a Trek fan for decades and this was WAY better than Discovery ever could be. I loved how they didn't try to make Picard something he's not, but were able to show that he has more humanity than he showed in TNG. There is a deeper side to his character that we weren't ever shown before, the depth of his soul and the size of his heart. Also that he is fallible... just like the rest of us. I have no words. I feel that the spirit has sabotaged away somewhere way before the camera started rolling. I don't know where. The only episode which I found enjoyable was "Nepenthe", although, I don't know why the writers had to torture Riker and Troi with a brutal loss. Star Trek - at least in my opinion - is a metaphore. This series so far is a long bath in explicit brutality, the darkest parts of our soul and unwiseness of our species. Which can reflect to the World - indeed - but that way it is the direct opposite of Star Trek, which is always cherished the power of seeing and seeking people's good sides, the strive for knowledge, to find comfort in literature and history and to thinking in a scientific way. And last but not least it always teached us to have the courage to live by these things, and not bend to immorality, what sadly is stable ground of this show. To say something good about it, in my opinion Data's death was beautifully interpreted. To become as human as he could be, he has to die like every living creature. This poetic approach hasn't given us and him in Nemesis. Somehow it is just right.

Im joining the war! I give this a full 5 out of 5 because as a complete trek fan I do miss the old analytic and scientific trek with a beginning, an end and a middle. However that said as someone who has several times watched all the seasons of every trek. Even Enterprise.. I have to say. It is nice to get something new in style. It is just nice. However you might not like the writing in general or the drama in general. Understand this. Nothing can take the old trek away. You still have 10000000000 seasons of the good old stuff. I like the bold idea that they can try out new themes and new styles. In terms of plot. It honors and follows the original shows + movies line well. Many people have an issue with Picard being out of character. However this is not true. He had the end of season 7 + all the movies to evolve and open up. That he did and we see his realtionship with Data grow in the movies as well as having had grown. Both these men where calculating and in a sense emotionless who grew to care with each other. That means Data grew to care about his finite mortality as well. This show borrows ground from all the movies and shows. The biggest weakness is easily that you have to know all of that and then still be opened to a new way of exploring it in a way. Very bold, just like trek itself. Thank you CBS for exploring strange new themes and styles.

I am really dumbfounded by all of the negative reviews of Picard. I want to say upfront that I am a massive fan of TNG. Picard is not TNG. I am not sure if people were expecting a new season of TNG in 2020? If so, you should consider yourself very silly. Picard is absolutely masterful. It is engaging, interesting, thought-provoking and, most importantly, relevant. What made TNG so wonderful was the exploration of philosophy and ethics through reflection of modern events and issues in the 1990s within the context of a better, more just future. That was 30 years ago!!!! Picard manages that same philosophical self-reflection but of our modern western world in 2020. Some things are better, many things are worse. That is simply our reality and if holding a mirror to ourselves makes fans upset, then you have been incredibly self-deluded. What is so absolutely fantastic about Picard is how the creators and Patrick Stewart have been able to integrate elements of TNG into a novel and updated world of Star Trek and the character of Picard himself, who is not the same Captain we watched and grew to love, but an Admiral 30-years his senior at the twilight of his life and career. We should all be so lucky. Please do not listen or allow any of the silly reviews on this website to bias you. Give Picard a chance. Do not go in expecting TNG. Expect something new, something older, something different, something engaging, a show that not only holds a mirror to modern times through a TNG-colored lens, but to you yourself; an older, more experienced you, one that grew up watching and loving TNG.
An achievement to all involved ;)

I am a casual trekker...grew up on the original series, watched NG and DS9, then lost interest.  But I've always adored Patrick Stewart and his Picard, so it was a no-brainer to watch the pilot. I was instantly drawn in by everything about this show.  It's fun to see the old crew's cameos in various episodes, and I am enjoying the intrigue and layers to the plot.  (Special shout-out to Santiago Carrera  who obviously had WAY too much fun making Episode 8!) Music and VFX are cinema quality and all of the acting is solidly believable.  If you're not a hard-core trekkie, or even if you only have a passing knowledge of the ST universe, you'll enjoy this.  Give it a shot!  (Especially with this pandemic, you've got time, lol)
If you're looking for a cure for STD, STP isn't it.

Overall, this is a disappointment. Once I accepted, based on the trailer, that this would be yet another dark and conflict-focused show, I did like what they came up with as the focus of the conflict, because it was a new type of being, which is good for a "Star Trek". And I allowed myself to be pleasantly surprised by the way they used somf of the old ST technology we were used to in some new ways (like for a certain fight scene).

But beyond that it's been disappointment after disappointment, and I haven't been able to watch most episodes without some fast-forwarding. First of all, most of the character writing and acting is bad, everyone's "too cool for school" and throwing snappy replies all over the place, just like the totally obnoxious characters from Discovery. Picard himself is unrecognizable, there's no serious and dignified attitude anymore, he never wears the uniform, never stands up for Starfleet's high principles, spends time with some ragtag band of misfits, which is completely un-Picard-like, and worst of all he's the focus of some strange "Picard Cult" the writers have created INSIDE the universe. WTH is that?! There was never any premise for that in TNG. He was just one of many Starfleet captains with healthy attitudes and principles, there was no reason to make him out to be this great hero that everyone knows about. He's a great hero for US THE VIEWERS, not in-world! It's very tiresome to keep seeing characters give all kinds of extreme reactions on finding out who he is, that was never what Picard was about - being a galactic rock star.

Really the only likeable character in all this is dr. Jurati, because she has some realistic non-superstar modesty and is well acted. The main female character(s), while they do have some humility, are not well acted at all, the actress they picked does not have enough emotional range, even though she's almost passable because she's at least not acting like a superstar all the time.

And while I fully expected there to be some throwbacks and a conversation or two about the good old days, it turns out that there's almost no episode without some sitting around the table scene, having a boring conversation about how things used to be and irrelevant stuff that happened in the past that does nothing to move the plot forward. This is just bad writing.

Then on the tech side they also failed to make this a "Star Trek", with the most annoying part being the ship interfaces, which have nothing whatsoever with the LCARS we used to know. I could forgive the fact that they went with this popular stupidity going around these days of making the GUIs transparent and therefore unnecessarily hard to read, but they could have at least preserved the general "okudagram" look, to make them feel like "real Star Trek interfaces" to us TNG fans. But no, they threw that part out as well.

Bottom line, there is no trekking, nobody's seeking out new life and new civilizations (we're practically served the new life on a plate in the first episode), and this is not Star Trek. Thank Seth we have The Orville, which I can't wait to see continue.

I don't like it. No likable characters including JLP. Lots of Trek-babble and great special effects. Uneven pace. The story is such that I don't care what happens to Picard or  Starfleet or Space Corps or whatever it is or will be when this mess is finally over. It also seems like all the old characters have effed up lives except the Riker family. A lot of hooplas that, to me falls flat.

If you are going to watch this series thinking it is "Star trek", don't be disappointed, this is more "firefly", but without the interesting dialogues and characters. In short, it is total shit, a disservice to the entire legacy of star trek.

This is what fans like me have wanted for a long time. A series in the *future* with characters we love, in a world that makes coherent sense with what came before. Something that actually moves the franchise forwards. Perfect? No. But much better and more respectful.

Yes, it's still a darker version of the Star Trek universe. I'd prefer the positive Roddenberry vision of the future. But at least we have Picard giving speeches and fighting for the morality of the Federation. At least we have characters that care and fight for the right values.

I don't care what Star Trek looks like visually. I don't mind new tech, graphics, modern pacing etc. What always bothered me is that we've been going backwards, and doing things that directly contradict Star Trek lore. Not so with this show. Old characters provide nostalgia and fan service, sure, but they're like a balm for the soul after all the mess we've had post-Nemesis.

Picard is an interesting takes on the Captain and the Federation. More realistic and certainly less utopian. I though the series did start very slowly. When he met the second sister, everything got better. Story, action and clarity. I was please to see past characters. Some have vital roles in the story. I give it 75%. Strangely, Picard TV show isn't just about him. Which is fine for an old man.
Jesus, this show is such a mess. Picard and Patrick Stewart were such an inspiration to me. Now it's all gone. Thanks to the writers for ruining Star Trek yet again.

I'm deeply disappointed. I honestly didn't think it would be possible make a worse version of ST after Discovery, especially with Picard. I was wrong. Other than 1 or 2 moments, the entire series has been a colossal failure. It has completely missed the mark on what made the originals so great. But even if I was to judge this sci-fi on its own merits, it still manages to fail. The characters, beyond the original ST crew, are so FLAT and unlikable. It lacks heart and soul (with the exception of 1 or 2 moments). It lacks pacing. It lacks character building. Even the ship designs stray from ST. This was supposed to save us from Discovery, but it somehow managed to be worse, or at best, equally as bad. I have lost faith that we'll ever get a proper successor to this franchise.
This is not a "Star Trek" show...

Huh ???  Probably the biggest let down I've ever had for a show .  I don't know where to start it's just bad.  The writing just sucks from the dialogue to the story.  The Romulans  seem  to be humans with pointed ears.  Horrible series .

Visually stunning, with a mix of characters from a few different Star Trek franchises. Wonderfully acted by Patrick Stewart. It's not a simple continuation of the Next Generation franchise, but rather a deep exploration into the character of Jean-Luc Picard, wonderfully imagined and brilliantly created. This is an excellent addition to an iconic franchise.

Amazing - A Darker Version of Star Trek but the cast does really well and the story line is unique to the franchise, Patrick Stewart has not lost his touch at all.  If your a fan of STNG - you will particularly like this series
The destruction of Star Trek continues.

I've been a fan of Star Trek since the late 60's. I enjoyed TOS, really liked TNG, loved DS9. Voyager was not too bad and Enterprise was getting really good when it was cancelled. The TOS and TNG movies were good. Then came Discovery, a show that makes no sense and that ignores everything that was established before. When Picard was announced I was really happy. At last we would have Star Trek again. But we did not. We got more Discovery nonsense. Did the writers ever watch Star Trek before? And the constant swearing! All of the previous series clearly established that swearing was a thing that disappeared in the 21st century… Borg do not die in the vacuum of space! Picard is not even the central character. There really is just one word to describe this series: stupid.
This is not my Star Trek. I was giving the series an honest try but after episode 9 I am done. This is a disgrace to Data's legacy and Star Trek as a whole.
This show was more then I could have asked for.  Patrick Stewart returning as picard is great but I'd love this show even with out him...must watch
Star Trek: Picard is a fresh new entry in the Star Trek universe. I think it is very action-packed, and Patrick Stewart shines as Picard. An amazing show.

Star Trek Picard Has Completely Betrayed Everything the Star Trek Universe has  Stood for, What is wrong with the Writers nowadays, Star Trek is Destroyed Gene Roddenberry would be Ashamed to see what has Happened to what he Created and how it has Been Destroyed..........They don't want to stay true to anything just get something on Film so they can have a Paycheck....

If I were rating this as just any old sci-fi series, completely unattached from all other series before it, I'd give it three stars. It's pretty bad in terms of story and plot holes, but pretty great in terms of effects and actors. Overall: mediocre.

But if I am rating this as "Star Trek," and part of the history of series and films with that same name, it's totally rotten. All Trek that came before is the toilet paper with which the current writers/producers wipe. Sad what they've done to this universe and these characters from past series. Oh well.

creators of this show probably never saw an episode of Star Trek, or maybe they did and decided to go exact opposite direction, both cases, show does not resemble Star Trek in the slightest, VERY disappointing

Growing up watching the-runs of Generations, it's nearly impossible to not feel excited and just good watching Sir Patrick Stewart return to one of his legendary roles. With plenty of cameos, a compelling story, and stunning visuals, I'm enraptured every scene. While the overall narrative includes rescuing a damsel in distress, the formulaic single episodes could be dull, if not for the show's charming cast and excellent writing. I can't wait for the finale and season 2.

The show where everyone is out of character, including the setting. It's an attempt that is some what in the right direction, but fails with poor writing. While it looks nice on screen, it's obvious that the writers have little understanding of science fiction or well thought out plot writing, it's feels like 10 hours of tv that could have been done in 2-3 hours. The action scenes are utterly boring as there are no stakes. It does have a few good moments, but is ultimately let down by everything else.

It's a great series.  I am a huge TNG fan and they nailed it.  Sure, it's loaded with fan service, but it's not gratuitous.  It's missing the Klingon element for sure, probably one of the best qualities of TNG, but not the only quality.  Fans of Data and the Borg will love this show.  TNG eps like Descent, The Best of Both Worlds, Datalore, Measure of a Man, I Borg, and the film First Contact are must-see before watching Picard.  I also recommend Voyager's "Scorpion" 2-parter (easily the best Voyager story ever) and the film Nemesis (not the best movie but this was the last time we saw Picard and it ties into the new show in several ways).  Throw in the Romulans, Star Trek's #2 bad guys, Seven-of-Nine from Voyager as a bad-ass Neutral-Zone ranger, and you have a winning series.

Terrible, terrible excuse to take JJ Abrams' already antithetical-to-Trek "universe" and make it even worse. The writing has no tension, no payoff, and no respect for character backstories other than passing "easter egg" references the writers seemed to have shoehorned in an attempt to one day generate Facebook clickbait quizzes, their most likely day job. Beloved characters are reduced to caricatures, the plot is meandering and pointless, and there are so many holes within what little narrative framework actually exists that conflict ultimately doesn't matter because it will be explained away with a flashback or usurped by a hokey cameo for distraction. 

The acting is solid for the most part, but the actors have nothing to work with. Patrick Stewart could read the phone book with the same passion and at least that would have a logical narrative flow, but here, speeches are canned, corny, and ultimately just time wasters between the next lens-flare CGI shot of lost Buck Rogers and Battlerstar Galactica fighter castoffs. Maybe this seems smart to the casual viewer with no investment in Trek's history, but for fans of Star Trek, it's just more self-referencing, smug throwaway garbage in the same vein as the last two motion pictures. As bad as it was, Discovery was MUCH better, and sadly, that is no compliment. Trek fans deserve MUCH better.
If the creators call it Star Trek, why are there so many inconsistencies with the series?
Well acted , good story line - keeps the interest - just like Star Trek of old
The worst of the new CBS All Access Star Trek shows. So poorly written, with characters you don't care about on an adventure that seems to be going nowhere fast. A huge missed opportunity.
Amazing!!! When you think that is impossible to do a much boring and slow plot you are wrong. They can do it.
Really good, a little slow but very enjoyable!!
Too much slow, unraveling psycho-drama than good sci-fi.

This series is phenomenal so far and as a fan of ST:TNG It's refreshing to finally see a Star Trek series continue with stories and adventures of a familiar and beloved character with Jean Luc Picard.

Picard is not nearly as bad as some reviewers make it out to be.   Episodes 2 through 5 did drag a bit and I can understand how some could be turned off during that stretch. 
Episodes 6 - 8 are far more entertaining and worth the trek (pun intended).   I'm happily entertained with Picard thus far unlike ST Discover which never built any interest for me despite watching 1.5 seasons of it. 
Perhaps ST Picard is not the best sci fi show...or even ST show... but it is still worth watching.  Don't let the full on haters scare you off.

Edit:  I dropped a star.  After finally finishing the season, ST:P ended up being mediocre.   The overall flow was inconsistent and the ending was cheesy and awkward.  I'll probably watch a second season, but have tempered expectations for it.

This series has been fantastic!  I was not expecting the show to have such great acting, character development, and plot (and sub-plots).  However, with Patrick Steward being such a great actor himself and knowing he takes his characters and their story very seriously, I should have known that this might be something special.
Do not let the fact that you have to sign up for CBS All Access to watch this series.  That actually is what turned me off at first. However, I gave into temptation, and I am glad I did. You will not regret it and like me will be hooked right from the first scene in each episode!  Enjoy guys!

I've watched all the originals.  While you can't compare all of them together as they are all separate story arcs,  Picard is able to Tie up on many loose ends that we never get any closure from.  It is nice seeing old cast from multiple shows appear.  Overall its enjoyable and a little nostalgic to see the old returning crew plus a few extras along the way.

Slow build up leading to nothing. Writing feels very, very dated especially when compared to shows like the Expanse; totally different league, watch that instead and thank me later!

Gave the show a chance at the start to iron out acting/pacing/story problems, but it just gets worse and worse. The story is so, so weak after a really good 1st episode, again when comparing to The Expanse which has a gripping story running through each season Picard feels like the writers really dont know what to do.

Total waste of Patrick Stewart and a decent budget. Sad
So boring. Nothing is ever happening. Mostly boring talking sitting down
A great drop in quality and storytelling; bad referencing of previous star trek's.
Really bad. A waste of everyone's time
This is exactly how to continue a story, it's so amazing. Love seeing the gang again.
Great story and excellent character development.  A little slow at times, but overall a refreshing approach.

Just not great. Stewart is amazing, but everything else is the complete opposite. 

Blergh.

Whilst the series starts out a bit slow, the intrigue that made Star Trek becomes clear. The introduction of characters difficult to understand, only to slowly add details on their histories and backgrounds with the motives behind their actions makes this a show that has you on the edge of your seat from the beginning. The introduction of old characters who has their histories continued behind the scenes, giving us an up-to-date presentation of them is heartwarming, to see these beloved characters develop as we'd want them to, and not just stuck in simple scriptwriting.
Not enough Star Trek and to much Alex Kurtzman

Picard is the only show that I hate watch. It doesn't feel like Star Trek, it feels like a 2 hour generic sci-fi movie spread across 10 long hours. Takes three episodes to get a ship to ya know... Trek around the stars. Two back to back episodes where nothing happens. The cold opens have suicides, mass murders, and utter violence rather than letting me get into episodes before showing me the gore.

This feels like sitting around talking. Lots and lots of 2 people talking in a metal room. 20 - 30 minutes of it in single episodes. It's an utter struggle of boredom. Everything is so poorly lit that it all blends together. The Borg cube is dark, the hero ship is dark, the only thing with light is Picard's Chateau that they bring the Chateau with them when they finally take off for space. The Chateau is a part of Earth and doesn't feel very Star Trek, but there I go hoping for a new Star Trek and then when it's given to us it's spent on Earth the first few episodes except for a Borg Cube that's just sitting there for the season struggling to exist except for to be part of a Romulan plot to show villains discussing villain things while trying to not have sex together despite being brother and sister. Yeah... you heard me.

People smoke, people drop F bombs, people drop hints of cash and money in a time where Earth did away with that sort of thing. I can understand when it's civilians, but did the Federation give up trying to hold its people to a higher standard or did the writers just forget that the Trek Universe is to be a higher standard? People with big houses complaining it's a hovel. Tacked on scenes where a character tries to reconnect with her son that she was too busy for despite never hearing about the son before. There are plenty of these side stories that don't really go anywhere, but every character seems so haunted by their past or just a murderer.

Another flaw with that Borg cube is that it struggles to have a place. One character is just on a Borg ship for two episodes away from the cast. No one seems to want this character back despite knowing exactly where he is and Picard knowing him since he was a boy, he doesn't seem to rescue him. Speaking of one character on the Borg ship, another member of the cast starts out on a Borg ship away from the cast and she seems to be the plot, to rescue her, only she gets rescued and then there's nothing at stake. The plot fizzles and it feels utterly pointless. Previous Star Trek series have single episodes where they come up with solutions that save planets and save lives. 

There seems to be a Federation without actually having a Federation beyond an admiral and a commodore. Everything you knew about Trek is just wiped away. The Federation won't help the Romulans when their sun goes super nova, a thing that can be predicted centuries if not millennia in advance. Picard taking all the blame for not helping the Romulans enough when he was the guy helping. The show loves to harp on that.

The biggest glaring problem is that if you aren't invested in this 10 episode storyline it turns into a chore to watch. Even they forget the storyline which revolves around saving a girl who is a dead comrade's daughter. Once she is safe, nothing happens. The drama ends and it turns into a holding pattern of fluff. It's tough to watch Picard struggle with lines with his age, that I pray is a character quirk and not the real Patrick Stewart struggling.

I feel like there were two strong episodes, the first and the halfway point where everything felt like it paid off, but I can't tell if I felt it was good from watching 3 or 4 hours of dull television or if it was actually good. There were hints of episodes that felt like Star Trek where a space crew would go off to a planet, land, do things, and then leave, even if they weren't saving the world or entertaining me.

I'd love to feel that this was a great show because I love Star Trek and that's the only reason I keep watching. Most Star Trek series have bad first seasons, but I felt like this was an awful chore to sit through. Now I love hate watching Picard or I would have given up on it a long time ago like so many other dull shows or bad science fiction shows.

Loving this season. Don't let the haterz put you off. I'm a long time (40 years) Star Trek fan and this show is great Sci-Fi, drawing on and extending the canon and ethos of earlier shows in a way which draws on the best of modern TV possibilities and sensibilities. The building pace is entirely appropriate given the subject matter - a mystery being unfolded by an older person gradually regaining a sense of purpose. The use of previous cast members has been masterful, and the new cast members are a wonderful ensemble.
Amazing! All the feels for a TNG fan, with an amazing cast of new and old characters! Must see TV!

Just engaging enough, but light years away from the intelligent episodic storytelling of the series that preceded it.  This is a woke revival filled with vapid and contrived writing where villains resemble characters from Lord of the Rings, duplicitous women rule the Galaxy, and male deaths are disproportionately high.

I find Picard to bring us back a good story with the characters I missed so much with special effects and acting that makes me shiver
Love the show and it makes me want more!
Finally, Startrek has teeth.
Star Trek:Picard , is elegant and full of memories.

This is NOT Star Trek and this is NOT Jean-Luc Picard. WTF is with modern sci-fi TV writers feeling the need to make everything "darker and gritter" instead of giving us something hopeful to aspire to? This show just sucks so much and it kills me. As a lifelong TNG and Picard fan I know this show needed to be fresh and new, but it just throws EVERYTHING that made Star Trek special out the window. Shame on everyone writing and producing this show.
Im so dissapointed with just about everything about this series. The writing is garbage and the story is just a big mess that has nothing to do with Star Trek. This is not Star Trek.

This show is a masterclass in contrived writing, non-existent character development, and overproduction. The characters seem to exist only to advance the recycled plot device from Discovery season 2. For example - the Rikers are written a son who dies of an incredibly rare and incurable synthetic disease. It just so happens it was only incurable because of the synth ban. All of it feels like the writers just needed to add the backstory so that Deanna could say, "Real isn't always better." Hey writers - really obvious plot devices aren't always better. 

The pace goes from overly slow, drawn out, and uninteresting - to overwhelmingly fast. For example - we get what feels to be about 20 minutes of Picard pining about Data - juxtoposed with 30 seconds of Elnor trying to help the borg and hue dying. It all happens so fast, there is zero emotional weight or connection developed between Elnor, Hue, and the audience, and then it all abruptly ends. Until next episode - where again 7of9 arrives out of nowhere and within about one minute of screen time - everything is resolved. I imagine the writers felt it was quite clever when they had poor naive Elnor duped by the caricature of a Romulan villain into an "open" fight - only to have Hue die as a result. The lack of build up and time spent leading the audience into what should have been a powerful moment of character and plot development, leaves us with a wham, bam, thank you ma-am...all flash no substance scene. 

In general, the dialogue is clunky and uninteresting. Jarring use of expletives is thrown in and completely fails to accentuate any rising drama or stakes within the story. What the writers do instead, is just piss off their loyal fan base that has kept this franchise afloat for over 40 years. Perhaps the writers could have some care in not alienating their core fans and constantly finding ways to flip the bird to trekkers.

The use of holographic technology is clunky, gets in the way of the actors, and just makes them look awkward on screen. We lose any tangible connection between them and their ships/consoles. Overall the production of the show feels like the love child of JJ Abrams and Michael Bay. Lens flair, unnecessary use of zooms, pans, shaky cameras. It's impossible to even feel like you are in a scene because the camera never settles. 

This show is an absolute train-wreck and tragedy, especially considering there are very strong writers like Kirsten Beyer in the room. Is this show an example of too many cooks in the kitchen and comprises made left and write, so what we are left with is a jumbled together mess of a story? I never thought I'd watch this show and find myself saying - ok, that is enough Picard. The character, universe, and story are so uninteresting I'd be fine if they never bothered to continue it. What will it take for some good science fiction to hit the small and big screens? 

The last episode was so difficult to watch, with the juvenile dialogue and plot development I had to pause it and write this review. I also had to create an account just to write these.

If the showrunners are going to bother giving us a Star Trek show with interesting characters, character driven plots, and well written and executed stories - just stop.
Outstanding drama. Best scifi I've seen in the in years.
Great show it's good to see Picard back in action.

Yarn inspiring.
Love this show! Haven't enjoyed a Star Trek this much since Next Gen.. !

Very bad. This is to anyone else who is going to "try" to make a Star Trek show in the future. If you are going to make a show about Star Trek please at the very least watch the real shows these are based on. There is so much continuity in the Star Trek universe that this show ignores or contradicts.
Picard, much like Discovery, is written by people who have absolutely no respect for what came before or for the core fans.

I find it to be a compelling story for the character of Picard. The writing in this series is a departure from TNG to be sure but I believe that it's a natural progression for a character who's become disillusioned both with age and with an organization that he dedicated his life to that he feels has betrayed its tenets. Not only is it a joy to see Stewart back as Picard it's refreshing to see the character in circumstances that are less than Starfleet, as well as getting to rejoin the crew of the Enterprise D/E at later points in their life. So far I've waited for each installment with baited breath and will continue to do so in the future despite what internet naysayers have to say about the series.

This is not Star Trek. It is even not Picard. How can a beloved character like Picard walk away and not talked to someone for over twenty years. He abandoned his first officer, his friend?
Why is everyone smoking and vaping in the 24 century? You would thinking by now humanity would know inhaling toxin in your body is bad.
I had high hopes for this series but it is letting me down. What the heck is happening to our beloved sci-fi?
I love Season 1! I think the story is interesting and the characters well developed. It is a serious series!

Story line goes against everything that is Trek and is is about as far away from Roddenberry's vision as it is possible to be.  

Scripts seem to be written (in the loosest possible meaning) by people that simply either know nothing about Trek or, at worst, actively hate Trek.  

I do not care for any of the characters, I cannot even remember the name of the ship, and it's just utterly depressing.  

Simply awful
Great show! All that I loved about the old with enough new to keep it compelling and intriguing.
Trek at its ABSOLUTE BEST!! Patrick Stewart is giving the best performance of his career and benefiting from the best show writing Star Trek has ever seen!!!

Average 2020 series, in other words shallow, poorly written, set and shot and simply putting all 2020 memes in a blender and hit spin... sheer f'ing hubris haha
very interesting series and stewart is brilliant in the role
A very different start trek to TNG, set in a less optimistic world and delivered less episodically. Character driven with a strong storyline.

Boring and rushed. Did not feel like a Star Trek show. Wasted air time with characters we care/feel nothing for. The rabbit looking Romulan being passed as handsome is a joke and the Commodore's ears are a riot.

I would suggest viewers to watch ST:TNG if you want to see Picard's character and the Star Trek universe lore.
Poor... must be using writers from the CW!!
Very different from the usual Star Trek TV series, more gritty, more real, more character development. There's swearing, there's blood and guts and so much more emotion. 5* from me.
Bad writing, characters, camera work. Feels like a money grab side project
I don't know why people are hating on this. I have been a fan forever and this is a fun adventure. At least it is not Chibnal writing it!!

Don't expect to see Star Trek: The Next Generation because you'll be disappointed (although there TNG references that keep the shows connected).  This is a beautifully written, beautifully acted story about an aging iconic hero who is reckoning with his mistakes in life and resolving not to let those mistakes hold him back from living any longer.  Like each Star Trek series iterration, it took a few episodes to establish the other characters and their relation to the story. Once those relationships were somewhat established, the story could take off and it has.  Highly recommend.
Great Star Trek Show
Making a disspointing Star Trek series is an achievement in itself
Fun explosions in space but very little to do with Star Trek.
It wraps you and bring you to the Final Frontier. Once you start to follow it it is difficult to leave wondering about the Federation ideals and the fight for justice!
Great slow burn drama with old friends and new fresh faced crew members. Different from other Star Trek series in a good way.

Cheap gore, paper-thin characters, scenes made entirely from Shutterfly stock, lack of appreciation for human life, magical spells...this is nothing more than pornography.  Most damningly, it's not even very good pornography. 

In the very first episode, they tried to bring in some enlightened ideas. Those are promptly forgotten, the story is instead a celebration of the most base instincts of humanity triumphing over reason.
The android/Romulan love affair is almost unbearable. I'm hoping she will stop bemoaning her lost humanity and just get the story moving. We'll see...

it is very poor.
