They really destroyed picard here.

This is another abomination.  This is not Star Trek.  This is the exact opposite of Star Trek.  I'm hoping that Picard wakes up and realizes he was in an alternate universe, that it was all a bad dream.  Why Hollywood hands the reins over to talentless creators who hold our beloved mythos with utter contempt I don't know.

It takes special effort to make something fronted by Patrick Stewart turn out this bad. We were sold on the promise of a thought-provoking, intelligent show more in line with the old 'Next Generation' Star Trek. What we get is a shallow story stuffed full of meaningless action lacking any nuance or reason to engage emotionally with the characters or story. Problems are almost always solved by violence. And while the caricature villains are certain to be killed off you can rest assured that the equally cartoonish heroes always get away scot free. Digging up the corpse of ST:TNG to squeeze this garbage out of it feels almost offensive. All in all a sad end to an influential show.
It's VERY slow and portentous (done in a pompously or overly solemn manner so as to impress). I'm not enjoying it a lot but it's a must watch for sci-fi fans.

So after refreshing my memory with all star trek series before Picard started, it's just so badly written, i have to wonder how the characters are so stupid? How is 
Picard so stupid? Why have character pop in for 3 mins not really adding anything to the story...it's terrible, just been watching it to see what happens at the end. I need a palette cleanser like the Orville.
I have watched star trek for four decades. Up and downs. I find this series tedious and self-referencing. I can't get myself to watch it. I tried. I am quite surprised by the positive reviews.
The writers and directors have clearly never watched an episode of star trek.

This show is a disgrace to Star Trek and an insult to Gene Roddenberry's vision of the future. It's not even just bad Star Trek it's bad Science Fiction TV. The plot and dialogue is the worst part and embarrassing to watch. The story is all over the place and the actors lines are bland and they can be cringe inducing. The characterisation of the new characters is abysmal and Picard is weak and hollow, he has hardly any charisma or style, he's just a depressed dying old man not the proud, strong and charming Captain that he was in TNG. Nothing much has happened to him since Nemesis to make him so bitter and down, his character is not believable here. The show has no fun or passion in it and the dumb writers have created a convoluted story which damages canon and disregards many aspects of pre-existing lore. The Federation is portrayed as an evil dictatorship and Starfleet are a bunch of mercenaries now. The show has no joy or optimism. The writers and producers have made a bad excuse of a science fiction show and just slapped the name Star Trek and Picard on it for prosperity. This is not Star Trek and disrespects Gene Roddenberry's creation. His utopian, Intelligent vision of the future has been replaced with a dystopian, dumbed down vision full of sarcasm and swearing. Some of the acting is painful and Patrick Stewart's performance is lukewarm and his portrayal of Picard is just like Xavier in Logan, tired, frail and hopeless. Everyone talks down to Picard and he needs others to do everything for him. The show is slow and after the first episode it is a meandering bore until episode 7 and even then it's still dull but seeing two old friends of Picard in the episode is a welcome sight. The few TNG characters you see only get brief scenes and hardly do anything it's such a waste of some great characters. The music in the show is good and the bits of Jerry Goldsmith you hear is great but it makes you sad because it reminds you of good older Star Trek and you realise how much potential this show had. The visuals are decent and good CGI but every ship is Kelvin-verse design and the lens flare and camera angles are annoying. Overall this is the worst Star Trek I have ever watched and one of the worst science fiction shows in years. Star Trek Discovery is better than Star Trek Picard and Discovery was not very good at all. Terrible show.
A disgrace. With horrendous, badly written darker, modern tropes masquerading as a Star Trek show.

Dark, dank, and depressing. This is not Star Trek. It's not even fun to watch. It gleefully celebrates in literally torturing characters (some beloved from previous Trek series) and ignores Gene Roddenberry's optimistic view of the future. Sure, Picard himself is still an optimist, and as genuinely a good person as always. But he's surrounded by series regulars who murder, drop F bombs, and try to numb their problems with steady doses of hard liquor. Graphic violence is jarring. In a recent episode, a character has his eyeball pulled from his eyesocket, which is shown in excruciating detail. My daughters freaked out. Then, another character sees no alternative but to kill the poor guy on the spot to end his suffering. Later, the same character murders someone else in cold blood. This blatant, matter-of-fact graphic violence and acceptance of horrible morals have no place in this franchise. Star Trek used to be something a family could enjoy together. I have been a Star Trek fan since The Original Series, and Picard is perhaps my favorite fictional character of all time right next to James Kirk. So you can imagine how difficult it is for me to rate Star Trek: Picard as rotten trash. Disney has it right with Star Wars in that it has not stooped so low as to produce material that a family can't watch together. Poor decision making and a rejection of optimism and emotional intelligence will doom Star Trek in the long run.

The problem with Picard is not that it's "different" from TNG. The problem is that that "difference" is often implausible, badly narrated, and inconsistent with the foundation from which it tries to depart. As with every TV show, Picard too has to be judged by the basic metrics that we all want to see in a good show: Does the plot offer a compelling and logical story? Does it perhaps even present an original idea, and does it deliver a satisfying end? Are the characters believable and authentic? Are the values and ethics consistent with what we know about Star Trek and the relationships between its protagonists fleshed out? Is it visually appealing? On all counts but one Picard is a complete and disappointing, nay utterly insulting, failure. Where it doesn't fail are its special effects and sets. It's true strength, in other words, is in delivering a slick and exciting optical package that detracts from its deficiencies. All the while, that which made Star Trek one of the greatest franchises ever created--SUBSTANCE--is flushed down the toilet. This show couldn't be further away from real Star Trek. It deserves to be quickly forgotten and forever buried in the graveyard of bad TV entertainment.

I have a high-end surround system with a Dennon X4100 receiver, 5 top-end speakers with a center channel for vocal audio, and an SVS SB3000 sub woofer, and with any of the CBS series the audio dialogue is so poorly engineered that half can be clearly understood. This is my third time editing my review because this show has been all over the place. There were a few aspects I liked, but there was so much I hated. This is one of those shows you can't think about too much or you'll realize the plot holes, the things that made no sense, the characters that just vanished, the fact a handheld "magic" deus ex machine saved the day. There was so much cringe, I was embarrassed to watch this with friends, and I don't think anything happened to redeem it's self. The appearance of Captain Riker came close, but then again he was leading a fleet of 200 copy and paste ships. How lazy and unimaginative. The second to last episode uses a bunch of re-purposed Shutterstock footage. There was some intriguing ideas and they did "Kill-off" Picard which was bold, The final Data stuff, I was like eh, ok not really necessary but it's fine. My final thought is that it diverged too far from what we know Star Trek to be. Had it diverged and been better than old Star Trek, I wouldn't have complained, but it was not even close. I will say that one thing we definitely don't need is a TV-MA Star Trek. It's not working. I don't really care much about the crew, so I'm not really interested in a season 2.

Though a lot of the hardcore trekkies don't seem to like this show, this is an excellent for us Trek fans who don't pay quite as much attention to the minutia. If you haven't seen it for a while, make sure to go back and watch the Star Trek: Nemesis movie before you watch the series -- it'll give you the background info you'll need.

Ok Picard dance.  I don't know how to teach someone how to write a good story.  But this isn't it.  Seven of Nine without a latex suit? Ok we've evolved beyond that. Boom boom shoot em up. Add some colorful graphics give a geriatric a sword and presto, a series.

This is NOT Star Trek! The writers clearly have never watched or liked Star Trek. Picard goes from being a strong captain who everyone respects, to someone that is ushered around, disrespected, and abrasively spoken down to. He's useless! How many lives were saved by Picard in his career, thousands? When is Picard going to act like a leader again? When will someone respect him?
The characters and dialog are beyond  terrible. For example, Jeri Ryan returns to the series, where she randomly runs into Picard out in the infinite universe. Even though the meeting itself makes no sense, this presents an opportunity for discussion about the transition from Borg to human. Seven of Nine asks Picard if he feels human. Picard answers "yes." What a deep philosophical discussion! A one word answer. Jeri Ryan was wasted by poor writing, and no wonder she mentioned panicking about the role in a podcast, and that the character was "slangy" and "not Seven." I tend to trust Jeri Ryan's grasp of the character more than the writers who likely never watched the original show.

The writers seem more content with fluff long their own egos with empty political points that fall flat. The use of contemporary language, slang, and swearing is just embarrassing for Star Trek. We have an elf cutting a head off with a sword, and the graphic drilling out of an eyeball. The changes are a total regression, and the passage of time is no excuse.

Star Trek was once about an ideal version of the future, where poverty, hunger, etc are eliminated. Instead, the series attempts to be "dark," a total regression from Gene Roddenberry' a vision. 
I would like to cut Patrick Stewart some slack, since he was fantastic for many years as Picard, and he's nearly 80. It's not easy to do anything at that age. Unfortunately, his best acting days are well behind him. He's extremely slow with his lines, and seems content to destroy his one strong character.

Needless to say, I am beyond disappointed with this series! Nothing will fix this beyond hiring totally new writers, it's clear that it will never work "as-is."

This is Star Trek as Tarantino might do it... far more visceral than the normal surgically clean Star Trek.  Gore abounds as dead Borg drones have their implants ripped from them, and the lack of concern for life shown by some characters is a change from the usual slightly preachy Star Trek north star.
In the latest episode we visit a Mos Eisley style cantina - only hinted at previously by Quarks bar on DS9 - but the kind of place you have to imagine would exist in any real universe - but never does in Star Trek.
Keep it coming guys - outstanding fun...
Is this show actually going to get anywhere?  I'm fine with slowing down a story to build your characters, but they aren't even doing that.  This show is 75% filler and 25% TNG callbacks.

Horrible. A (nowadays) typical corporate move. Afraid of putting out something new they put a known name to something completely different. The show has nothing to do with star Trek: its premise has been overthrown. Star Trek fictional hypothesis was that of an humanity evolved not only technologically, but also ethically and morally. Forget about that. Humanity here is victim to its worst instincts, characters are not deemed interested if they are not thorn by remorse and overridden with guilt, just like dungeons and dragons backstories invented by thirteen years old kids...Sad. Very sad.

I'm a little disappointed, actually. I loved Picard in TNG, But watching him play the lead character role now is a bit like watching Betty White being tackled on a football field. Age has caught up with the actor and it is a bit like watching a doddering old man meandering around then a heroic figure out to save the universe.
Wow, what a disappointment

I haven't seen such thrilling Star Trek series, since Deep Space Nine(just a matter of preference), and I'm glad I can see JL once again, I mean, everybody have to admit there is something special about Sir Patrick. So, all in all, I really like this show
An almost perfect opening episode. Building it's story each week, with strong performances and solid storytelling. Looking forward to each episode.

People who say "this is not Trek" really need to get over themselves. There's room for all kinds of Trek, from the Utopian TNG to the darker examples like Deep Space 9. The problem with this show isn't how "Trek" it is, but that it's mostly slow and plodding, with characters that feel like I've seen them before, even when they aren't going for the nostalgia factor by bringing back faces we've seen before. It all feels very cliched and derivative. Still, the acting is top-notch, as expected, and I'm holding out hope that the show gets a more solid footing, and doesn't need to rely on overused tropes as much, as the season moves along and the show finds its own feet to stand on.

Absolutely awful. Full of tired tropes, IKEA set design, and pacing like its a British murder mystery on BBC at 12am, I have no idea who the audience for this show is. 

Shame Patrick Stewart himself can't rescue it. He seems as lost as his character is.

This show disrespects Gene Roddenberry's vision.  What happened to humans moving beyond greed, want, & suffering?  That was covered in the first few episodes of TNG.  There's no hope or humanity.  And why all the "F" bombs?
A little disppointed to be honest. It appears to be very drawn out and more like a mini series. The story is interesting and the acting good. Just speed it up a little.
Bit of a slow start, but the show has been fantastic since it got rolling.  A return to true Star Trek form as it's meant to be.  Intelligent sci-fi.

This isnt Star Trek.

I dont think it would be such a terrible show if it didnt try to steal some shine by calling it Star Trek and try and drag people in with well known characters. if it were set in a different universe eg. Babylon 5, or better yet Firefly, it would be much better.

I really do not like this version of Star Trek and I do not know how it has recieved such positive reviews. They swear, murder pointlessly and paint the federation and humanity in a negative light instead of a hopeful and advanced set of civilisations. It is a step backwards, Picard is a weak old fool and the canon just isnt followed at all. I had been waiting to watch this for the last year only to be sorely dissapointed by each episode. Killing old characters who the audience liked in pointless fashion is really a finger up at the audience. I am done with the new Star Treks

First of all I'm a huge fan of past Star Trek series since my childhood, even Enterprise, with The Next Generation being my favorite of them all. For reference, I pretend ST: Discovery doesn't exist.
Watched 3 episodes of S. Picard and all I can say is: Everything I liked when watching adventures of the  crew from the Enterprise D isn't present in this new,now generic,  sci-fi mess.

This is not Star Trek and this is not Picard.  This is generic Sci-Fi dreck.  The uplifting and optimistic message of Star Trek has been erased.  Instead we are shown a dystopian society that is xenophobic and isolationist.  All the shows characters are deeply flawed in the most contrived ways imaginable.  Science, compassion, and knowledge has been replaced with senseless killing and treachery.  The writers have tried to make a poor imitation of the Expanse and have come of widely short of the goal.

What's worse the show isn't very good.  Where the Expanse is compelling, Star Trek Picard is not.  We are five episode in and I don't care about the story or any of the new characters.  The pacing of the show is widely inconsistent.  It constantly changes from creeping along like a snail to completely manic.  Many of the plot devices are complete nonsense.  The Romulan Tal Shiar wasn't nefarious enough for this show so the writers came up with a even more "Secret" secret police the Zhat Vash.  Apparently the Romulans have some deep hatred for Synthetic life which we've never explored in any other version of Trek.  I'm guessing the story will unfold that the Romulans somehow create the Borg.  That or they just stole the playbook from Mass Effect and the Romulans had some long forgotten war with Synthetics.  Somehow the Romulans have managed to make the Federation complicit in this nonsense and Synthetic life is now banned in the Federation.  So much for all the progress we saw made with Data in TNG and the Doctor in Voyager.  

The few characters that we know from previous shows are nothing like we remember.  The Picard we meet in this show is nothing like the man who Captained the Enterprise.  Captain Picard was an extremely competent, commanding, highly moral man.  This "JL" that we follow in this show is a broken, frail, helpless old-man.  We are supposed to believe that Jean-Luc Picard gave up on mission to rescue the Romulans because he ran into resistance from Starfleet Command.  This is the same man who argued against Starfleet in Measure of a Man to secure the rights of Data.  This is the man who defied Admiral Haftel in Offspring to protect Lal from Starfleet.  This is the man who stood up to Admiral Satie in Drumhead to protect the rights of a half-Romulan crewman.  This is the man who arrested Admiral Pressman in the Pegasus when he illegally developed a cloaking device.  Clearly Jean-luc Picard is a man compromises his morals and gives up whenever he encounters resistance from above.        

Good work Star Trek Picard.  You tried to reinvent the wheel and came up with a triangle.  Good luck, forge onward in complete incompetence.

Not true to the originals at all! Throwing source material and lore out the window like its last weeks lunch. The writers of this show either hated the old star treks or never even watched them! I have no idea why this is so highly rated with critics its not better then a 60% at best.

A great start to a much loved franchise. Watching old characters come back in a more violent adaptation makes it more exciting.  The Borg were always a violent race, so the visuals should be more graphic.

Destroys everything magical about Star Trek and replaces it with the same moody depressing conspiracy garbage found in any current drama. Legacy character motivations make no sense and the plot is so predictable a child could see the twists coming.

I am loving the show. So glad it took a new turn and is a character piece for Picard. It really has departed from the same old, same old formulaic Star Trek. Michael Chabon is one of my favorite writers. He writes excellent character driven stories that won him the Pulitzer Prize for fiction, and that type of writing and character development comes through in each episode like a peace to a larger puzzle. It really is much more interesting to see Picard battle his demons and face his regrets and atone for them than just throwing him on another star ship. 

The series is very close to Batman The Dark Knight Returns in which an aging, retired hero must return to bring back balance and stand up for what's right while fitting into a world that defies him and doesn't really want him back. The character and his beliefs are pushed to the extreme, corruption of Star Fleet (Government) are pushed to their extreme. 

The series isn't for those who have a short attention span or for those that don't like a slow burn build up of character development. I see a lot of people say there's so much talking (that's plot and setup). Also ohhh it goes no where....I watched 2 episodes and I don't know everything that's going to happen yet. That's because seeds are being planted to develop later on, that's what good storytelling does. It's unfortunate people are so quick to dismiss something that doesn't have an instant payoff and takes it's time building a solid story.

Life long Trekkie and someone who would listen to Sir Patrick Stewart read a phonebook.. Disclosure - I hated Discovery! But Picard is terrific and to see Stewart take on his Signature role as Picard is a must-see in my book. I'm glad they returned to the Prime Timeline for this series.
love it keep seven of 9

It's all the tricks of the superhero movies with none of the heart that made Star Trek great. We have no character development and nothing to tie us to the story line. Heavy CGI, martial arts, and space battles were never what made Star Trek compelling. It's inexcusable that after 5 episodes, I know nothing about any of the characters except that their miserable about the state of the world.The producers just keep cashing in guest appearances and directors, trying to generate some nostalgia which might make us watch just one more episode. Not sure what you're going to do when you run out.

For anyone saying that Star Trek can't be done well anymore, just watch the Orville. I would have never expected Seth Mcfarlane to better emulate Gene Roddenberry than Alex Kurtzman. I guess after the disaster of Discover, I shouldn't have been so surprised.

Star trek Picard is good to watch for loyalty sake only: 5 episodes so far and the characters are either lost, confused or schizophrenic. 

After Star trek Discovery, the bar was high and Picard is way below it.

Drama for the sake of drama. Very little substance, uninteresting characters and dubious choices about the plotline. Confusing to the point you start wondering if the things that are clearly either mistakes or setups will be ever used again by the writers - or will they be forever forgotten. Many inconsistencies in the story as well, not mentioning the characters that you may know from the previous series are portrayed completely differently here. Boring world and storytelling - not worth watching so far
This is not Star Trek.

Abysmal.  Bad writing and poorly coached acting. The main thing that ALL ST producers have to realize is that your old formulas don't work.  After STNG Brannon and Braga kept up their old schtick and that hurt everything.  With Jonathan Frakes in the directors chair you are guaranteed substandard 'directing'.  The writing is just bad.  This series will not survive.
Not star trek sorry, maybe if it was actually good i would be more forgiving but this is a terrible show.

As audience critics say - slooow plot line, mish mash of pulling in some ex Star Trek actors, special effects overdose with no particular point. I took Amazon Prime for this - but will cancel membership, not worth it. Glad I can skip 10 seconds at a time until next relevant plot line is revealed. I suppose all the old hands who made Star Trek great are not working on this, or, if they are, have jobs as go-fors, Very sad to see ... (who are the prodessional critics? Paid lackeys?)

First off, Die hard Trekkie here. I've seen every single episode of Star Trek to date including discovery and all the movies. That being said although it's truly exciting to see some of my favorite characters come back on the screen included Brent Spiner and Jeri Ryan so far I'm not all that impressed with the screen writing and plot of this slow moving series. We are, to my understanding half done with season 1 and I feel like it hasn't even gotten started yet. Also the killing off of Icheb was completely pointless and really bothered me for some reason!! So we'll see if we get more back story on that other than the garbage presented so far. I had such high hopes for this show so hopefully my opinion will change with the coming episodes. (not likely)
This show is Trek in name only. It destroys the utopia dream of Star Trek and is nothing more than a soap opera in space.
This is not Star Trek. Star Trek inspires and gives hope this doesn't.
5 chapters into the series the show is still boring.

Dystopian, post-war, post-catastrophe Star Trek. It follows in the footsteps of Discovery, trying to be edgy and dark, with strong elements of JJ Abrams Trek. There are elements here that are interesting, but poorly executed, and a host of anti-Roddenberry themes like a Federation that seems to have lost its values and is increasingly isolationist and racist and bigoted. Stewart is a good actor, but he's written here as a sad, woeful and self-flagellating version of Picard which feels utterly wrong. Combined with the uncaring, isolationist Federation, and - by episode five - where Seven of Nine returns as a kind of angry freedom fighter (similar to the Maquis, but "Ranger"), and her mercy-killing of Icheb who has been captured, broken, dismantled without anesthesia, this doesn't feel in any way like Star Trek. Pacing runs from manic speed to iceberg slow, the known characters are warped dark versions, the new characters are angry and bitter, too many storylines are mashed together in a piecemeal way, and the backstories are all angsty and load blame for things on Picard. It's just not enjoyable, nothing seems earned on an emotional level, and the disjointed plotting makes it impossible to like any of the characters. It's just awful. The only purpose in torturing and killing Icheb was to give Seven a reason to revenge-kill a former lover (female, btw).  A scene between a new female character and her son is loaded with guilt and angst, blame and anger for "abandoning him" but I don't care because nothing has been built up to induce me to care. Romulans here are galactic refugees, some are friendly and others enemies, and there's tons of thickly laid guilt on Picard's side for "failing them" with loads of anger and hate on the Romulans' side... but it's never explained how the Romulan Empire couldn't evacuate/save themselves. Woven in to this mess are threads about Data having "daughters" who are like sleeper agents, some weird Romulan mythology tied to the Tal'Shiar (or an even more secret sect within that group), visits to random edgy dark planets to pick up a new character or save Maddox - who, by the way was an old TNG episode character who tried to have Data ruled as property so he could take him for experimentation. All of this just feels greasy and unpalatable. Bits of an easter egg here and there try to bring nostalgia, but it's nostalgia for a show that was better, brighter, and hopeful compared to this awful, hot mess.

So wanted to love this show. Not a trekkie but watched TNG every week. Even through the bad episodes I always returned to see next weeks adventure. I have given this 4 episodes before basically working out its not for me.

So lets get the good stuff out of the way.
- Visuals
- Nostalgia

Rather than give a big list of things that I dont like I will tell you why I tuned in every week to the original TNG. 

- Interesting stories
- Compelling balanced characters.
- When visiting political topics try to give a balanced view from both sides and let the viewer decide their own opinion. 
- Looking at Star Treks future it filled me with hope.
- Fun/Levity

I don't think Star Trek: Picard does any of the above for me. Im happy some people like it but for me its a no.  Like I said so wanted to like this!!
Can it be any worse?

Dam!! There are some tough critics here. Don't get me wrong, there are some issues with the show. I may even agree with a few of the criticism I've read. I personally don't think it deserves a 1 star, It may not be a 5 star, but it's watchable. Don't be a hater. If you are a fan of the franchise, pleases support it. Hopefully, they'll continue making more shows.

This show simply tosses everything that made Trek unique and charming out of the window only to replace it with a depressing mirror image of 2020 politics.

Like many tedious sci-fi shows these days it has a message, not the same positive message of hope that we saw in TNG where humanity has cast off it's ugly past and learned to transcend racism and inequality, but rather it presents a misserable mirror image of the political and economic issues that exist today.

It takes a huge leap back from gene roddenberry's whistful vision of the future and absolutely tares apart once beloved charactors.

Picard himself seems to get torn a new asshole by every person he meets, regardless of if their friend or foe. Throughout the show you will get re-united with charactors from Treks rich history... to simply watch them die. Oh and it's established very early on that picard himself is on his last legs.

If you were to look at this as if it weren't a part of the Trek universe I would describe it as being mediocre, slow paced and somewhat boring. 

Save yourself the time and dissapointment, if you want to watch a show set in a dystopian future that is stylish, engaging, and has decent charactor development watch Amazons "The Expanse"

Saw the first three episodes during the free 7 day trial for CBS All Access, had no desire to pay to see the rest.
The plot and dialogue are a mess, and the characters are lackluster.
I feel like I'm watching one of those old late night syndicated shows from the 90s, like Time Trax or War of the Worlds, with a really bad attempt to add a layer of grit and with a somewhat higher budget. I like gritty, but dropping completely awkward F-bombs and using completely out-of-place slang is...it's like that scene in Airplane with Barbara Billingsley, only repeated several times per episode and not because they think it's funny.
I gave it a chance, I just don't care for it.
It's an embarassing pastiche with no soul, even worse than Discovery, which means a lot! If you love Star Trek don't ruin your memories of Jean Luc Picard, stay away from this one.

The camera work and the storytelling is shit from the get go. The timing is done in a way as if it was to be akward on purpose and the characters explain everything trice. The overall story would have some potential. But  I could see that the show sucks in the first episode. Camerawork and pacing doesn't magically improve over on seaseon when it is filmed in one go. How should it? I have never watched a show that bad. I am only watching it because it's Star Trek. But it pains me to see Patrick Steward's talent wasted. Even he is sub -par in this show. He's old now I get it, but it's the directors job to make up for his age and use it. Instead they make him seem obnoxious and out of place. The costumes are OK and the CGI is bad but I can live with that in a TV series. But the cutting, writing and most camerawork reminds me of "The Room" way too much. It's a bad show.

After a somewhat promising (although boring) start this has turned into unwatcahble garbage. Patrick Stewart is too old for his role and apparently can't act anymore. The writers can't deliver a good story. It's just cringy, forced and distateful.

I enjoyed the first episode.  Wonderful to see Picard again.  But that's it.  I've now watched the first five episodes and its just wasting my time.  The second and third episodes are filler.  By the fifth episode I'm really starting to hate the show.  And its not even that they ignore all the things Star Trek was about--they have money again, gambling, prostitution, etc etc.  All supposedly things that humanity have evolved out of in previous series.  But its BORING.  The characters are dumb.  The action is not well shot.  People's motivations aren't well explained.  Ugh.  I guess the 7of9 actress did a good job, but that's probably it.  I think I'm out.

I'm biased because it's Star Trek and I love the franchise, but Michael Chabon is doing the series and TV in general justice by portraying this rag-tag, down-and-out band of adventurers trying to claw out a scrap of justice in a nuanced and dramatically darker version of the shiny, post-scarcity Federation universe portrayed in previous incarnations of the franchise.

If for nothing else, one should watch this show for the fact that Patrick Stewart is being given an opportunity to bring to bear all of the talents his classical training as a Shakespearean actor has provided him. His portrayal of Picard's transformation from a weathered and defeated optimist to a reinvigorated champion of the disenfranchised and threatened stands on its own, and is supported by a cast that makes Picard feel like a classic Greek epic.

Great production and well acted, but very slow....waiting and waiting for something to happen but keeps disappointing.

Was hoping it would improve and fulfill its potential but gave up after Ep 5.     Long slow saga that tries to survive on seen-it-before CGI and name brand, but in the end it doesn't work.
1st episode was good enough. Every other episode is simply terrible. Don't think i will continue to watch it.
A slow build up to some interesting stories and development of what Picard has done for Romulan and cybernetics
This show should not have Start Trek in the name.

I love this show. They are doing a great job of telling the story
of Jean Luc Picard after his life in Star Fleet. Great new charters 
and legacy charters.
This is sooooo bad. You are ruining Star Trek legacy...

This Star Trek started off great, loved episode one. Then it quickly had become a spiraling dark path of less and less hope.  Add to that Legolas and a katana in space and the ability to suspend belief is getting tested.  This last episode 5 has almost eliminated hope and good feelings. I actually don't want to watch this anymore and I love Star Trek.  It's no longer about escapism, it's just a reflection of the ugliness of reality and it seems very little is being done to actually being the possibility of something better. I have a little hope the season will get better, but for now it is just depressing.
Even Patrick cannot save this one, but there is always hope for better season 2.
A waste of time that should not have been made. Destroyed Canon, characters, theme, setting and everything it touched.
Completely agree with the Rotten Tomatoes consensus. This series departs from TNG in ways that mirror the current state of the world. Very timely.

Three episodes in and I already hate it. This bitter Picard hurts my inner Trek. What happened to the Prime Directive Loving Picard? He would have let non-Federation planets die in the past but now he throws away everything because of Romulans???

Picard is back ! With my love of The next generation it's definitely carrying over to Star Trek Picard. Visually amazing 😉 Love the storyline and seeing all the old characters back on screen ! Truly one of the best surprises on tv in ages for me ! I just hope this show stays for as long as possible ! 

Must see for all fans of Star Trek! Common it's PICARD !💪💪

Not your father's Star Trek. 

Keeps the cast interesting and neat, actually gives them a backstory and a reason for being there (not just copied and pasted into the same roles on a new ship), doesn't just bam into existence and actually has some good little mysteries going on. Production values are through the roof and aside a few teething issues, it's all very good telly. Some nice nods to established Star Trek lore. It's good to be back in the universe. Thank you cast and team!
All I have to say.......JLP enough said
The biggest issue I currently have is the first 4 episodes could have easily been 2 episodes. It's frustrating since there's only 10 episodes this season.
Gefällt mir gut!  Mal ne ganz andere Art von Star Trek...
Worst Star Trek series ever made..... it's close between this and Discovery.... But Picard wins it for me.

Well i've tried, more expanse style which is not bad but which is not star trek at all.
No real use of the star trek universe only for mandatory easter eggs which are useless. completely illogical and too grim. 
it seems that all that have been accomplished before is gone. all the evolution of mankind gone now it looks more like out present days with all the politcal issues. 
absolutely not star trek !
Sadly, I have to agree with others here. This is not Star Trek.
this just fundamently not star trek
Outstanding Patrick Stewart is at his best
Excelente serie, mejora con cada capitulo, muy recomendable.
Absolutely NOT Star Trek, this is Anti Star Trek. It is poorly written and borrows heavily from other franchises. Meh science fiction at best, Star Trek is dead, CBS All Access killed it.
Really bad plot and no real Star Trek atmosphere and continuity with this universe at all. Dissapointed.

Just like any other Kurtzman Trek: Zero regard for canon and continuity, uses Discovery ship and shuttle models in a show that is set post Nemesis. The one original design of the show looks like something straight out of Mass Effect. Just like Discovery, a generic dark sci fi series that has nothing to do with actual Star Trek.
Just like Discovery, it's just badly written sci-fi drivel that they have stuck the Star Trek name on, even though it bears no resemblance to the Star Trek universe.

Poorly acted, cringie scripted. Reminded me of the jj abrahms action/disney crap, with some sprinkels of 90thies  power rangers dialogues.

Wanna see something less cringewhorty? The orville and the expase are the way to go.
I'm sorry Patrick, but JL deserved better than this popcorn crap.
Fantastic. Come on Sir Patrick!

Surprised at how much i enjoyed it, beacuse it's so different, I tuned in thinking i was getting more of the same and was taken aback by how much i like how different it is. Thoroughly worth it. How they've made an old favourite new and fresh is brilliant. Totally hooked and cannot wait to see where they go and how far they go.
This is the best TV sci-fi series I have ever seen in 10 years. Just can't wait for the next episode!!
What is all the rave about!? So far I find it boring, lost, over-complicated, and Piccard too...forced.
Love this show. Patrick Stewart is amazing

I watched 5 episodes of Star Trek: Picard
She is so bad
I have no words to describe
I love the show runners' take on this classic Star Trek character. Long live Picard.

If you can look past some of the very few parts that might bother you, you'll get to all the parts that are very wonderful. This show is well executed and Patrick Stewart is at his best. Truly superb addition to the Star Trek universe, and as a huge fan of STNG, this is exactly what the Dr. ordered!

This show is brilliant! It is not the episodic Trek of the past. The entire season is one story arc that is superbly constructed and delivered. For me this hails back to Babylon 5 which told one story over 5 seasons. Patrick Stewart is flawless as Picard delivering valuable reminders of what we humans should be. I'd give it 10 stars if I could.
Loose the foul language and this could be a better quality show. Foul language = foul thinking.

If you've been looking for the Star Trek that became a global phenomenon and endured for more than 50 years, the Star Trek that depicted humanity as having evolved beyond pettiness, greed, and violence - keep looking. This ain't it.

In the first five minutes, a half dozen people are shot and stabbed. Every scene thereafter is a painful reminder that everything which made Star Trek unique and successful has been stripped out in favor of violence, sarcasm, and selfishness.

See, in Star Trek, characters speak to each other with dignity and respect. Even the bad guys spoke with observable self respect.

Turn on Picard and you'll see Starfleet officers dropping F-bombs like it's an audience blitzkrieg, superfluous action sequences that add nothing of value, and not one character who can refrain from aggressive sarcasm for more than a few seconds at a time.

And the pacing. Good God, the pacing. In 4 hours of content so far, we've spent about ten minutes in space. On a show called Star Trek. And at the end of each episode I find myself wondering:
Who is this show for?

It's not for people who love Star Trek, that's for sure. Theyve stripped out the peaceful co-existence, the mutual respect and understanding, and the evolved humanity trek fans expect. Now it's just another violent science fiction series with swords in place of solutions. And no one grew up loving Star Trek because the decapitations were just soooo cool.

And it's not for people who don't like Star Trek as evidenced by the plodding dialogue that's thick with Star Trek jargon that no one outside the dedicated fan base understands.

So, who is this for?

Well, it seems like it was for the CBS executive to pin their hopes and dreams of becoming Netflix upon. And that ain't happening.

You know what sucks most of all? A buddy of mine plays one of the lead roles. He does a great job. He deserves writers and showrunners that care about the franchise beyond watering it down for greater profits.

The story arc is a wonder to behold. Much darker and subtlety plays important story points. Having an interesting set of cast members will allow for a new breath of fresh air. Bravo Patrick Stewart!  You still have me enthralled after all these years.

Picard has gotten old and his acting isn't what it once was, but you can't beat the nostalgia or character building on display.

In addition to accomplishing a fresh take on the final frontier, it is successfully staying true to the original themes and character. State of the art effects are amazing. I expected to see more of Number One, (the dog), based on previews. But clearly not a necessary element.

Let's put our frustration of Kurtzman-era Trek into a different context.  Imagine a different timeline, where after the lukewarm reception to Enterprise, Star Trek went on its hiatus, but a different company made an offer to continue the franchise.  SyFy channel, having found success with Battlestar Galactica, was given the reigns to create a new Trek series.  Since modern Star Trek dictates that you can have significant historical changes and the present still turns out the same, Discovery and Picard then still come into existence, just not through CBS.  

Now, anyone who has ever watched SyFy channel productions kind of knows the feel of their content.  Not even Battlestar Galactica was immune to their brand of dark, hokey science fiction, full of science magic and interpersonal drama, with questionable acting and writing at times, even if it was ultimately considered a success for the network.  It would be easy to imagine that if SyFy produced Star Trek, that we would see something very similar to what Alex Kurtzman and his gang have managed to come up with.

Would I be frustrated with Star Trek if it were on SyFy?  I don't know.  I think I would still be frustrated that they don't have faith in the viewers to still want an intellectual and positive portrayal of that universe as we've previously come to know.  But I also think I would just accept that anything on SyFy channel is going to be of a certain production quality, and manage to enjoy it for what it is.  I did manage to go through the entire BSG series despite a lot of really slow periods of space politics, after all, and still come out of it with a generally positive opinion.

My frustration is just that this is mainline Star Trek.  CBS is charging us a subscription fee, on top of showing us ads, for something that is really not at a production value that we expect.  If you enjoy it, then I'm happy for you, but there are many of us who have a hard time accepting this rather low-brow level of storytelling.  

The show creators can say what they want, but I don't feel the profanity is necessary.  I don't think space vapes are necessary.  I don't think all the personal drama is of any relevance.  I don't think the action scenes are particularly exciting.  I don't feel anything for most of the characters, and even have a hard time associating Patrick Stewart as being Jean Luc Picard; most of my interest has mostly involved his housekeepers.  There is seemingly endless exposition, with a lot of junk science, and frankly just bad writing.  Combine that with graphic violence, particularly killing off a past character in a gruesome manner, in seemingly a spiteful retribution for a real-life disagreement with the original actor, to prevent him from ever being in the show in the future.  It's just petty.

With that being said, somehow this show is still better than Discovery.  That shouldn't be taken as a compliment, though, because being a step above garbage doesn't exactly put you on a pedestal.  Discovery's second season had some of the worst writing I've ever seen put to screen, with essentially no character development, ridiculous science that they should be embarrassed about, and endless drama between characters that I have no emotional attachment to, resulting in empty and pointless storytelling.  And yet, Picard is still better.  Barely.

We're essentially half-way through this show and almost nothing has happened.  It's a sad production for what was an amazing actor and character.  And I think it's rather mind-boggling to think that Patrick Stewart even rejected the initial pitch.  How bad could that version have been, if this is where we ended up?  Or better yet, why are these same people allowed to continue turning Star Trek into this insultingly bad franchise?

We want Star Trek.  We will happily pay for Star Trek.  But as many others are saying, this is not it.  This is shockingly bad, and brings genuine doubt into the future of Star Trek.  CBS will undoubtedly blame the viewers for its failure and put it on hiatus again, rather than accepting responsibility for hiring a bad team and trying to do it right.

If this is the best you can do, you can put it on cable with the rest of that dying industry.


UPDATE:  It's over.  Thank goodness.  What an unmitigated disaster.  What a waste of film.  What a waste of time.  What a waste of potential.  Ten episodes where nothing happens, where the writers forgot their own plot, where you find yourself asking "Wait, what?" between nearly every commercial break.  Ten episodes of hyping a situation up and then completely dismissing it with some cockamamie conclusion that made it all moot.  Killing characters left, right, and center, desperately trying to force some kind of emotional reaction in the audience, and failing miserably every time, even when that character is Picard himself.  The only emotion I feel is disdain for the creators.  You failed, and you failed hard.

I really enjoyed Star Trek TNG and TOS.  I enjoy and respect Sir Patrick Stewart.  I'm on the 4th episode and I will probably give up on the 6th if the series doesn't change. Remember the hope and wonderment that TNG brought to audiences.  We wanted to "boldly go where no one has gone before". This Trek has few cohesive story elements and instead of individual story's typically not dependent on the others this is a soap opera.  You must watch each episode to understand the episode that follows.  Picard is broken, old and regretful in a narrative that is far different from the captain we know and love.  It's out of character and sadly leads us on a path that isn't transformative as much as it is mundane.  Star Trek draws people in with hope, inclusion and a resolve to never sacrifice values and principles over hatred.  I've watched Discovery and what a mess that was!  I gave up simply because it to echoes the poor writing of Picard.  Scenes slip back and forth in time and Starfleet is a generic governmental mess concerned with being isolationist and boldly going inward.  This is not Star Trek it's CBS and make no mistake about Kurtzman's poor understanding of Star Trek. 
The CBS app has little content, poor controls and was programmed by someone who hasn't looked at other superior streaming platforms.  I have to watch it on the CBS app in the U.S. which just adds to my misery.  I hope in a galaxy not too far away we will once again find the optimism that made Star Trek great.

I really find the series to be a compelling continuation of Star Trek: the Next Generation, updated to reflect 21st century sensibilities and production values. There seems to be a very vocal minority upset at the "darker" tone and alleged "woke" agenda, and while there are certainly prominent strong female characters and obvious nods to current real world events, I find them completely in tune with the spirit of what Star Trek has always been about and never ham-fisted in their delivery. Some might chafe at the steady pacing of the show and relative lack of action, but that also carries over from the tone of the Next Generation; action was never the point of the show and in particular for a serialized show such as this, it's actually welcome to let the show take its time. Highly recommended!

I have watched the first three shows in its episodic format but last night watched all of the 3 - the first 'act' - in one go cutting out the intros and recaps, etc.  Contrary to the comments made by the more negative reviewers some of whom criticise the lack of pace and others saying too much was crammed in I found the first three episodes to be well paced and set out a clear narrative of where 2399 in the Star Trek universe was at.  Yes, piecing together the flashbacks and the comments made by the characters was at times challenging and there are many mysteries and leads to be followed up but surely that is the whole point of thoughtful sci-fi?  Many of the episodes of TNG were relatively slow and thoughtful and they concentrated on one issue and searched for a resolution.  The difference here is that across 10 episodes you can deal with more (as well as catch up on the 17/18 years since Star Trek Nemesis).  I have no problem with the series not being based on a starship called the Enterprise.  DS9 was an excellent series based a space station central to the galactic politics of the day.  Whether people like it or not Star Trek Picard does move the timeline forward and we see the alpha and beta quadrants in some distress following the events of Romulus and Mars.  The portrayal of the powers that be in the Federation and Starfleet is not necessarily bad and they clearly still aspire to being utopian societies but clearly confidence has taken a knock.  Again, the events of the previous 25 years with the Dominion War would have also had a devastating effect on the morale and confidence of all the species in the alpha and beta quadrants. So well done to the writers for very carefully thinking through what the galaxy of the Star Trek Universe would be like in 2399 and setting the scene for Picard to re-emerge from retirement and save the galaxy once again! I can't see how that in any way conflicts with the optimistic tone that was set for Star Trek by Gene Roddenberry all those years ago.  It relates to today in that as everyone has said we can't just sit back and assume the world will get better.  We have to work at it and as a result we have to hope that the world will get better.  That's the point of good sci-fi and certainly Star Trek. Well done again.

With the exception of the title character, it's sometimes hard to tell who the cast is or will be. But 3 episodes in, Picard has done a wonderful job of building this era of Star Trek. It's also introduced several intriguing new characters and set up an interesting story, filled with mysteries. And the people behind the show are writing the big checks, so the show's production values are amazing.

Most importantly, Patrick Stewart is back and is still wonderful.

His dialog is just a beat too slow, and definitely over delivered. I get that this is intentionally an older Picard who is making his way out of retirement, but the tottering old gentleman element is way overplayed.

Watchable if there's nothing else, but this is not a great show.

Fake and plastic. With such a budget and such actors, how can you possibly screw it up this bad? I mean, watching 1 episode of Wesley Crusher playing soccer on the Hollow Deck would've been more interesting to watch. Evil AI? Romulan farmers who suddenly created American farming values ? Cigar smoking in the future? Living in the desert and vaping? Mental Institutions? A 1920's movie could've reached this point. What annoys me the most is the way this story is presented, so damning self important and dull. No humor. No ideals. No progress. No sense of improving ourselves as humans. No exploration of our emotions or ideals of what makes us human. It seems stuck inside some dull emotion of a 12 year old. It only makes me tense and want to vomit from the warm milk which is being poured down my throat.

So far I really like what I see with Picard. It's a drama, which is new for Trek, but it still comes with its fair share of action. I also like that they went with a linear serialized storytelling instead of hopping around between storylines that Discovery did.

Three episodes down and "has it started yet?" I am just waiting for a character I care about - too may one dimensional pretty people with pointy ears and wild eye brows. The writings all too cautious apart from a weird sprinkling of the f word - why bother or is this just the writers getting over-excited by using a swear word? Patrick Stewart is solid but too many soulful speeches and moments of reflection from a character that seems to have evolved into Old Father Time. Not what I was waiting for but maybe it will improve. Please say, "Make it So".
It's lame. Picard is too old.
I'm not a big fan of the serialized Star Trek. Aside from Patrick Stewart it just doesn't have the Star Trek feel.
It's not star trek. Even though it is better than discovery, it still isn't star trek. The way people speak is wrong, the whole 'the federation is evil' idea is just garbage.

I'm a rabid Star Trek fan since the sixties, but I have always preferred TOS and the movies that spraang from it with the original cast. However, Patrick Stewart brought class to the role of Jean-Luc Picard and much of it carries into this series. But his age is beginning to show and it makes this a rather creaky portrayal, at least to me. The first two episodes were just so-so, but I expect it to improve with each new episode. So far, I much prefer Star Trek: Discovery.
I feel like i am being spoon fed by a bipolar ADD scriptwriter. OMG my brain is melting.  Please what happened to great writers an directors.

I'm 3 episodes in and now I just don't care to watch anymore. Trailer for ep 4: Picard: "Will you bind your sword to my quest?" This writing is garbage. 

And another thing: he explains who Commander Data is to a woman who is going to be a Fellow at the Daystrom Institute. Data would be famous enough in science circles for her to know who he is. Super clumsy exposition.

This is Trek for a 21st century audience. All the people whining that this isn't a clone of 1980's TV aren't being realistic. We aren't going back to the 1980's/90's, people. No more listening to Rom scream, "Moooogie!". No more Captain Proton and Arachnia. No more Paris and Janeway turning into salamanders and spawning. No more Crusher doing the space ghost. No more Quark in drag. No more "Oh noes! The holodeck is broken!" episodes. No more Q and his mariachi band. All of that is done. That ship has sailed. They just aren't going to do Trek like that any more, people. Let it go. Move on.
Outstanding. So happy to see this incarnation of the epic Next Generation storyline.
Since was the Federation filled with isolationists and racists who don't care if a whole species is annihilated? What happened to Gene Roddenberry's hopeful future?
I wanted to believe..... they fail again....
As a very long time TOS and TNG fan, I could not get into this show.  It was sad and depressing.  Picard always saved the day in TNG but not in this show.  Its just I hate the galaxy over and over.

A fabulous series for any Star Trek fan, but especially for Next Generation fans. Picard has been a character of great complexity since the beginning of the series in the 1980s, and here, seeing him so fragile and yet resolute in his convictions is exciting.
Star Trek Picard is just superbe !
It has had a great start
Rich stories, deep characters, worlds filled out, spies and assassins. Watching it gave me goosebumps.
Everything I hoped it would be. It pleased the fans and brought us back into the Star Trek Universe 18 years later as time had never passed at all. I'm all in and engaged.

The writing is severely lacking here. I get that the show runners want to take Star Trek in a new direction and i am all for that, but in order to do that, you have to respect what came before. Picard and Discovery suffer the same problem, in that they start from a completely unrecognisable point. Abrams' Star Trek was mediocre at best and CBS had absolutely no reason to try and tie Picard into that timeline, yet they attempted to shoe-horn the whole Romulan Supernova into the prime universe when they simply could have ignored it. The result literally wipes out half of the map that Star Trek spent 50 years drawing.
The first Episode is OK in terms of plotting and pacing - There's a mystery that needs solving and Picard is the man for the Job, but there are several signs that the writers didn't do their homework. Jurati states that Synths are outlawed by "Galactic Treaty". Galactic? Did Senator Palpatine sign off on this? Wrong Franchise. The federation occupies a very small corner of the galaxy so, unless they sent ships to every planet in the galaxy, I think not.
I know this is nit-picking but it is very telling that the writers don't fully understand what they are getting into.
Episode 2 was just bad from start to finish. I can suspend my disbelief when an Irish Actress play a Romulan whio now lives in France. She's a talented actress and her accent doesn't get in the way of her performance, but to exclaim "Cheeky Feckers", an Irish slang term, was just nonsense. If anything, The Romulan (Alien from another planet hundreds of light-years away) who now lives in France could easily have uttered something in French and gotten away with it. Cheeky Feckers was a choice made by the actor and the Director should have shut that down on the spot.
By all means Star Trek, Explore brave new worlds but try a little better to make it look like you know what you are doing.
Patrick Stewart is always great! This adventure is right up there with The Mandalorian! Must watch!

The dystopian star trek does not fit with Picard, this show is all visuals no substance. Dash is a unrealistic character flying around and jumping like shes from the Matrix. This show is garbage, new Star Trek timeline is garbage.

Its Awesome. A must see for the 21st century trekker

Edit- Looking back lol no
This show has something for every type of trekkie whether you're an old fan or a new one. It has great balance between all the new stuff and the things we love from TNG. It's a must see for sure!

If you're a fan of summer blockbuster action films and never particularly cared for Star Trek, you might like this show. If you're a Trekkie, stay away. It's always nice to see Patrick Stewart as Picard again, but very little else about this show feels like Star Trek. The writing and plot are just as lazy and paralyzingly stupid as anything in the JJ movies and almost as disrespectful of canon. I'm only sticking with it for the Riker/Troi cameo.
He had me hooked after the first five minutes. Looks like it's going to be an amazing show!
Somewhat entertaining. Star Trek in a dystopian society. Apparently, Picard (or JL) has been wallowing in self-pity for 15 years.
Great premise, good fun, good twists, familiar faces

This show was written by people who have no understanding of Star Trek or basic astronomy.  Why does the Federation hate the Romulans?  They were writing peace treaties with them at the end of Star Trek: Deep Space Nine.  Having the Federation be evil is stupid; it undermines the optimistic Science Fiction theme that is displayed all throughout the original 5 Star Trek shows which set them apart from other Sci-Fi.  How could Mars explode?  The atmosphere is about 95% carbon dioxide, so you nothing would ignite on the surface.  Supernovae don't just happen; Stars give signs that a supernova is eminent years in advance.  If you are a Star Trek fan, you will not enjoy this show.
A fresh take on the Star Trek universe that is faithful to what came before.
I think the show has started brilliantly and is an excellent contrast to the fake Star Trek show that is called Discovery!
Brilliant - I've watched the first two episodes and the show shows immense promise. It has all the elements (even a creepy shadow of the borg) ..I am looking forward to seeing where the story goes.

It started off with great promise but quickly fell victim to the hackneyed writing of contemporary SF. One woman character--Seven of Nine--has her own motivations. Picard is less the captain we recall and now someone everyone (for unknown reasons) views as either a fool or a charlatan. The character development devolved quickly and now nobody is likable. Picard acts less wise and more like a teenager when he isn't being treated like a frightened old fool. 

Lots of violence towards senior citizens depicted; lots of disrespect of the elderly. Shameful what they've done. It started with a strong premise and is now gone straight to Hell. Once Deanna Troi started scolding, I turned it off and canceled CBS All Access. This show is not worth your time.

I would say that after the first episode I thought this new Trek iteration looks promising.  A little slow to build but that's to be expected to set up the story line.  HOWEVER, after Picard sits down with the Admiral in episode 2 and she drops the F bomb--with my 4, 8 and 11 year old watching--I was turned off.  The M rating is one reason why I'm not interested in Trek Discovery and for some reason the producers seem to think an M rating will result in better ratings?  Not for me and my house.  If they cleaned things up a bit to give it a TV14 rating I could give this a 4 star rating.  But watching a Trek show shouldn't be like watching sailors talk.  This only distracts from the show and it's sad that they've decided to go this route for such a once great franchise.  Picard himself even looks a little out of place with the Admiral's remark.  You would never see him speak that course in any previous Trek.  Sad.
This is fresh, updated and compelling! Star Trek at it's best!

Surprisingly good. I think too many Trek fans want this to be a show like TNG or DS9 and it's not so they're disappointed. And a lot of people were bashing this show before it even came out. The saltiness on youtube is real lol. But unlike Discovery which is trash, this feels like a Trek story to me. Patrick Stewart is great as usual and the story so far is gripping. Approach it with an open mind and you'll probably like it.

This Star trek show is excellent! Definitely the best Star trek I've seen since TOS because unlike TNG it actually is action-packed! And the story is great and leaves you wanting to see more.  I have been waiting for this for so long I don't understand why they couldn't produce a Star trek like this sooner... Patrick Stewart is a shining star, he embodies Picard exactly like he did during TNG, it's as if he never stopped playing that role.
I like it a LOT! wanna see MORE!

1.5 just because I miss Patrick Stewart as Picard but it's obvious already that this show is not going to change the direction of modern Trek, I have to wonder if our generation is just a symptom of stagnation, our creative community is just not as talented as gens past or we rely to heavily on crank it up mentality like JJ and effects or in your face yet unaware political lectures, gone is philosophical exploration episodic trek.
I'm happy that even though this is a trip down nostalgia street, it was deemed important to have a good storyline, and great writers.
I actively groan as I listen to the dialogue on this one...  (Loooooved Next Gen, this is not that :-(

I love this show. It is everything I was hoping for and more. I have only seen the first 2 episodes(3 comes out tomorrow), but am very excited to see where it goes. There is a lot set up,and we haven't even got to the appearances of the tng and voyager cast that are returning.

Love the new series, Patrick Stewart is brilliant and at his best, cerebral, ethical, a man of reason with a deep sense of justice. Love the pacing, prefer this to endless serial chapters of Jordi tweaking the deflector dish or rerouting plasma conduits to ward of the bad guy of the week.

There's nothing new under the sun. But if you're going to bring back Jean-Luc Picard it needs to be something grander and more out of the box than this. At least TRY for more originality. So far it's Bladerunner and I, Robot. They literally pull I, Robot off the book shelf and make a quip about it. Might as well hit the audience over the head with it while it's in her hands. But it's still a joy to see Patrick Stewart back as Picard so I'll keep watching. 

I love good action, but slow it down and delve into the character to allow Stewart to shine. The best scene so far is Picard being interviewed by a reporter. No more long, ominous monologues from obvious villains. Isa Briones is great so far as well. Stick to the characters, let the action come naturally. No one's going to read this, but what the hell. Gotta vent.
No complaints. Absolutely incredible.

It does not have much to do with Star Trek, except for the name. The federation is not the actual federation, the decades long canon has been thrown away. Plot holes, illogical behaviour of characters are what awaits the viewer.

Horrible. I'd like to think of a kind word, but this misfires on all cylinders. Patrick Stewart is a fine actor, but he's wasted here. Writing, casting and directing share the blame.
Cool cinematography, but I don't think this is their best work

It's an odd watch for sure. There's plenty of familiar names and locations but none of them seem written by someone with more than a passing knowledge of Star Trek, making the whole show feel like watching a parallel, dumber, universe's version of what could constitute a Star Trek drama if it wasn't so obsessed with trying to seem grander and more intelligent than what the limits of the writers allow.
It is a bit less assaulting than ST:D though (if you can look past the gaping plot holes and ridiculous plot lines that absolutely make no sense in the universe), so I guess that's something.

Update: Three episodes in and the degeneration into ST:D has begun. The show is now mostly comprised of cardboard characters delivering poorly written (and already inconsistent) exposition to the point where even character traits that would normally be used as performance hints to the actors are now delivered directly as dialogue by the characters themselves. Every scene is now also written from the point of the script writer with a complete disregard for what the characters know or might be feeling; if the story demands something, the characters will immediately blurt out that they now feel or think in a way that facilitates it, character or race traits be damned. This is turning into quite the travesty.

I've been a Star Trek fan for as long as is possible. I've watched and loved all series in the past. Each one seemed to be a little better than the last. Discovery was a huge disappointment but I was still hopeful Picard would deliver what Discovery did not. Alas, it was not to be. Picard makes no sense in overall premise or in the details. It's so distorted it bears no resemblance to the last 50 years of Trek. It's obvious the writers don't love trek and haven't even bothered to know it. They make leaps of logic in their story telling and expect you to fill in the gaps. Lazy or bad writing, I don't know which it is. Probably both. So sad. Star Trek has been a family tradition for many people, to be enjoyed with and handed down through the generations. No more hope for the future and something to share for generations to come.
good cinematography. everything else is a train wreck

Its like nobody here had any respect for the legacy of what Trek was and was just appealing to the lowest common denominator. The dialogue is awful (and young adult modern slang?!) and the plotting is filled with lapsed logic and technologies just made up to suit the plot, that are then explained away as non-functional in a later scene when they need that to remain a mystery. It SCREAMS Bad Reboot productions with mystery-box writing and complete disregard of what came before and how any of this works. It is not universe building, it is universe breaking. Again.

Did Patrick Stewart forget how to play Picard cause his maneurism and his delivery is nothing like on the TNG. Other than that it is a reskinned Discovery. How can you have 40 years of advancement in technology and gazillion budget only to do way worse show than the cardboard sets and face paint of TNG? This is not Star Trek. If they want to make something different then don't name it Star Trek.

💤💤💤💤💤. A snooze fest.

There is swearing in it which doesnt make sense and ruins the family friendly theme trek always had. Picard is a dystopian view of the future and of Starfleet that is wholly inconsistent with Roddenberry's vision of Star Trek. Although Star Trek has always delved into politics, they've usually separated themselves from contemporary politics and from taking sides. Not so Picard. It's purely partisan and preachy which will look dated and irrelevant in just a few years. Get rid of alternate timeline Bad Reboot movies and shows and get back to telling real Star Trek stories. If you ask nicely I bet Seth MacFarlane would put the franchise back on track.

I watched episode 2 and then quickly canceled my subscription.  I found the pacing to be really uneven and the leaps of logic to be too far for even the Star Trek Prime universe. Another series that Kurtzman has destroyed. What a disappointment, I have always loved Picard he has been one of my favourite childhood hero's always having the correct and right answer. To se what they have done to him is embarrassing. Why do you have to use the star trek name Gene would be rolling over in his grave for what you have done to HiS Star Trek. You use the name to get viewers but yet ignore any and all canon because you don't have the skill to write anything other then this garbage.

It appears the only disease that cannot be cured in the future is: TDS. For once, I am almost rendered speechless. So, according to Alex Kurtzman, Picard is an old, angry wine-guy in France, Romulans are a band of space-faring vagabonds with Irish accents, and Star Fleet is the root of all evil. Are you kidding me??  How is this in any way Star Trek??? What happened to the optimistic, forward thinking, anything-is- possible-yet-grounded-in-scientific-reasoning Star Trek???? So, the take away from this is that it is not Star Trek. Shun it. Ignore it. It will go away in time and then, maybe, we can actually have Star Trek again, despite Alex Kurtman's best efforts.

Was so excited to see Sir Patrick Steward back in a Star Trek show, 
and then reality struck. It's a mediocre SF show that doesn't have anything to do with Star Trek. What a train wreck.

Second episode in and any remaining hope I had for Trek in this era is completely dashed. ST:P is great if you like mindless plot and no science in your science fiction. 1) A positron is a subatomic particle, the anti-electron, if you will. Makes no sense using it as a centerpiece McGuffin to build your story upon. 2) Putting a positronic brain in a human body doesn't automatically make it capable of super-human feats. 3) There are other examples of misusing technical terminology but you'll probably notice them on your own. 4) The writers don't even know the correct way to use the phrase "ghost in the machine" so I question whether they even understand the source material they're drawing from 5) There's no world building or building of suspense. They only have two episodes out and you already know exactly what's going to happen during the rest of the series. I guess this is a great series if you like having every little piece of the plot fed to you like a parent feeding his infant. 6) The sets and the majority of the costumes could be for any Sci-Fi show. They don't give you a sense that this is happening in the Trek universe.

Best Trek series since the ST:TNG.  The acting is first rate.  I care about Picard (of course) but already care about many of the new characters only two episodes in.  Really looking forward to watching and seeing where this series goes.
Outstanding! He is back. Sir Patrick plays the older Picard very realistic.
This is Star Trek made for people who don't like Star Trek made by people who have no idea about Star Trek.
Not without it's little flaws its still got me engaged enough to stick with it.

Hard to watch. This show is INSULTING to the audience and the action is really pointless. Why do they insist on all the killing? Not only is this show boring, it is cringy and Picard is constantly getting yelled at by others. Also, my is this show behind a paywall? Stay far away from this show.
ugly, We'd better stop the series now, I stopped watching on first episode

How is it possible that only two-thirds of the way into the first episode I can be so upset over the loss of a character?  I just met the character a few minutes ago and yet I was fully invested.  Such is the quality of the new Picard series.  Admittedly, the second episode did not have the same impact as the first, but I am certainly willing to let the show do some table-setting in order to get going.  There are a growing number of open-ended plot lines that are only alluded to.  Without context it is hard yet to fully appreciate the stakes that are being set up. Hopefully these will resolve in the subsequent episodes.  Regardless it is evident that the level of story-telling confidence, acting, and tone is light-years beyond the erratic and adolescent Discovery.  This is a show that promises to fulfill the potential of Star Trek. Engage.
Brilliant Star Trek. From myself a TNG trekker and my new to the franchise wife. Great escapism and moral values. Must see top stuff.

My opinion could potentially change in time as there are presently only two episodes out at the time of writing but I feel I need to vent already.
I'm giving Picard two stars, these are my reasons why.... 

First of all, the writing is generally poor. The show is constantly trying to allude to something but it never does it in a subtle way. The dialogue is poor and it doesn't seem to fit the characters. As someone who is used to the lore and history of trek, all of the characters feel undeveloped and historical and cultural backgrounds completely ignored. Romulans for example have years worth of history on the screen yet we are met with very human Romulans (complete with very human accents). 

This moves me on to my next point. Picard himself feels like a shadow of the noble man we knew and loved from the bridge of the enterprise and even if this is perhaps part of a plot device I'm not aware of. It makes it difficult to watch a programme about possibly the greatest star trek character whom feels nothing like the character we know and love. 

The other issues are part of the way the show has been produced. The vaseline blurred edges of the screen, the appalling editing and the bizarre over the top cinematography (complete with random pointless camera angle cuts) make it hard to focus on the sub par plot.
There is a lack of depth and lack of philosophical engagement that trek and Jean luc the character used to bring to the table and although Patrick Stewart said in an interview that this was a darker trek for a darker world we live in, I believe now more than ever we need the positive, morality seeking, exploration and guidance of Captain Jean Luc Picard.
I like it. The story is slow moving, but I think they are build up to something good. I'm willing to keep watching.

If I were to summarize what Picard is in the current Trek landscape, I'd say it's the TNG to Discovery's TOS. The world of Star Trek Picard feels vast, and full of characters who are more than just a captain or a first officer. Picard reckons with aging and being passed by by the rest of the galaxy. Yet, he maintains the strong moral fiber that has been the core of his character.
There is intrigue and revelations, a new foe hiding among new friends, and it's all very wonderful!
Amazing! This is the Star Trek Series fans have been waiting for since TNG with Sir Patrick back at the helm.

Nice to have picard back.
Not your usual star trek but a very interesting plot. Very good visual efects for a tv show. Does not dissapoint as some people say. Don't understand some negative critics on this show. The only negative point is to have to wait a all week for each episode.

another StarTrek for people that hate it. even as just a random SyFy it's still a dull "current year" slogfest.

I still miss the science-y part, the mystery, and the actual Trek (to boldly go), but a (skeleton) crew seems to be finally forming.

More F-Bomb's, Girls jumping into bed with Romulans, and no real reason to like this. Complicated and contrived, and mix between CSI and a soap opera. Very very sad :(

Only watched the free Episode 1 on YouTube.  I will not be subscribing to CBS All-Access to continue watching this season.
