Star Trek: Picard shares similarities with classic Trek by name only. This show is a far departure from the Trek envisioned in the mind of Gene Roddenberry. What once was a family friendly, episodic "space western" with dynamic characters, optimistic ideas, story telling, and engaging discussion on ethics & culture had now become a brooding serial with uninteresting characters and lazy story telling. Each episode is jam packed with overly complicated plot, boring dialogue sequences, unrealistic characters, and convenient oversights. While the show is generally well acted, and has a polished looked, each episode is generally uninteresting, and has a feeling more of fan fiction then that of a true sequel.
Average I am not sure where this show is going certainly not a patch on Next Generation , the characters were done . Its like watching a retirement show gave up after one episode

Two episodes in and I can say I am disappointed. I don't write reviews or publically comment on shows, but star trek was such a part of my childhood and my life that I feel compelled to in this case. From what I've seen there is no care taken with the narrative or production of this show. It seems to just be thrown together from a collection of loose ideas because there is a general direction to the narrative, but the way it's presented, the sets and the visuals tell me it's was never really scrutinised before they produced it. Like publishing a first draft. 

I get the direction Patrick Stewart mentioned, in that this isn't the world of ST:Next-Gen, this is a Star Fleet that has "lost its way" so to speak, as a commentary to what's going on in the world. I get that and accept that. Sure there are plot holes, but if you've been around star trek long enough you can sort of fill those in yourself with benefit of the doubt thinking. Granted in Star Trek-style they SHOULD be explained with "techno-jargon" that is based in scientific theory or pseudo-science in some cases.

Yet what gets me is the visual style, which seems to be lifted directly from ST: Discovery, set just about a century before Next-Gen and nearly 150 years before Picard, yet the shuttles to get around look like they're right out of Desconvery's hanger. The Enterprise-D has a hull so dark it might as well be made out of steel, making the ship look more like the combat-oriented Enterprise-E, rather than a ship built for peacetime ambassadorial duties . 10 forward looks extraordinarily sterile, dark and gloomy for a place that is supposed to be a place for relaxation and socialisation. The Daystrom Institute scene has exposed air ducts in the background, Starfleet has been travelling the stars for more than two centuries, and apparently, humans have never figured out better air vents than that. Furthermore, from what we've seen of the preview scenes as well as episode 2, human starships are as dark, sterile and gloomy as a borg cube. No seriously, compare the light levels in that borg cube and the scenes of any human starship, if anything the borg cube might have better lighting.

I get it visual style is an artistic choice, and there is a certain element of poetic license with that, but honestly, this is just lazy and slapdash, relying more on post effects, lens flare and light rays to make it seem futuristic and visually appealing. I can't help but be pulled out of my immersion of the story by that those very elements, and when I'm pulled out of that immersion, how can I enjoy a show that already has pacing issues?

A brilliant, bold and deeply completive series that shocks all good Trekkies into a dark chapter of humanity's very likely future with the consequences of the role of artificial intelligence and synthetic life that arises from it -- not to mention the return, albeit briefly, of several former "Next Generation" cast, STAR TREK: PICARD reminds us that although we can never truly escape our past, we needn't be forever haunted by it, and that, most importantly, we can utilize our past to help write a better future.

AS could always have been done in Treks: The best of old — not just nostalgia, hardly just fan service -- but the use of the universe with a new modern shoot of a venerable man of truth and honor in a colder wold, speaking to current events and our fraught times in the best Star Trek tradition. Approachable to any new viewers, lots of fun bits, but always propelled forward in a modern eye. JUST AS PROMISED. And a different tone than all other Treks (and obviously, more settled gestation than Discovery).

The issue with Picard is just one. Nostalgia. People have this nostalgic view of TNG that is so far from the reality that taints anything new they see. I just re watched the first episodes of TNG and if that´s our point of comparison than Picard first episode did just fine. Actually it's better in many ways. In Picard we see a Star Trek for the times we live in. TNG was about optimism. Utopia. It´s the 90's in the end of the Cold War with the fall of the Berlin Wall. But you know what?  No one explained to us how to reach that Utopia. Now we have new challenges to face and a generation that seems to be repeating the mistakes of the past. Perhaps this is why Patrick Steward decided to return as Picard.  We see a character that realizes he can´t just let injustice go by. He can't just sit still in retirement while a new generation faces such major issues. I can see the potential in Picard. I can see how it can become a though provoking series. And hopefully, much like TNG influence a new generation.

I have been a Trek fan since I was a child.  I grew up with Trek, especially Picard and his crew.  I was not impressed with the first season of Star Trek: Discovery, but as that show has improved I have come on board with it.

I was concerned with the pre-release comments that suggested that Picard was possibly going to be yet another release where politics and agendas were being placed above plot - but I needn't have been.  The first episode suggests that the politics will be included in the plot, as was usually the case in Trek's past, and that the story is going to be a logical continuation from TNG.

Sadly, modern Star Trek has seemed to turn its back on the original premise of showing an example of the utopian society that Gene felt humans could work towards creating, which knocks back the star grade a little.  Depending on how that plays out I may have to revise the grade downwards.  Trek was not, and should not, be "depressing, dark and gritty".

The first episode of Picard was rather different than I'd expected and was oddly earth-bound for an installment of Trek—it's still compelling though and sets up some interesting problems for the future. It's good with a lot of potential. 

Overall the production quality was of a high standard though the acting/dialogue was shaky in places. It appears to be akin to DS9 in that it's taking a more critical look at the federation but doesn't look to be trying to make it into an evil-empire. Rather I think it's exploring the notion of how war and unexpected challenges can led people to not live up to their ideals. Or maybe not 😁. 

The new Romulan warbirds are super cool though. And there are some pretty fancy weapons. And perhaps acid-spitting warriors??

I've watched it a few times now, and my non-ruin everything statement is that it's good, but it's so far lacking the Star Trek 'feel' - It has the easter eggs, memorabilia, and of course: Picard himself, but otherwise just 'feels' more like it could be any other sci-fi. Fortunately, that's only episode one... and, an extensive knowledge of Star Trek lore already pays off in pretty big ways: The whole thing is a lot easier to buy-in to if you know Bruce Maddox from TNG - both the episode in which he is most relevant, but also the other contextual dialogue references to him throughout the series. It's not must-have knowledge, but it adds credibility to the goings-on of the show. 

Patrick Stewart is exactly what you'd expect from a retired Admiral Jean-Luc Picard in his 90s; they do a good job continuing the natural course of his character development. I'm not sure how he'd be perceived by people who aren't familiar with the character (especially late TNG/the movies), but he's who he starts to become at the end of All Good Things (the last episode of TNG), and the first time we see him is absolutely 100% a call back to both that moment and also Nemesis (the last time we saw him on-screen) at the same time. He still maintains the natural authority and command presence he's renown for (and it's helpful that, even though he wields no real power any more, he's literally a living legend to everyone), but it's also pretty apparent that he's well past his prime, and more or less has nothing left to live for initially. They've really amplified Picard's moral authority (like you'd expect from a bitter old man), but they've also double downed on his self-doubt, uncertainty, and Picard-style brooding/mourning.

All-in-all, I'm glad it's finally here, and optimistic about how they'll play this out.

Great, great show! Classy, exciting, thought-provoking and incredible acting. Patrick Stewart steps into his role like he never left, and merges well with the original series and the movies. The 1st episode quickly sets the tone for the show and pulls you in. Star Trek fans will have a field day analyzing all the Easter eggs! Production quality is excellent, and so is the story (based on the 1st episode). Looking forward to the rest of Season 1!

Epic, stunning, engaging, and worth every minute of your time. I wait in breathless anticipation of the upcoming episodes. Great effort and job well done to all involved in this new entry into the Star Trek saga. Thank you.

I was uneasy when I heard about Star Trek Picard coming as his character and story are time honoured amongst Trekkies, but this first episode didn't disappoint. The writer and director achieved a balance I could never have expected: a respectful homage to the series/films that were, whilst adding just the right amount of contemporary film elements to bring it into 2020, and finally give Star Trek the budget it always deserved.

This IS Star Trek, but with an Altered Carbon/Star Trek: Discovery budget. I noticed each and every nod to Picard's character history, and greatly appreciated it. The story is engaging, characters were beautifully performed, and the CGI visual update was perfection.  I don't have a single criticism and I cannot wait for the next episode.  Well done to everybody involved.
So far this series is a winner, I know it's only one episode in but this first episode has forecasted a great series ahead, with fantastic connections to NG themes.
Wonderfully written, it is a pleasure and a delight to be able to see Picard after all this time. The acting, writing, CGI and cinematography are outstanding!

This is a vandalization of Gene Roddenberry's vision.  The show plays loose with Canon, forgetting about lore (both in its literal meaning and with regard to Data's brother).  The believeable science based on the Okuda's research into scientific research into real world science is gone.  Science in Picard is just magic.  The first episode is just so mind numbingly boring and the "mystery" of the show is revealed midway through.  No reason to tune into episode 2.  Canceled CBS All Access after the episode ended.

I love Picard. I think it's great, I am a huge star trek fan watch every version from the original, TNG, Deep space nine which is my favourite and sisko is personally my fav captain, voyages, enterprise, discovery and all the movies. This is a great addition.
Wpisowe 1: boring and disappointing. The story is not written well.

I'd have to say, for the first time since I've been watching Star Trek (and I've been watching since the beginning) Captain Picard has replaced Kirk as my favorite Star Trek Captain, and with the new Star Trek Picard, he hasn't really done any Captain-like stuff...yet. (Although I do think Anson Mount was excellent as Captain Pike and they ought to develop a series with him). Patrick Stewart is so far and away a better actor than Shatner (or Chris Pine) that it just goes to show how far great acting can take the whole Star Trek idea to great heights. I'm really looking forward to seeing how this new series progresses.
Great start never touched my phone once while watching it.. completely absorbed in the story.
There comes A time in all actors lives when at a certain age they are propped up like A chimp as in  "Lancelot Link Secret Chimp"  and "Grumpy Old Men" .  This show is a perfect example.

The show is thoughtful, sensitive and yet very suspenseful. It exceeded my expectations in every way. I really liked Star Trek Discovery, and enjoy the Short Tteks....but so far I LOVE Star Trek: Picard.

It is difficult to rate this show.

For a SciFi show it is very good. Good acting, pretty special Effects, good story-telling...so far 4 out of 5 stars.

For a Star Trek show Picard is as castastrophic as Discovery. It shares no values of the imagination of Star Trek by Gen Roddenberry like an optimistic depiction of the future where mankind has defeated old problems. Furthermore there are illogical plot points if you know Star Trek canon....for example why does the Romulan EMPIRE need ships of the Federation to evacuate their homeworld. They have thousends of ships by themselves. Like Discovery Picard pretends to be Star Trek and it fails...so 1 out of 5 stars.

Combined I give it 2,5 out of 5.

Great, no not great, Picard is Back y'all!
What an Awesome start, it felt like Star Trek, it wasn't too futuristic (like some other Star Trek Series). A broken Picard played by the Giagantic Sir Pat Stewart, a great (elder) Data and a Nice looking Isa Brenosa' Dahj.
I can only recommend it,, for you, who likes Star Trek and who wants to watch the REAL Star Trek
Love seeing Picard again and star trek moving forward in time.  Great start I'm excited to see where this leads.

Sono senza parole. Era tanto che aspettavo qualcosa di bello non rovinato dalle mani di JJ. Speriamo che la serie continui così ma, se patrick stuart ha accettato di farla probabilmente sarà tutta un capolavoro. Il trekkiano che è in me gode.

I'm a HUGE trekkie! I love TOS, TNG, Voyager, Enterprise...in that order. I sort of enjoyed DS9. I hate Discovery! Picard is too much like Discovery and not anywhere close to "Star Trek". The creators are trying to constantly WOW you with sets, and "style". Ugg. What happened to creating characters I care about? I'm sad because I had such high hopes when people said it wouldn't be like Discovery, and I'm sad because I gave CBS $10 for this!
Excellent return! Very happy with the pace, the story, new characters and of course, watching Patrick Stewart on screen is just so captivating!

the direction of this show, is a disgrace IMHO. cloning androids. WTH! if somebody wanted to write a book about the science of star trek 2020 edition it would be called: "The deconstruction of a legacy".

Some minor points of criticism that come up after watching it a couple of times, like:

- "That's an unusual necklace" What? No, it's just not. It's two rings on a chain. Thats basic af

- The intro consists of wildly divers imagery that does not really work harmoniously  together but is forced together with an overkill of visual effects (different blurs, shakes, transitions, chromatic aberations... stuff like that) 

and some other - but overall the show is amazing on many levels.
Episode 1 Shows great promise. Hoping for the best.
Amazing revival treats fans and material with respect unlike many other revivals!

Disappointingly unoriginal. The point where I abandoned plans to watch any more episodes was with the introduction of the idea of some fleshy android with Datas personality inside it, (apparently derived from a 'single neuron' of Data's ???)
I have fond memories of Stewart in TNG, but I really feel he is well past his productive years. I frankly found his faible performance a bit cringy.
Feels like a prelude to a series that could be a masterpiece.  Can't wait to see the rest.
Best pilot to a startrek series ever.
Great start, subtle writing, Stewart still at the top of his game.

After watching 1.1 twice, think a solution to this slow, too short introduction which seems to rely on nostalgic Next Gen fans, would have been to have the first episode begin with Picard running the armada to evacuate Romulus, show what happened at Mars, cover his resignation and self-initiated exile to his winery.  Then have 1.2  commence 14 years later.  There is little drama to the first half (consuming 1/2 it's running time! remember looking at the timer and thinking, crap, just get on with it) being expository for events never shown on screen and about pretty much nothing.  Compare this to the Mandalorian which in half the running time grabbed an audience.  I'll give this show more time out of deference to Picard being the best captain in Trek and second best character (well, Spock #1), as well as Stewart being a fine actor.  But this show has to get better -- a lot better.
so far so good an. Retired admiral Jean-Luc Picard -- still deeply affected by the loss of Lieutenant Commander Data and the destruction of Romulus -- steps into the next chapter of his life.
An okay story... feels rushed as a season opener though... I don't know who these Romulans everywhere are... and the music feels wrong... some of the direction/cinematography also

The first episode was not bad, better than all episodes of Discovery. But until now, the only character I care about is Picard and that won't be enough to keep me watching...3/5 for the first episode.
I just finished the fifth episode and I think that's it...I won't watch it further. I still don't understand what this series is about and honestly, I don't care anyway because I don't like the characters. This series feels like a nightmare Picard would have in TNG about the future, everything feels so unreal...
A refreshing take on the Star Trek Series! Great!

Fantastic!  Did an excellent job of reigniting TNG feelings without feeling like they were making a cash grab like so many other series have lately.  Stewart is as fantastic if not more than before and the cgi is breathtaking.
Hated Discovery but love Picard. Fan of TNG, DS9, VOY and this made me quite happy. Still can't believe they used Abrams time line but they did it well so I (shockingly) accept it.

Awesome show for fans of Star Trek! If you're looking for explosions and over the top action then this might not be for you. But if you love Next Generation, the stories, the characters, the world, and the messages then this show is a must watch.
Not good, not bad either.

Episode 1 was exceptional. It began slow and mellow however the action and activity picked up fairly quickly and thats when the story began and will continue to evolve throughout the series. I think Patrick Stewart has made an excellent comeback. He's stands up for what is right and is ready to embark on any space trek. So power-up your TV, Initiate All Access or Prime video and hit the play button for Star Trek: Picard.
It's simply banging TV.

The new series is off to a very strong start with great acting and a relaxed pace punctuated by enough fast moments to keep it moving forward.  Rather than trying to constantly dazzle the viewer on a roller coaster ride, ST: Picard invites the audience to dive into this man and his world, think about things, and appreciate a rich and complex (but not too complicated story).

It brought me a bit tear-eyed because we are reminded of "Captain Jean-Luc Picard", of Data, of Starfleet, all through the eyes of an older, retired admiral Picard. You could feel it when an interviewer asked Picard if he ever lose faith in Data because of the uprising of Synthetics (seen in the Short Trek 'Children of Mars') and he (and all of us) answered back "Never!". But we also felt it when he barked back "Because it was no longer Starfleet!". I am glad to see from the reviews that this was a Star Trek series that everyone enjoyed.  While I anxiously await for episode 2, I will keep watching the brilliantly written 'Remembrance' while sipping on some Tea. Earl Grey. Decaf (because we are all now a little bit older in all sense than when we first enjoyed The Next Generation).

It started off good, then became aweful. Too many stories, not enough substance. Character development was not there at all and was completely wasted by drama that left you not shedding a tear, even though you wanted to.
Loved every moment of the first episode! I hope the series continues this strong start and gives us a great story to enjoy. Patrick Stewart was amazing!
Old Man Stewart can still bring it.  His performance is worth putting up with the occasional plot holes and a questionable take on Star Fleet following the Dominion War.
This is everything I've been hoping Star Trek could be for so many years. I am on the edge of my seat with every moment of this show so far.

I have watched the first episode twice already. I think the storyline is intriguing, and the production values are great. I just hope that there isn't a long break between end of S1 and beginning of S2 though! Some shows can lose viewers when you have to wait a year or more for the next season. As a long time Trekkie, I am very happy to have Picard back! I also love ST Discovery and am eagerly waiting for the next season!

There are two franchises I love that have always been diverse & progressive; Star Trek & X-Men comic books. X-Men might be at the best it's ever been right now while Picard & Discovery feel like a bit of a travesty.

Star Trek used to have a sort of comfortable formula to it with types of episodes. Holodeck, character building, character bonding, world building, species lore, getting familiar with the ship itself, diplomacy, & battle. The characters were mostly chill, laid, back, & friendly. Episodes could be slice of life, horror, mystery, romance, bromance, or comedy. It had a unique architecture & it was colorful; a stark contrast from your run-of-the-mill sci-fi where everything is steel grey. Where is all of that now? Everyone is stressed out, aggressive, snarky, & unlikable. There are no friends, only acquaintances. Every episode is just more of the same thing.
Love the first ep, looking forward to years of this show, welcome back true star trek
First episode was great, brings back memories of the old tng. Can not wait for more.
Episode 1: Wow... Picard take down of Fox News....
Amazing! Best start to a series in years. Picard looks like it's going to be my favourite show of all time. Loved seeing Picard in action again, and my kids finally enjoyed a Star trek show with me.
Really compelling, visually, musically, storywise, acting... Only a few nitpicks... I feel a certain character did not need to die...
Loved it! I would love some more please :)
Way exceeded expectations.  I was glad he's not the same Picard from 20+ years ago.   But he still retains the moral core of the character.
Want to watch more......like a pair of comfortable shoes
I loved it, I love the tie in from the old, it was action and great pacing, and I can't wait till the second episode!
Loved this opening episode, old characters and new direction🖖🏼
I'd like to see what's coming next in the following episodes next week. Steward is old okay, but damn I like him acting as Picard again and the plot seems to go forward into the Star trek universe.
Absolutely loved it. Moves the franchise forward while respecting the established canon in a way that is refreshing. Jean-Luc is back, and in a great way that makes. Can't wait for more!
A love letter to The Next Generation

Nice cinematography, but boring plot that doesn't make sense. Tropes repurposed from other SF drama, with very few original ideas. Character motivations seem overly shallow. Worst of all for Star Trek fans, it completely vandalizes the character of Jean Luc Picard, turning this hero into a weak shell, blamed for all kinds of things not his fault.

Wonderful new storytelling that honors the Star Trek past but moves the story forward in a thoughtful and compelling way. Beautiful cinematography, fantastic acting, and strong writing combine to make Picard enjoyable for both long-time fans (such as myself) and newcomers to the franchise.

I will watch the rest of the season and see what happens. The first episode highlights how certain directors cannot come up with unique ideas and they use current politics and social norms to steer the plot of a character, that inspired strength of character, towards fear and fragility. After the first episode I am not filled with enthusiasm. I will readjust my opinion once the remainder of the season has completed.

After a promising opening episode the series has been on a downwards trajectory. Star trek's hopeful vision of the future is gone, replaced with more generic future dystopia SciFi. Patrick Stewart is great, as one would expect, but would I watch without him/TNG nostalgia? I don't think I would.
A good start to the series so far
I really enjoyed the first episode of PICARD -- the growth of the character and direction for him was very intriguing. Job well done so far!
And next, we have Sean Connery returning as James Bond...  sad

LOVED IT! Can't wait for the next episode!!!
So lovely to see old friends, really exciting storyline from start, beautiful to look at, so far everything I could have hoped for.
I was at the premiere in London to watch the episode and wow goosebumps watched again today and I got them again star trek is back ENGAGE

There is an emotional resonance with Picard that was needed in a Star Trek show.  It doesn't start off in the middle of a battle or heart pounding action.  It starts off quietly, and that is a good thing.  A very good thing.  It treats cannon and the characters with respect, and assumes the audience is willing to put down their cell phones and devices and actually pay attention.  So hopeful for the future of Star Trek.  Go boldly. . .

We're only one episode in and I see nothing so far which violates established canon, now being set after Admiral Picards retirement. It has a look and feel of following an old long-lost, yet fondly remembered, friend as he has a form of awakening to what and who he once was. This series appears to be a child of a number of ‘Questioning Starfleet' episodes as well as ‘Insurrection' and ‘Nemesis' and so retreads some ideas brought up in TNG, and indeed DS9 in many places, about the direction and moral compass of Starfleet and the Federation. In comparison, I watched and intensely disliked Discovery until they injected Pike and Spock into Season 2 which started to redeem the direction. Picard, to its credit, has none of the ham-fisted, canon-retconning/ignoring, disdain for the franchise that Discovery Season 1 gave me from The first episode. Picard Ep1, however, was a joy and has me looking forward to where they will go with this bold (and not so new) direction. I must add that the ability to only comment about, and rate,  the entire first season when having only seen Ep1 seems to be a failing on RTs side, as commenting on, and rating, the episode would make more sense.
What amazing start and so fresh, if you love the next generation you will want to watch Picard, he might be old now but he still our captain

I was pleasantly surprised by Picard.  Because of the disdain I have for Discovery, I was expecting the worst.  However, I found myself enjoying the show from beginning to end.  The slow pacing didn't really bother me.  I prefer that to the sometimes maniacal pacing in JJ Trek.  And I was thankful (relieved!) there was no jittery handheld camerawork or lens flares.  No, it did not feel like Star Trek to me.  But neither did the DS9 pilot.  And that's okay.  I think it will become more Star-Treky when they get a ship and leave Earth.
This is a fantastic addition to the Star Trek Universe. I'm so thrilled to see Jean-Luc on my screen again. Give me more! Oh, and a Pike series could really work too!
I love Picard!  Great continuation of TNG and goes off in a whole new direction.  Amazing production effects and design!
An incredible entry into the Star Trek saga. Not just because its Patrick Stewart, but the story is rich and the plot is already full of twists. Bravo!

After the first episode...

It's good, I liked it, but it is not like old Trek at all. It doesn't even seem to be in the same universe. They have sensational news media on Earth, which of course is a corporate money making entity. I thought we were beyond that by Kirk's era, let alone Picard's. And Jean-Luc Picard would not have let himself be so easily baited as he did with the news reporter. That was a shameful representation of Star Fleet's finest Captain.

Things I liked; well Data's daughter obviously. That is really cool. The show is more bloody and violent than our old Trek was. And the Borg cube being reclaimated was a very interesting touch.

I'm still on board for the next episode.

Thoroughly enjoyed this episode which exceeded my expectations, an absolute pleasure to see Patrick Stewart reprise his role of Picard. I liked the cinematic flare reminicent of the JJ Abrahams 2009 film, making it look like a film and not a TV series. I think they just nailed this episode, if it continues like this then it will be one of the best series of Star Trek.
Patrick Stewart is great, the show itself is cheesy and awful though. When you compare it too previous star trek series or modern greats like Mandalorian and Expanse its woeful

Great first episode.  Not your traditional broadcast Star Trek because production values and story lines are unconstrained.  More "human" in may respects.  I recall the awkwardness of TNG that first year...not here...jumps right into (the water is fine) the story and treats the audience like adults.

Amazing first episode! Can't wait to watch the rest of the season! I'm a huge star trek fan and had been waiting for this show to premiere since they first announced it. They have done everything right so far. Picard was by far the best captain they could have picked to center a new series around. The storyline is new and exciting yet nostalgic and touches on events from TNG. I recommend watching that series first as you will have a better understanding of the characters and some of the things taking place, but you definitely don't have to. The major story line is something that is new and not from the older series. So excited to see what's to come! If I could give more than 5 stars I would!

Loved seeing Sir Patrick Stewart back in this role. Writers did a phenomenal job re-introducing us to the character. Nothing felt rushed or contrived, it was very organic. It felt like a natural progression of time, given what Trekkies know of him from TNG. And the fact that Whoopi is coming back as Guinan next season, and Riker & Troi guest starring this season, gives me hope that this will be a wonderful exploration of humanity and all its potential.
Just seen episode 1, so far so good!
Very good first episode, looking forward to the rest of the series already.

I went into the first episode of Star Trek: Picard knowing that it would be very different from TNG. Patrick Stewart said as much when first announcing the series, and Discovery has shown us that Kurtzman's brand of Star Trek has a vastly different theme, tone, pace, palette, and narrative style than all of Rick Berman's productions (for better or worse). In saying that, Picard is an improvement over Discovery. Yes, one could argue that the plot points surrounding Dahj are somewhat uneven and contrived, and while the ending of episode is meant to be monumental, it is a bit cliché (if not unimpressive and underwhelming). On the other hand, the commanding and emotive presence of Stewart's late-in-life Picard is very appealing and attractive, and I appreciate that even after experiencing great loss, Picard is still a man driven by an unshakeable moral compass and sense of duty. I also enjoyed the subtle gratitude and devotion of the two Romulans working at his side at Chateau Picard; I think simple beats like this are more beneficial to Star Trek than heavy exposition, convoluted storylines, or derivative action sequences. The first episode also benefits from beautiful cinematography and an outstanding score. As long as the production team focuses on unpretentious arcs driven by relationships and character (and plot points that truly honor franchise canon as well as Roddenberry's vision), I think Picard will undoubtedly be an amazing Star Trek series.

The only bright moment in this show is the acting of Sir Patrick, which is the only thing propping this first episode up.  The writing is sub par, often forgetting the past Star Trek lore, cannon, etc...  The Romulans, once an alien race, now seem like humans with pointy ears, right down the the millennial speech patterns and vernacular.  The leading lady, Isa Briones, cant act.  The concept of "clones" are fine...  But then the writers make it impossible to believe when Dahj "activates" and kicks the crud out of several Romulans which would make sense if she were a ROBOT, NOT A HUMAN CLONE!!!  This is NOT Star Trek...  This is Soap Opera Trek...

This is not Star Trek. This is media & Hollywood destroying the foundation of Star Trek. No positive outlook on the future, just hype of violence, killing, and divided nations. This should not be called Star Trek. The acting is horrific and the plot introduces to much with no character development. A real Star Trek is needed now more than ever to promote the ideology of the old Starfleet, but instead we get another violent mind numbing and worst of all serialized garbage TV show.

I am a life-long Trek fan. I frequently re-watch all 700+ episodes and spend most of my free time talking about Star Trek. I can be pretty critical of it some times. Now. With that being said, I loved the first episode of Star Trek: Picard. This is a modern Star Trek televison series that feels like a natural evolution from TNG. But, it is still very much it's own thing just like everyone said it would be. Stewart is probably the best actor working on weekly TV right now and, so far, the writing seems pretty good too. The show really got its hooks into me almost immediately with a premise I wasn't fully expecting. I can tell that it's going to be one of those shows that I'm dying to see every week and then hate when it gets to the end credits and I have to reset the clock and wait a week again to see what happens next. These next nine weeks are gonna be a trip if Star Trek: Picard can keep this up and I'm so here for it. LLAP. 🖖

This isn't Star Trek: The Next Generation. It is something new and wonderful. It is a show that has beautiful elements of the past and deals with the passage of time. In one scene, Picard is being interviewed and his words gave me goose bumps. He reminds us all that values of the Federation must be protected and not taken for granted.

As an actor, Patrick Stewart at the age of 79 is as good or better than his previous ST roles. I highly recommend this series to any lover of Star
Trek.

Truly incredible reinvention! I loved all the deep cuts to TNG and using those as a basis for a new adventure. Performances and sets were incredible. I also loved that the first episode didn't get bogged down introducing all the major players and focused on establishing the new status quo.  Star treck has always been about exploring a the politics and ethics of now through the lens of sci-fi and I liked that the show has reinvented itself for 2020 in terms of structure and tone, instead of trying to just recapture and reproduce a carbon copy of what TNG was. This is everything Discovery wanted to be but succeeds because it moves forward instead fo trying to backfill the cannon.
Much better than expected. Great production value. Good intro. Seems to take its time a bit and show off some great cinematography.
Based on the first episode, this is a return to form for Star Trek, balancing poignant character work with intriguing science fiction mysteries.

The sparse moments the TNG guest-stars shine through, don't make up for a messy plot, forced drama and zero characterization in the new crew. Where discovery was overpacked with action, this is completely bland.
I wish the people working on the new Star trek series cared about the franchise I think I'm going to cancel my membership
Nonsensical nonsense.

Even the opening sequence gave me the chills. This promises to be Picard, dealing with lots of regret, more than a little PTSD, and trying to make the last chapeter of his life really matter. After the first episode, I'm all in.
Can drive a bus through the plot holes and bad writing.

It has me reaching back into memory of events that occured in Star Trek First Contact, TNG S2E09 'Measure of a Man', ST 2009, TNG S2E11 'Data's Day', ST Nemesis, and many other critical events that fit into the puzzle that is unfolding already in the first episode.  I enjoy when shows are able to do this.
Wow, much better than I thought it would be.
The first episode was well told, well acted, and it had beautiful visuals. As a MASSIVE fan of TNG, I couldn´t be more happy.

As it wasn't until about halfway through the first season of Discovery that I began to get disgusted with the stories and how it painted everything in the worst possible light, I'm reserving judgement here. However... Sir Pat's performance has been stunning - perhaps good actors are like wine and age makes them better - perhaps the best that he's delivered on screen.

We need Picard in 2020 more than ever. I especially hope he's able to touch a new generation of young people. I think watching The Next Generation growing up helped me to be a better person. It was a show about morality, about doing the right thing. It was't about killer aliens and special effects, even if it had some of those and they might have been what originally lured you in.
Nobody doubted whether he could reprise the role. It's who he is. My doubts, however, are whether the supporting cast could be as strong as the Enterprise D crew. The darker and more action oriented Star Treks were never as good as the ones where Picard and his lot were going around the universe stirring up random trouble, or inadvertently creating a sentient holographic Mark Twain with the Holodeck. Special Effects have come a long way since TNG, but they're a dime a dozen and no longer what we care about. 
It seems the new series picks up on the lowest point of The Next Generation's storyline from the last feature film, Nemesis. However, it also takes from the final episode of the TV series, which was arguably better than any of the feature films.  Maybe this is a chance for redemption. Time will tell.
The premier episode was pretty good! My only complains are the action scenes.. Sir Patrick Stewart clearly can't run, so don't cut away constantly to try to cover it up. Put him in a 24th century wheelchair or Segway or something. And that explosion, and him suddenly just waking up at home, unharmed? I felt like I might have blacked out or skipped some parts. It was a little hurried toward the end, like they had to edit a lot out. Should have been a longer episode or split between two. Other than that it's off to a pretty good start! It exceeded my expectations, since these days I try to never get my hopes up.

Star Trek Picard's premiere episode, Remembrance takes a meaningfully-paced and character centered approach to introduce us to a new era in the Federation's 'post super nova' world where Jean-Luc makes a life for himself at home in his French villa. Lots of meaningful nods to the series and hook-you-in conversations make the storyline instantly interesting. With sprinkles of 23rd Century technology that you'd expect to see and an insanely cinematic experience that leaves you breathless, this is excellent TV and undeniably Star Trek. Sir Patrick Stewart and Isa Briones bring the entire show on fire! Touching, shocking and with a hint of magic!
This show has absolutely nothing in common with Star Trek. It's as it was written by people who know about Star Trek casually. I doubt that they saw one whole episode between them.

Episode 1 was great.  I wasn't a fan of the Next Gen movies, but Picard looks like it might be the conclusion for that cast that we always wanted.   Let's hope that the series continues in the manner it started.

Despite Alex Kurtzman's involvement, the first episode wasn't too bad.  Maybe that's because Star Trek Discovery is just monumentally worse by comparison.  It's great seeing Patrick Stewart back in the role, there were some nice nods to the past, and some interesting plots setup I hope they don't flush down the toilet in future episodes.  It definitely doesn't feel like TNG, but I didn't expect it to.  It wasn't perfect, but there was enough here to keep me watching.  I just wish Kurtzman would leave Trek alone because I'm constantly gonna be waiting for this all to fall apart as the season progresses.
What an amazing start - everything I wanted and so much more
A complete disaster from beginning to end. Awful.

Loved it! Nice to see a sci-fi show that starts with humans and story instead of with  tech and random violence (not that it doesn't have a couple of fighting scenes, of course). Welcome back, Jean-Luc!

As always, Patrick Stuart is truly masterful in his portrayal of Captain Picard. The story is original and the special effects are extraordinary. The photography is wonderful and the direction is great. This series is truly unmissable

Incredibly mediocre. First episode opened with way too much exposition "telling" us the backstory rather than showing it in the most cringeworthy way possible. The new characters aren't at all compelling so far. The dialogue was just bad - the Romulan who told Picard he needed to "be the Captain they remember" might as well have winked at the audience it was so on the nose. Costuming was dreadful, since when does Picard wear a shirt with a tie in the 25th century, not even an attempt to make it look like the future. The alien make-up was the only redeeming feature and even then, the latest movies and television series just can't seem to get Vulcans/Romulans ears quite right.

But the real problem with the show is the premise. I don't buy that the Federation - which has gone to the assistance of their enemies *numerous* times would give up and simply refuse to help the Romulans during a crisis. And the Jean-Luc Picard who I grew up watching, in the event of the rescue's fleet destruction, would be on subspace in a flash calling Admiral Riker, Admiral Janeway, Captain Worf - who'd then call Chancellor Martok, First Minister Kira, Captain Dax - and before you know it a new rescue fleet has been assembled.  I simply cannot buy that Jean-Luc Picard was faced with a challenge of such magnitude that he simply gave up and went to mope around his family vineyard for 20 years.

More to the point, I am uninterested in any story universes in which my heroes, who have faced such enormous challenges in the past and held onto their ideals, have now given up and exiled themselves to grow bitter and angry. Star Trek has always been about optimism and hope and so far Picard has neither.

I'll update my review if the situation improves but so far this looks like another dreary bleakquel taking itself too seriously, what has happened to the fun, intelligent sci-fi franchise I loved?

I thoroughly enjoyed this first episode, Stewart IS Captain Picard, there's a seamless transition to his new age. The premiss of the story is strong and believable, I hope that this resurrection of the Star Trek name is not deluded as the "Discovery" series. Discovery adds the name Start Trek to a wholly unworthy show. Far too much personal interaction and concern for who's involved with who, which is nothing more than a space filler for a lack of storyline. Keep it up Picard!!!!

Based upon the first episode only at this point, I was very concerned that my excitement would overtake my ability to view the show objectively.   I was introduced to star trek with the next generation when I was 8 or 9 years old, I have had so many issues with the visual ecstatic of the most recent films such as why the technology is somehow more advanced in the past.  What I've seen from this series thus far is that visually it's been able to continue the physical look of the Next Gen/DS9/VOY era but using the same/familiar elements and aging them about 20 years as the timeline follows.  Even the sounds work as they are familiar and enhanced to grow with the time frame.  So far everything I've seen in terms of lore being followed and honoured makes me very happy.  Star Treks acting has flared of brilliance over the various series but at the same token if the surrounding world doesnt make me feel like I'm watching star trek... then I cant believe it actually is.  This is the same reason that the show The Orville is loved by ST fans where as ST Discovery is not.

I had hope for 15 minutes than began the horrible pacing, ridiculous dialogue, sub past techno babble. I wanted this to be good, instead it's just more of the same junk they've been doing since the 2009 reboot. Lazy writing, poor pacing, even the film editing had obvious errors that wouldn't fly on a show with one tenth the budget power episode.
Pros: Patrick Stewart's acting is on point
Data and Picard playing cards (though it's just a dream, so it's also a let down) 
The actress who plays the AI scientist at the institute gave an amazing performance though she had the worst line in the show (clone a positronic brain with intact memories from a single neuron is just patently ridiculous and the most egregious Kurtzmanism in the show)

Cons: Horrible writing; also according to the credits there were 5 writers for the first episode, and boy did it feel like it. The exchange at the end where they introduce the Twin clone, is so horribly awkward. It felt like a 5th graders first attempt at writing a romance novel, if all they had to go off were the front covers of a bunch of Harlequins from the 80s.
Bad pacing and editing : There are 18 producers that is ridiculous, the show looks like a bunch of kids fighting over how to do a group project in school, and then storming off to their desks to do their work on their own. There cuts that make no sense. The events of the first episode felt stretched out for the first few minutes as if they were trying to fill time to make up their network block, then from the introduction of Dhaj onward everything was so compressed it destroyed any sense of discovery or reveal. Realistically they could've made the events of this first episode a full season arc, and it would've at least had emotional playoffs, instead all this episode established is new characters are one dimensional and don't expect anyone to stick around long.

All in all this is the death knell for ST. I have JJ two films to get good, couldn't be bothered to even watch the last one. I gave Kurtzman 3 episodes of STD, before I gave up on that. I was willing to give Picard the benefit of the doubt because they got so many of the old cast on board for cameos, but if this is indicative of the quality of story they are going to be putting out I won't be watching.

Gene Roddenberry is turning in his grave over this show.  In the 80's, the Kirk crew were shocked and confused at cursing.  Now Admirals drop F-bombs as easily as normal speech.  Nostalgia aside, this is not a Star Trek series, its a 10 hour movie with a weak base for a story.

I am happy to see Picard back in the seat, but I am afraid they waited too long to make this series happen.  As an actor, Mr. Stewart will be great, but any action scene will be difficult, as seen in the first episode.
Serious and emotional. A show that is worthy of the title character and star.

I have been looking for to this since it's announcement and boy was I not disappointed. It looked fantastic, great beginning to the story and some really nice touches to TNG. Can't wait for the next episodes to arrive.
Simply fantastic. Had everything a hardcore die hard fan could want as well as making it fresh for new viewers to watch and enjoy.

As a trekkie for decades and having grown up with TNG this doesn't even resemble Roddenberry's Star Trek.  It is not cerebral or thought provoking in any way.  It is not a story about exploring space and humanity as the Trek of decades ago. I recognize Patrick Stewart but Jean Luc Picard is not there at all.  This is just another Hollywood rehash throwing in old characters for nostalgic purposes.  Those who don't know the real Star Trek of old will find this a yawner.  Very disappointed.  Sadly, Roddenberry's Star Trek is gone and has been for many years.

Excellent premiere. It handled a lot of exposition in it's first episode well, without having everything told to me and also leaving the right amount of questions to be intrigued and not lost, all leading to a conclusion of the episode that was thoroughly satisfying.

A Shakespearean trained actor exemplifies it's the little things that count. Stewart shows Picard's true character. He has aged, vulnerable yet still has the fire in his belly to rise from his bed and fight for what is right. I look forward to this saga.

It also seems to already start answering some questions without giving the audience any time to think about things. I can confirm that this is NOT The Mandalorian, but better than Star Trek Discovery so far (which isn't really saying much). I would have made the plot less confusing, and left most (if not all) questions unanswered... for now. Introduce ideas, let them be for a while, then you can pull twists and turns later once audiences think they've figured things out. That would have been better. Anyway at least it's not horrible.

FANTASTIC!! From someone who has seen TNG more times than I can count, I'm all in and I'm not disappointed. I felt like I was returning to my all-time favourite show and experiencing something totally new at the same time--with all the coolness and modernness of J.J Abrams Trek but all the soul of what TNG, and maybe all of Trek, was trying to be. I'm fine with a more character-driven and earthier premier/show, a lot of exposition and a slow-burn to explore this universe and meets its people 20 years on before 'going back out into the cold'. We were warned it would be different. Sir Patrick is a legend and I believe his genius along with the writers will hold most sceptics through the bits they don't like as they adjust and find patience with this kind of story-telling. And to have Data back in some form, yes!--a compelling plot connected to some of the best episodes of TNG. I can't wait for the next. I hope there are many more to come. Well done Picard team and thank you.

I just don't understand some of the reviews I am reading about Star Trek: Picard. If you watched TNG, you should watch Picard. Full stop. That is the only review you need, if you want to know what happened in Picard or even in the Star Trek universe after the end of the prime timeline shows, this is your chance.

But also, the subtle passion being shown in this role by Sir Patrick Stewart, is just breathtaking to me in the first episode, i was drawn to full outbursts of emotion at moments, and that is not super common for me.

I do not want to spoil anything, but you can feel a clear love for the story and tapestry of Picard's life, if you were paying attention was always a clearly highly tragic character. If you watched TNG and the following movies, every note I watched in this premiere is genuine to the character and all of the motivations are clear to me for him. This is a man that has lived his own life over and over again (thanks Q and random alien probe), and even an entire other life as well, who has experienced love and loss we can only imagine, and honestly, this is where science fiction shines. This is not an enterprise bubble gum establishment show, and this i think is part of the tone of the reviews i am reading, The reviewers seem to not understand the character and in turn the universe.

I CAN NOT WAIT for the next episode.

And knowing it already is greenlit for a second season, really shows how the showrunners understand what they have made because this show is really amazing already in my opinion.

But honestly, I am a person that you can not talk to Star Trek about in the car with, simply because I will get into an accident (and have... 3 times...) So take this all through the lens of a real fan, but one that knows the faults of the franchise.
Anxious to see where this show goes! First episode was definitely a different experience than I expected.

Solid opening episode that sets up a whole bunch of plot threads for the season. Despite the departure in tone from TNG, Picard is back with the same values, same mannerisms, and low tolerance for degrading nonsense. There's a scene where a character has a self-realization that places her into a category that she believes is soulless and "bad", and for every self-depreciating bit of propaganda she recites, he turns it around in the best way. This continues the optimistic side of Trek without pretending that getting there won't mean dealing with challenges and setbacks. Other lovely details: his portrayal of being a now aged Picard who has to manage physical limitations while trying to make the world a better place.

You might hear some criticisms like "romulans can't spit acid" (perhaps they've never heard of cyanide capsules) or about the character having parts of herself activate like lightning. Fortunately the writers did not feel the need to hold our hands and explain everything in episode one. They've avoided anal retentiveness: story and themes are more important than debates as to whether fictional technology set 30 years in the future after TNG can exist or not, especially when that tech is a mystery that is set up to be explained in future episodes. Season 1 is off to a fine start!
Best Trek since the 90s!

This is only a review of the first episode, because I won't be watching any more. The entire concept of "cloning positron brains for super powers" is ludicrous if you've watched even one episode of the show dealing with Data and his brain. Apparently if you break off a piece from one of your RAM sticks, you'll be able to clone an entire new computer, complete with the hard drive contents. Then if you shove it into a cadaver, it will give it super powers and it will remember what porn you downloaded. For reals. 

This serves as a sequel to Discovery, another travesty that tries to be "edgy and kewl" instead of being Star Trek. Discovery + Picard = Discard.
This show is pale and tasteless imitation of everything I used to love about Star Trek

This is what happens when a company that has never actually produced the once-loved IP they now own outsource production to a man who has generated nothing but franchise-killing flops. Discovery & now Picard are shows trading on the name Star Trek and looking for an audience that's watching Riverdale and Gossip Girl. The dialogue is dull while thinking it's clever and deep. The plot has more holes than a washing machine tub. An hour on Memory Alpha would have shown the writers all of the canon they were ignoring in the pilot ep alone. If Redstone doesn't fire Kurtzman, the I pray she sells Trek to NBC so that Seth MacFarlane can fix it.

This show is beyond stupid. "Cloned" Android brains, Data suddenly having twin daughters, Romulans with blood that dissolves human beings?

An unmitigated disaster. I've never been so disappointed in a Star Trek show as I am now. I thought the show would recover from the rocky start but instead it just slid into one ridiculous mystery box after another with a Picard that is practically unrecognizable to anyone familiar with the character before this show. What they did with Seven of Nine is a complete shame. She's a cold-blooded killer bent on revenge that learns after killing all her enemies that maybe it's not a good thing to kill...for revenge. Didn't she learn about morality years ago on Voyager? That's just the beginning of a ride that is Star Trek in name only. Terrible show.

With a lot of recent controversy around Trek, Star Trek Picard is refreshingly welcome. Having grown up with Star Trek as a child of the 80's, even to this day, at least once a year I re-watch TNG, DS9, VOY and ENT. It never gets old. With Picard, we are treated to a wonderfully rich backstory that is TNG with Sir Patrick Stewart reprising his iconic role.

I am VERY pleased that everything I loved about Captain Picard in TNG and the TNG movies is back in this new show and Patrick has clearly given an immense amount of attention and passion to lovingly bring this beloved character back to life for one last adventure.

The cinematography is fantastic! The acting is superb and the nods to the characters TNG backstory and roots is fabulous for those of us who grew up with, and have a deep affection for this character, as well as the others who are making cameo appearances.

I've only had the good fortune of watching the first episode thus far and I can honestly say, no TV show has been this hotly anticipated for me ever! With the usual distractions (fiddling about on my phone or PC while something is on in the background), for the first time in the last 10 years I was completely glued to my TV screen with wonder and awe.

I wish the cast and crew of Star Trek Picard all the best and I know before I've even seen the rest of the first season that I am going to love it. I cannot wait to see how this story unfolds and am thrilled that there is a Trek show that so strongly resonates with me on a level that reminds me why I fell in love with the original Next Generation-era TV shows in particular.

Sir Patrick Stewart - you legend!

Sadly I was hyped for this and got disappointed again like with Star Trek Discovery...
Picard is nothing like the TNG Version. The storyline is pretty much garbage and nothing of Star Trek is in here again... No good future for humanity, no positivity, just dumbed down show that carries a name it isn't worth...

Great acting, really great potential with story, and the visuals were top notch. I love TNG, but if this show references it too much, it won't be able to stand well on its own. Fortunately it appears the writers paid close attention to this and made sure to not overwhelm the audience with technobabble.

Star Trek Picard is a jumbled nonsensical mess that violates Star Trek canon and the very notion of human intelligence. Star Trek Picard is a sequel not to Star Trek The Next Generation, but Star Trek DISCOVERY! Very disappointed!

Finally, we're back to real Star Trek again! It may not be the kind of Trek where everything is okay at the end of 42 minutes, but unlike Discovery this has smart, interesting characters that have a reason to be there and that you want to learn more about. It doesn't seem like each character is plotting against the rest of the cast - motives are reasonable and logical and fit within the established universe and characters. Looking very much forward to next week's episode, It's so exciting to finally be back in the 24th century proper!

Started watching Trek in the early 70s and I've been a Trekker my whole life. I loved the show. Great seeing Picard again, still standing by principal in his life. I can't wait for the rest of the season.

It feels rushed and disparate at times. The script seems to have been oversimplified in places that makes the dialog very, very awkward. It introduces SO MUCH in such a small time frame that I can't imagine NOT being a trekkie trying to watch this. This should have been an hour and a half episode, not crammed into half the time. I think the director and editors really need to pump the breaks at times. IGN said it best, "...the premiere episode does feel somewhat disjointed, as if some connective tissue between scenes is missing."
*** Spoilers hereafter ***
Having said that, it does find a groove right after Picard gets blown to hell, only problem is, the episode doesn't have that much time left before it's over. And as a trekkie, I love the references to ST canon; everything from Data's daughter (which I'm going back to watch that episode on TNG), to Commander Maddox's wild obsession with making Data clones (another TNG episode that questions if Data is sentient). This feels like a sci-fi series with Star Trek tones. It's not a typical Trek like TNG, Voyager, Enterprise, or DS9. So be prepared for that. And I will say, the episode left me sleepless last night, wondering what happens next!  A good sign for any new series.
Fantastic first episode! Glad to see Patrick Stewart bring back this iconic character in a new and exciting storyline! Bravo!

Its so great to see Patrick Stewart back as Picard, as well as allowing him to play with new aspects of the character, while retaining that core. The effects are stunning, very high quality, and it almost feels like a movie. It feels like Star Trek that I used to watch as a kid, but with a new proper outlook, as opposed to the somewhat hokey morality plays of TNG (which were done far better in DS9). If you want Picard pontificating on right and wrong, and every issue being wrapped up in the last 10 minutes of the episode, you probably won't enjoy Picard. If you want something more cerebral that you can wrap your head around and discuss with others, while still getting the occasional exciting action, then watch Picard now!

If you're just looking for a quick "thumbs-up or thumbs-down" vote from me, "Remembrance" gets two very enthusiastic thumbs up. This premiere had to meet two basic criteria in order to win me over: 1) Give me enough call-backs to the Trek that I know and love to give me the warm-and-fuzzies; and 2) Tease enough of a new, mysterious Trek in the as-of-yet unseen 2390s to convince me that there was more to this than just nostalgia. It succeeded handily on both counts. Sir Patrick Stewart has fully re-embodied the character of Jean-Luc Picard (albeit with an extra helping of regret), and the supporting cast is magnificent. Jeff Russo‘s score is gorgeous, and the production values are top notch. Much like its older sibling, Star Trek: Discovery, there are fans who will find ST:PIC's overt social commentary heavy-handed. But I am not one of those fans. Honestly, my biggest complaint was that it was only 46 minutes long.
Loved seeing old characters brought back to life with a fresh take on what's going on in Picard's life. So far... great acting and an intriguing plot. Looking forward to the rest of the series.

If you're expecting to watch a Star Trek show, look elsewhere. The Picard premiere was full of lazy writing and tired tropes.

Picard has continued the trend of gutting the very heart of what Star Trek is...or was.

The Romulan Empire could not have done the same and they have their own ships anyway? Starfleet just gives up after this, hence Pickard resigns? Dash switches on and is suddenly a perfect fighter/killer, a super hacker and leaps a super hero 30 feet. She tells Pickard everything and he just accepts her instantly? You can create a Data positronic brain by using some "fractal duplication" from a single "cell" of said brain !!!??? 



This is garbage. Good actors, music and sets save it from 1 or 0.5.

Amazing! A great peak in at the life of one of our favorite captains that maintains the core of who he was when we last saw him 20 years earlier, still hopeful, willing to help anyone, particularly the crew he sees as family. But also acknowledges that time has past, he's 94 years old, he's long retired.

I think the series is off to a great start, if this the first taste of what the series has to offer, we (audience) are about to embark on a great adventure. The first episode looks and feels like we are watching a movie. The cinematography, story and editing are pleasing to look at. Some viewers are saying this series is saying Star Fleet went rogue, I would not say that at all.  The audience must remember you are looking at things through the jaded lens of Picard (again focused on Picard) which has been influenced by what happened to him during his tenure in Star Fleet. To setup an interesting story the camera will be forced to step away from Picard from time to time to setup the other story arcs, these other story arcs will influence Picard later in the series. Does this look like the other Star Trek, the answer is no, it is better because now instead of the story being completed in 1hr it will now be completed over the series which will give the producers more time to explore in detail different story elements. I can not wait for the rest of the cast to be revealed and introduced! Also, Star Trek has been a series that takes current day events and overlays them in the Sci-Fi universe of Star Trek which I think they are off to a good start. Let's Boldly go where TNG has not gone before and explore the inner depths of Captain (Admiral) Picard! I am interest in seeing what will be revealed later in the series and the many other it may have. Live long and prosper!

Well, it's certainly not Star Trek in any way, shape or form, but as generic, poorly written, just about watchable sci-fi, it has some promise. It's very slow, has far too much exposition, Stewart's not playing Picard, more more like Charles Xavier. He's chewing the scenery a little too much acting wise. I felt like I was watching a 10th sequel X-Men movie. The bits without Dhaj in aren't bad, but the whole thing goes down the toilet when she turns up. Picard's Romulan house staff are just humans with pointy ears. It's all very slick, expensive, and admittedly looks lovely. While it's far far better than STD, it still ain't Star Trek in any way.

The opening dream sequence with Data wearing a First Contact uniform aboard the Enterprise D is horribly wrong. I suppose you could explain it away by it being a dream, but it just looked like a schoolboy error made by someone who doesn't know what they're doing.

Some might dislike the darker tone, but Star Trek has always been about interrogating our current state and applying aspirational values to that milieu. The changes in the world of Star Trek mirror our own. The '90s were a time of naive optimism and earnest social progress. Contrast with today and you see the rise of nationalist fascism across the world. Picard is the perfect character to embody this existential crisis. I feel as he does, but there's hope. 

It's such a treat to to see the characters and universe I grew up with in the '90s get another chance at expanding the story with an unprecedented level of production and writing talent. Every scene has some kind of world building revealing a depth of knowledge about the Star Trek canon. I can't wait to see where this leads.

Patrick Stewart's Post-Starfleet Picard is aged, bitter, disillusioned and resigned to be a footnote in late 24th century Federation history, living out the rest of his life on his family's vineyard.  Decades have past, and his faith in the institutions he used to represent have wavered, due to a policy that stood to put pragmatism over compassion.  It's at this point in his life that a visitor comes to his vineyard, seeking his help, drawn to him by some unknown instinct.  

This sets the stage for the newest incarnation of the Star Trek franchise, a show that will examine the events at the turn of the 25th century, the state of affairs of the Federation society, the aftermath of the Hobus supernova on the Romulan Star Empire (as depicted in the 2009 Star Trek film by J.J. Abrams,) and Jean-Luc Picard's place in it all.

The pilot episode, "Remembrance," does a great job of setting the stage, giving enough exposition about the past few decades without ignoring the driving motivations that will see Picard leave the Vineyard to unravel a mystery that promises to tie many of the main themes of the show into a compelling narrative that will appeal to many fans of the franchise and new fans alike.

Unlike its sister series Star Trek: Discovery, Picard seems to flow at a more deliberate pace, more concerned with deeper characters than driving action set-pieces, though there is still plenty of action in the pilot episode to be had.  It continues the legacy of Star Trek: The Next Generation, without being beholden to the episodic formula, or need to fill time in a TV season with filler.

I recommend the show, obviously.  But more than that, I recommend that you actually watch it yourself and make up your own mind on it.  Especially if you're a fan of the character, and the franchise.  Please don't allow the disgruntled youtube gatekeepers to determine for you what is or is not REAL Star Trek, that is only something you can do for yourself.  Personally, I am excited to see the rest of the season, and hope that it can live up to its pilot, if not improve upon it.

Thanks.
Great new addition to the Star Trek universe.

I really wanted to give this a chance. I love Star Trek, I always have... but this is not Star Trek. This is a melodramatic Dystopian soap opera that is appropriating the name Star Trek. No disrespect to the acting ability of Sir Patrick Stuart but my love for Picard is not enough to make me ignore the horrible direction in which they are taking trek. Star Trek is meant to be a utopian view future where we've moved past our shortcomings as a race, to face new adversity not be mired in the past, this show is an insult to all that has come before it. (With the exception of discovery which has the exact same problem)
This note reflect what I feel about the show so far and might change with next episodes. But for now... AMAZING ! Looks great, finally Star Trek is back.

Yikes. This show dosen't feel like Star Trek. I did not like the whole story with Dahj, she is OP and her lines are quite cringe. I also feel like this show don't focus on Picard but rather Dahj who I do not like.

The first three episodes - which is what most of the professional reviews are based on - were okay in parts, but it went downhill fast. Forgettable characters if you can call them that at all and mystery boxes with no payoff at all. And that's just, when you don't compare the show to its source material. Then it gets downright insulting. Especially the ending is a slap in the face of everyone, who was a Star Trek Fan before 2009.

Also the show isn't suitable for a younger audience (traditionally Star Treks core demographic). Lots of graphic violence, swearing and sexually charged dialogue. Also some weird messages, like: Putting women in charge of an organization automatically makes it incredibly racist, sexist an xenophobic and every queer character has to be a psychpath. Weird, considering, it was marketed as a progressive show.

This production looks and sounds amazing, in ways The Next Generation simply could not for its time.  Additionally, it is a wonderful continuation of Jean-Luc Picard's story, that in the first episode alone demonstrates that Picard is unwilling to betray his own moral principles, even if it means living in a life of isolation and depression.  Picard does an amazing job of giving Patrick Stewart the same kind of latitude to explore the character and make the same powerful Picard-esque soliloquies and speeches TNG fans came to love as part of his character.

Becoming involved with Dajh immediately ignites a flame within Picard that very quickly re-ignites the spark we have all come to know and love from the good captain.  Based upon what we have already seen it is quite clear that this story, is going to take Picard to places he, in his solitude; and us as fans could never have expected - and I look forward to seeing the rest of it!!!!
Completely lived up to the hype! Man, I absolutely loved it. Can't wait for the rest.
Marvel type show set in a kinda star trek universe. Ok for what it is but no where near a trekkie program.
Excellent, going straight to the essence of what the Star Trek universe is about, cannot wait to see how the season develops. Well paced and well acted.
